speechtext:
Before proceeding to the daily routine of business, I want to give my ruling on a matter raised by the hon. member for Calgary Northeast a few days ago.
As all hon. members know, there were some technical difficulties with the Votes and Proceedings of Wednesday, June 3, 1992 in recording the divisions on motions of amendment at report stage of Bill C-81, an act to provide for referendums on the Constitution of Canada. A reprint was immediately ordered to accurately reflect the results recorded by the Clerk.
In his point of order, the hon. member for Calgary Northeast was concerned by the fact that some of the names appearing under the listing for paired members also appeared under the "yeas" or "nays".

I would appear therefore that some members whose names were paired with others indicating that they would not be voting had in fact cast votes either for or against certain motions.

Should or could action be taken by either the Speaker or the House in regard to this situation.
Standing Order 44.1 specifically deals with paired members. It explains that a register of paired members is kept at the table "in which any member of the government party and any member of an opposition party may have their names entered together by their respective Whips to indicate that they will not take part in any record division"; independent members sign in their own right.

The names of these paired members are inscribed immediately following the list of "yeas" and "nays" for each recorded division.

However, the Standing Orders are completely silent on the question of a broken pair; there is no penalty provided for, nor any corrective action suggested. As the 21st edition of Erskine May explains on page 350:
The Speaker has ruled that agreements to pair are private arrangements between Members and in no sense matters in which either he or the House can intervene.

Although Westminster's rules relating to pairing are different from those employed in Canada, the basic principle enunciated in May holds true for our practice, that is to say: a pairing agreement is a private arrangement in which neither the House nor the Speaker can intervene, according to the Standing Orders as now written.

Any change to our current practice would require amendments to our Standing Orders. The Standing Committee on House Management which has as part of its permanent mandate the power to review and report on the Standing Orders, procedure and practice in the House, may wish to look into this question. I thank the hon. member for Calgary Northeast for bringing this matter to the attention of the House.

Mr. Speaker, the Official Opposition House leader can call it whatever he likes but I hope he will listen to my remarks. He will see that it is no such thing. I think, and hope, that he will agree with me when I finish.
I introduced the amendment to alleviate some of the concerns that many of us have about Bill C-70 and the jury selection process. Allow me to explain to the House what the bill is and what we are trying to do.
The bill before us today is a result of the decision in the case of Regina v. Bain. It is a major decision of the Supreme Court of Canada. The judgment was rendered
Government Orders
January 23, 1992. In that decision the Supreme Court ruled that sections 634(1) and (2) are inconsistent with section 11(d) of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms in so far as they provide the Crown with a combination of peremptory challenges and stand-bys four times the number permitted the accused.
As the court noted:
The observer of the process is bound to conclude that, absent some control, the Crown possesses a substantial advantage and can effectively influence the make-up of that jury under partisan considerations.
Let me translate that into plain English. We have a system in which the Crown prosecutor has a different level of challenges. The Crown can follow a different process. It has a better crack at excluding people from a jury than does the defence. The Supreme Court basically said: "Make it a level playing field".
The court gave Parliament six months to bring forward a remedy. That was on January 23, 1992.1 know that the parliamentary secretary has acted and the government has acted. It has introduced a bill and we have expedited it in committee.
However, the government's legislation deals specifically with the narrow and very limited recommendations that come from the Supreme Court decision, which was limited to the very specific questions that were asked in the case. I believe that it was a case concerning sexual assault and the lower court's ruling that the Crown could not use stand-asides to influence the make-up of the jury-
My concern, and I know I am not alone in this, is that we have gone through the process of drafting and debating amendments to the Criminal Code without making full use of this opportunity to really effect meaningful and innovative change that will bring the code into the modem age and into the future.
Instead, we have done the least that could be expected of us and left the real work for another day. What kind of real work am I talking about? There have been numerous studies and inquiries that have shown that the justice system is not always fair. Justice is not always equally available to Canadians as a result of procedural flaws, including the jury selection process. This is not only because of the use of stand-asides by the Crown-even back in 1980 the Law Reform Commission drew this to

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
our attention-but because of the nature of what we call peremptory challenges.
I will give an example. The report of the aboriginal justice inquiry of Manitoba found that aboriginal people were excluded from the jury in the Osbourne case because of their race. The defence used a peremptory challenge to exclude six aboriginal people. This was a case concerning the murder of an aboriginal woman in a community with a large aboriginal component.
As the report states:
The jury was not representative of the community from which it was
drawn and in which the crime was committed.
In modern Canada there are instances in which people have been excluded from juries because of their race.
It is my understanding that one of the ideals we strive for in the justice system is to provide for the selection of a jury that does represent the community. The peremptory challenge may in fact stand in the way of achieving this goal. Perhaps it should be incumbent upon counsel to provide cause for every challenge. After all, the Supreme Court of Canada in the Bain decision noted that:
The peremptory challenge is purely subjective.
Perhaps we need greater objectivity; if you do not like the person's face or you do not like the colour of his or her skin, you can challenge and you do not have to justify why you are challenging.
This is one of the concerns we could have looked at when we opened up this part of the Criminal Code. We are going to have to do it in the near future. I know the Attorney General of Ontario-I have a letter from the Attorney General of Ontario to the Minister of Justice of Canada-is determined to see these concerns addressed and these flaws remedied. The Attorney General said so publicly just a month ago in Toronto.
We have yet to have any substantive assurance from the federal government in this regard. In fact, by introducing legislation that killed the Law Reform Commission the government has given every indication it is not prepared at all to do the kind of work that needs to be done in this area. There had been some hope when the minister asked the commission to begin work on
multiculturalism and the law that we could begin the process of updating our laws.
Were it not for the articles of Mr. David Vienneau in The Toronto Star after he obtained a copy of a consultation paper from the Law Reform Commission which was looking specifically at a trial by jury and had drafted well thought out and researched recommendations in its final report, we would not have known that the government was even looking at this area. This is a copy of the draft consultation paper by the Law Reform Commission. It is incomplete.
I suggest to the government and to you, Mr. Speaker: just take The Toronto Star for today and look at the headline "Anti-Black Racism Deep, Lewis Warns Ontario". This is a very relevant issue. Mr. Vienneau of The Toronto Star really did us a service to get this report public and get it out. We did not even see this in our committee.
This is not the way government should work. It should not hide things from Parliament, especially when racism is such a huge issue in our major cities in Canada today.
This report has recommendations that address the issue of proportional representation of the accused's racial, religious or other minority characteristics on juries, recommendations that would improve our ability to ensure that juries represent a fair cross-section of the community, and recommendations on page 38 regarding peremptory challenges and challenges for cause. I suggest some members of the House, including the House leader of the Official Opposition who I know is a lawyer, might want to have a look at this because it deals with stand-asides and peremptory challenges.
Basically, if I can summarize, it says maybe we should look at this because it is a purely subjective standard. As I said before a defence counsel or even Crown counsel could have people stand aside because they are black, Jewish, aboriginal or whatever. They can do that.
I am not saying they are doing it, although there was one instance in the case I have cited. At least we need to have some study of that and we need to look at that. I am not trying to hold up the government's bill. I understand the parliamentary secretary has to get this done in six months, although he could go back to the court as the government has done in the past and say we need more time. If the court does not like it, he could blame it on
June 11, 1992

the socialists down here and say they caused all the problem and ask for more time.
The Law Reform Commission's report called Minister's Reference, Jury Selection on Multicultural Issues would provide members of Parliament with a learned impartial non-partisan opinion. That is why I do not want an in-house study by the government or by the Department of Justice. I know that the government likes that but we want a non-partisan report. We want something that can be tabled in the House of Commons. In short, we want this study completed.
If the government were prepared to say firmly that today, now in the House, I am prepared to consent to going to third reading and putting this bill through today. If not, I am not prepared to consent.
The member from Nova Scotia, the official government House leader, can call that blackmail or call it what he likes. I call it good parliamentary tactics and doing my job as justice critic for the NDP and trying to get the government committed. I know the government really is committed and I know the member from Niagara Falls, the parliamentary secretary, is committed to having these issues looked at in the best possible way.
It is my hope that we can bring this in and we can get this report completed before the law is challenged because visible minorities, women or others are excluded from juries through abuse of the peremptory challenge. We do not want this to start going back to the court.
These kinds of time constraints can only result in hastily written and often barely adequate legislation, that is the six months, the stop-gap legislation.
I suggest that Canadians deserve better. By bringing forward this amendment it is my hope that the government will agree to look at least a short distance into the future and that it will agree to at least giving us the tools, if not the time, to come back to the jury selection process and make some real and meaningful amendments that will make the justice system fair for everyone.
That is what I am trying to do today. I will be pleased to hear the reply of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice.
Government Orders

Mr. Speaker, we on this side are supportive of the intent and direction suggested in this particular motion. We all recognize the problem that exists and the need for change in the area of jury selection and in particular to do everything possible we can to make the system function properly so that there is not racial discrimination within that system.
We are also faced with the problem of doing the possible. My understanding is that under the Supreme Court decision about the middle of July, July 22 or July 23, we have to correct the problem which the Supreme Court found, and that is what Bill C-70 does.
I would hope the government and the NDP could work out an arrangement to accommodate that. I would hope they would see to it that there is a commitment as to time for that report to be brought forward, a commitment by the government to act on that report and to conduct the full study necessary in order to make amendments to jury selection to accommodate what the report brings forward.
We are supportive of where they want to be as far as the motion is intended. We just do not know if it is a doable situation given the time constraints we are involved in. I look forward to the parliamentary secretary coming forward with a solution to that time constraint.

speakeroldname: Mr. Rob Nicholson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, time constraint is the problem we have at the present time. As was pointed out in the Regina v. Bain decision, the Supreme Court of Canada struck down certain provisions of the Criminal Code as they relate to jury selection.
We had a specific problem on our hands at that point. The Supreme Court of Canada indicated that it would suspend the operation of its decision for a period of six months. That period of time expires July 23, 1992.
We have a situation where we are at report stage on June 11. I hope the House deems it appropriate to continue with the third reading stage of this debate so that it can pass this House and move on to the Senate.

Government Orders
The bill is specific. The member for Port Moody-Coquitlam talked about that and we have nothing to hide in that regard.
It was specifically directed toward the issue raised in the Regina v. Bain decision. It was not meant to be a comprehensive look or solution to all the issues or questions raised in the jury selection process. It was for this specific purpose. We did not dawdle with this. Within I believe she weeks of the decision of the Supreme Court we tabled Bill C-70. Prior to that we consulted with groups such as the Canadian Bar Association and others that were generally interested in commenting on new initiatives from the Department of Justice and took their advice on this.
As well the minister has consulted with provincial attorneys general. I can tell hon. members of the House that this particular bill has their blessing and approval. I do not think it is unreasonable they would give it.
We took this through the committee stage. At that time there were no amendments, no briefs, and no witnesses who appeared before us. I think that was a result of the consultations that took place prior to the introduction of the bill.
I hope I have addressed the question of whether the government is hiding something on this. We are not.
With respect to the motion that the hon. member makes, he asks that the application of this bill be suspended until there is a review and a report commissioned on the authority of a reference from the Minister of Justice to the Law Reform Commission.
I do not think he will be too surprised when I say that the government will not be supporting it because it puts an indefinite time period for the application of this bill. I do not think that is something the courts, the judiciary, the bar or Canadians interested in seeing Parliament act would want at this particular time.
However, I can tell the hon. member that he is quite correct. He raised issues in his comments that are of concern to the government. I believe that he and I, the member from Moncton and others at the committee stage discussed this very question in terms of a review being undertaken by the attorney general of the province of Ontario. I can tell him, as I think I indicated then, that the government will be very interested in hearing what
the attorney general of Ontario, or indeed any others in this country, has to say on this particular issue.
With respect to the specific reference in the motion vis-a-vis the Law Reform Commission, I want to tell the member that the issue that was referred to the commission is being studied and will continue to be studied by the Department of Justice itself. The minister, I and everyone would like to see that concluded as quickly as possible.
I cannot say to the hon. member or to anyone else that we will therefore bring in amendments when we do not know what the report is. It is reasonable to see what the report is, to see what the attorney general of Ontario recommends to us in this regard and then to decide the appropriate action. But I cannot in advance of a report being completed say that we will accept whatever the conclusions of the report and therefore bring in amendments to the Criminal Code.

I rise on a point of order, Mr. Speaker. I hesitate to interrupt the hon. member.
I just want to point out to him so that we can expedite this matter. What I asked in my speech was that he give a commitment to this House that there be a report, an independent study, and that this study be made available to members of the House. I did not ask for an internal Department of Justice study but an independent study that is available to the members of the House. If he were prepared to give that commitment I would withdraw my amendment.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I can tell the hon. member that the issue being studied by the attorney general for Ontario is not one that is controlled or directed by the Government of Canada. He can be assured that there is independence in what the Attorney general of Ontario will be doing vis-a-vis the federal Criminal Code. I can only tell him what we are doing at the present time. Yes, we are having a look at it.
He is a member of the Standing Committee on Justice and Solicitor General as are several other members of the House. I would indicate to him that if he would like to study this as well as the study that is going on within the Department of Justice, then by all means he should propose that to members. That is certainly within his purview and that of his colleagues on the Standing Committee of Justice and Solicitor General. If they want to undertake a study that would act in parallel or in concert with what we are doing at the Department of
June 11, 1992

Justice, then by all means do so. That would be the appropriate route.
If the member is asking me to make a commitment that we will have a royal commission, all I can say is that I want to see first the Department of Justice review. Let us see what the recommendations are from the attorney general.
With respect to the attorney general for Ontario, provincial attorneys general want this bill passed and they want it passed by July 23. As far as an independent inquiry is concerned, I say to the hon. member, please go before the Standing Committee on Justice and Solicitor General. That is his right as a member of Parliament to make that recommendation.
We heard that the hon. member for Moncton. I know my colleagues on the government side are interested in all aspects of the justice system and all attempts to create a fair justice system for everyone in Canada. I would suggest that is the route.
At this point, I do not see why it would be a good idea for us to stop the internal review being undertaken by the Department of Justice. I would suggest that we let that proceed and find out what the attorney general of Ontario or anyone else in this country has to say about it. Let us hear what the Standing Committee on Justice and Solicitor General has to say on it and then we can formulate an action plan at that particular time.
This is very important. Time is running out in Parliament and I hope that hon. members will not proceed with this. It would suspend the application of this bill to an indefinite period of time. I hope that we will get on with it and pass this bill.

speechtext:
Motion No. 1
That Bill C-74 be amended by deleting Clause 39.
Motion No. 2
That Bill C-74 be amended by deleting Clause 40.
He said: Mr. Speaker, first of all I obviously accept the Chair's ruling in terms of Motion No. 3. I will make my remarks to all three of the motions. I invite the parliamentary secretary to avail himself of the answers to some of the questions that I will be raising.
First of all, I indicated at second reading that it is my intention to vote for this bill and to recommend that my colleagues do the same. I want to indicate to the government that we have no interest in blocking, stalling or otherwise delaying the passage of Bill C-74.
It should be made clear to all Canadians and to all members of this House that the reason Bill C-74 is needed is because of an action by the government across the way some years ago. It decided in its so-called wisdom to make all parcels coming into Canada under $40 exempt from customs duties. In so doing, it has created an industry in the United States.
I have here a magazine entitled The Guide to CrossBorder Shopping, Tourism and Entertainment. This little publication comes from the U.S.A., right across the border in Ogdensburg, New York. It tells of all the great ways Canadians can cross-border shop.
I understand that Canada Post is busy right now in the United States soliciting this kind of business to encourage Canadians to shop in the U.S. We will deal with that some other time. Right now, we are going to talk about the amendments that are before us.
The bill does two things. One, it reduces the tax free amount from $40 to $20. I had proposed in the amendment that has been ruled out of order to reduce that amount to $5. The government said at committee: "Don't worry because all articles even under $20 will be subject to a $5 fee at the border by Canada Post".
That is not true, because in the bill there is what is known as a foreign certification program by which a large mail order house in the United States will be able to apply, collect the taxes themselves, and exempt themselves from the $5 surtax.
The long and the short of it is the following: A company in the United States will be able to by-pass the new $5 fee that the government is proposing by registering under the foreign certification program. Okay? Now, say a Canadian small retailer imports by mail some small article made in the United States to resell in Canada. It has no possibility of being so exempted.
What have we created? We are going to make it harder for a small business in Canada to compete with a large business in the United States because the certification program is only made available to foreign companies and not Canadian ones. We are actually creating a new device in order for foreign companies to exempt themselves from paying the $5 surcharge we are initiating in the Ml.
That is why the government has to answer for this. I invite the parliamentary secretary or one of the ministers across the way to explain to this House and to Canadians why yet another loophole has been created in a law that is supposed to get rid of loopholes this government created in the first place.
We really need to clarify that. As far as I am concerned, that foreign certification program should not exist. There is no reason for it. Why are we so desperate on wanting to export jobs out of this country? I cannot understand it.
If a Canadian mail order house wants to sell something to the U.S., it has to pay $8.40 U.S. at the border in order to get the privilege of sending a parcel across the border. That is roughly $10.50 Canadian at the time we are speaking today.
We are proposing to charge them $5 for what they charge us $10 and then we are proposing to exempt most of them from paying it anyway. Do they exempt us? Likely not. We are proposing to exempt all the large mail
June 11, 1992

Government Orders
order houses that are able to avail themselves of this foreign certification program. I really think the government has to answer for this.
There is another element in the bill I want to address. The purpose of the two amendments on the Order Paper in my name is to reduce the gift exemption the government is creating. Under the present rule, there is an exemption for someone receiving a gift from offshore. If a gift is received from offshore, this particular tax does not have to be paid.
Someone was mentioning to me in the lobby a little while ago that if her mother sent her a gift from offshore, she would have to pay the $5 surtax. Well that is not so. That only applies to goods purchased offshore. If a gift is received from offshore, right now one does not pay customs or any kind of administrative fee on the first $40 of value of the gift.
The bill proposes to increase the $40 to $60 and the amendments I have proposed would delete those clauses. At the very least, let us leave it the way it is now at $40. Let us not give an advantage to companies outside of this country. Let us give every advantage we can to the ones operating within Canada.
The Minister for International Trade and a few others across the way have recited to us at length the phrase "operating on a level playing field". That is their favourite line across the way. What is level about the playing field I have just described when we are plugging up loopholes in our system and creating new ones that will not make the plugging up we are trying to do half as effective?
Again, I repeat that we want those provisions to be tight but we cannot help but wonder why the government created this new loophole in the bill under this foreign certification clause.
I have here briefing documents for people working in Revenue Canada. These are questions and answers. These are prepared questions for the officials. This information was sent to me. I do not know whether I should call this information a leak or what, but anyway I have it. The information works this way. Proposed question No. 6: Finance has announced the foreign certification program, how does it work?
The proposed answer for the government official who is supposed to recite those prepared lines goes this way: A foreign mail order business can apply for certification which would allow it to collect duties and taxes on behalf of the Government of Canada. It would collect duties and taxes from its clients in Canada when the Canadian pays for the good and then send a cheque to the federal government on a periodic basis. This would in turn reduce the number of dutiable/taxable parcels to be processed by customs.
Then there is a supplementary question in case the person is real nosy and wants to know more. Question No. 7 goes this way: If I understand you correctly, by allowing foreign businesses to collect duties and taxes, Canadians can bypass customs altogether along with the Canada Post handling fee and have the parcel delivered right to their door. Is this not really facilitating crossborder shopping through these American mail order houses?
Well, thank you for asking, Mr. Speaker. Listen clearly to the proposed answer the official is supposed to give because you might find that it does not quite answer the question. As a matter of fact, I submit to you it does not answer the thing at all. Here is the proposed answer the government official is supposed to give to whoever is nosy enough to ask this supplementary question. Answer: Not at all. Foreign firms of course will have to consider this option in light of the cost that they will have to absorb or pass on to perform the collection and remittance function.
That is very clear, is it not? That is the proposed answer.
Again I recommend to this House the two amendments that I propose to close in on the loophole for gifts, but in addition I ask the government to really reconsider this foreign certification program because it is itself creating a new loophole that will not make its bill half as effective as it would be otherwise.
Point of order, Mr. Speaker. I am seeking unanimous consent of the House to table a report from a standing committee. Could we revert to that now?

With regard to the group of amendments put forward by my colleague from the Liberal Party, I want to say that I do not support them. It also facilitates cross-border driving because there are no fees attached to the processing when you drive across the border and bring goods in, but if you are using the mail or courier services, there are. speakeroldname: Mr. Barry Moore (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Revenue):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Revenue
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am honoured to begin today third reading of Bill C-74, an act to amend the Customs Act, the Customs Tariff and the Excise Tax Act.
This is an important piece of legislation, important to both Customs and Excise, and important to Canadian business. It is designed to enhance voluntary compliance in the importing community and also to assist Canadian businesses by ensuring a level playing field and greater opportunity to compete in the global trading environment.
This bill is composed of two main parts. The first is directed to the elimination of the imbalance that currently exists in the interest provisions of customs legislation and to introduce penalties for the lack of compliance in certain instances.
It is noteworthy to mention at the outset that Customs and Excise has a veiy large commercial clientele who for the most part are very familiar with and who comply with customs legislation. For these importers then the proposed amendments will have no impact on their day-today operations. It will be business as usual.
Rather, these measures are aimed at those commercial importers who find it financially rewarding to delay filing their accounting documents or paying their fair share of duties and taxes. Current legislation requires Revenue Canada, Customs and Excise, to pay interest on moneys owing to an importer. However, the same obligation is not required of an importer who owes money to the Crown.
These proposed interest and penalty provisions have been designed to bring customs and excise business operation more into line with current commercial operating practices and they are fair to both the importing community and to customs, as the regulator. The proposed amendments are quite straightforward. Moneys owing by either party would be subject to interest provisions. As well, to further encourage compliance, the proposed amendments dealing with penalties will provide an incentive for the provision of timely and accurate information to customs.
The second part of Bill C-74 is directed to the importation of parcels through the mail. This aspect of the proposed legislation would modify current policies

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
which encourage significant Canadian shopping through foreign mail order houses. As well, the system today encourages Canadian mail order houses to establish direct marketing operations outside Canada to sell back to Canadians. The net effect of the current policy on postal imports is a significant loss of revenue to the government and is a subsidy to those who use the mail to import goods.
We have mentioned the government's commitment to ensure that Canadian business has the effect of competing on a level playing field. Perhaps the most serious ramification of today's policy is that it puts Canadian business at a disadvantage in a highly competitive industry.
The proposed changes hon. members have in front of them are a direct response to Canadian business demands that this government make the necessary changes to existing legislation to balance the scales. Representations were received from the Retail Council, the Canadian Direct Marketing Association, independent retailers and other small business people. Changes were also requested by members of this house.
The necessity of these changes is well borne out in fact. Over the last two years customs has experienced a 46 per cent increase in the volume of dutiable and taxable, parcels. Estimates put 1990 Canadian purchases from foreign mail order houses in excess of $900 million, almost a staggering $1 billion. All indicators point to a worsening of the situation as foreign mail order houses direct aggressive marketing and sales campaigns to Canadians.
This has become an important issue affecting an important sector of the Canadian economy, the Canadian direct marketing industry. When trying to make the argument for a case, in this instance the bill before this House, sometimes it is good to have all the facts in front of oneself. The industry over all has an annual sales volume of $7.8 billion. The catalogue direct marketing business represents $2.2 billion of these sales or approximately 28 per cent. Catalogue direct marketing represents approximately 600 firms and employs an estimated 35,620 people.
The proposed amendments before this House are critical to the health of this industry and it is our responsibility to put an end to the competitive disadvantage under which Canadian firms presently find themselves.
During second reading of this bill hon. members may recall some of the statistics that have provided further impetus to the necessity for revised legislation.
The facts continue to be alarming. Estimates are: $260 million in lost sales in 1990; 4,170 jobs lost since 1986; a once healthy growth of 7 per cent annually has declined and stagnated since 1986 at 3.2 per cent per annum. The comparable U.S. growth rate in this industry was 8.3 per cent in 1985 and a very significant 12.4 per cent through 1990. The facts are there and they speak for themselves.
Why the difference in growth rates? This has been previously explained but bears repeating. Simply put, an Ontario-based firm selling a Canadian-made article for a $40 catalogue price would deliver it to a customer in Canada for $50.26 including GST, provincial sales taxes, shipping and handling. However, the same company could ship the Canadian-made good to the U.S. and deliver it to the same customer in Ontario for $45.36 with the same dollar value of profit margin and allowing for differences in postal rates. It does not make sense and it is easy to see how the duty and tax exemptions for parcels valued at $40 or less create a serious competitive inequity for Canadian retailers competing for Canadian mail order business.
The bill in front of us today is designed to provide the Canadian businessmen with a relief from the present day onerous legislation.
You will agree, Mr. Speaker, and I am sure most members of this House will agree that there exists very solid valid reasons for the proposed legislation that would lead to the implementation on July 1, 1992, of the following changes which I would like to highlight: duty and tax-free entry of postal or courier imports valued at $20 or less; collection on behalf of Customs and Excise by Canada Post of a $5 handling fee to cover the costs of services such as collection of duty, provincial sales tax where provinces are harmonized and GST on importations over the $20 threshold; Canada Post will bear the cost of clearing priority courier items through customs as is done by private couriers; voluntary registration of foreign mail order firms for the collection of GST and duties; and, options for non-resident mail order houses to collect and remit applicable duties and taxes on all
June 11, 1992

shipments over the $20 exemption limit sent to Canada destinations.
The review of the exemptions for postal and courier imports provided an opportunity to reassess our policy on gifts and to consider the merits of amending current exemption levels to make them more liberal.
As a result of the review and in response to numerous recent representations received from Canadians, the gift exemption level would be increased from $40 to $60 under this proposed legislation.
It is important to note that the gift exemption is intended to deal with unsolicited gifts sent to Canadians from family and friends abroad.
Mr. Speaker, you have in front of you a comprehensive piece of legislation that has been carefully thought out which is designed to improve existing legislation both for the benefit of the user and the regulator. It is not the cure-all for some of the complex issues with which we are faced. Specifically here we refer to cross-border shopping. Rather, this initiative proposes fair, balanced measures to restore the level playing field and gives Canadian mail order firms the opportunity to compete on an equal basis with foreign competitors in Canada.
As well, the bill proposes to bring customs legislation more into line with other statutes administered by Revenue Canada and continues concerted efforts by Customs and Excise to streamline operations and to manage in a more business-like fashion.
Bill C-74 has been a joint effort between the department and the Department of Finance. It is the culmination of many months of thoughtful hard work, work that has been directed toward being fair and trying to balance the different interests that inevitably collide when you are in the process of change.
I would like to thank all those who helped bring the bill to third reading and to suggest that we hear from members who may wish to contribute.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to speak in favour of this bill at third reading. I must indicate, however, and reiterate the fact that the government is only partially plugging loopholes that it says it is plugging. The difficulty is, of course, that it has created a system within the bill that will make the measure it is announcing only half as effective as it would otherwise be.
Government Orders
Let me be perfectly clear, however, that this bill even with that loophole is going to be much tighter than the present legislation. No one is denying that. Right now, a person can ship goods into Canada worth $39.90 by mail from the U.S. exempt of all duties, exempt of the GST and everything else. It means that the large mail order houses, the L. L. Beans of this world, ship into Canada several goods in individual packages. They will ship a tie in one box, a shirt in the next and so on. They will send those goods into Canada in individual parcels and completely bypass our Canadian taxing system.
With the bill, the exempt amount will only be $20. We are referring to purchases not gifts. It is still possible that many goods will be shipped into Canada duty free because the $5 surcharge will not apply to large mail order houses for the reasons that I have previously indicated.
I first brought this issue to the attention of the House on May 30,1990. In a speech in the House at that time, I asked the Minister of National Revenue what he was going to do to plug that loophole in our law which makes it possible for U.S. retailers to ship into Canada and completely undercut Canadian retailers, not because Canadian retailers are taking too much profit but for a reason totally different. They are exempt from taxes.
The member for Pontiac-Gatineau-Labelle indicated in his speech a while ago that a $40 parcel costs $50.26 if purchased in Canada and the taxes have been paid. Similarly, a $20 parcel will cost $25.13. For a U.S. company taking advantage of the registration system, when it sends a $20 parcel to Canada, the parcel will cost $20 plus postage. That's it.
Canadians selling the same goods will have to charge its customer $25.13, using the hon. parliamentary secretary's own calculation. There is still going to be a $5.13 advantage on a $20 item.
The Canadian Direct Marketing Association issued a press release on February 12, 1992. It expressed its concern about this exemption system in the bill. It stated: "The changes in the postal and courier emission policy are definitely a step in the right direction". No problem, I agree with that. The hon. member across said that a while ago. However, let us read the next sentence: "But we still have concerns about goods valued under $20

Government Orders
being shipped to Canada duty free, tax free and exempt of the $5 handling fee".
That is because of the registration system that I described a while ago. They will not have to pay the $5 fee in question to Canada Post. That is what is wrong with that loophole that exists.
The particular concern of the Canadian Direct Mail Marketing Association is the following, and I read the next sentence: "Many Canadian companies, those that specialize in smaller ticket items such as nursery, garden products, small tools or books will still be facing unfair competition". Most books shipped from the United States into Canada are under $20, particularly when they are sold in large quantities. When they are to be shipped across the border, large book distribution companies will obviously use the certification mechanism. They will ship their books in the mail and be exempt from the $5 fee. That is what is wrong. That is the hole in there. It will eliminate some of the cross-border shipping by mail.
Yes, a small fishing and tackle shop located in Massena may not be able to do it any more, and that is good. I accept that. I am in favour of the bill. I will vote for it. However, we are not going to eliminate the large ones because of the certification program we have created. That is the deficiency in the legislation before us. In other words, it is good but it could be a lot better had the government not put in that particular exemption.
I want to speak briefly about the damage caused by the present policy, the one that exists now, the $40 exemption. Let me read from a letter I received from McIntyre and Dodd Marketing, a company located in Hawkesbury in my riding. They sent me this letter on May 22, 1990 and it reads as follows: "I would like to draw to your attention a loophole in our laws that an American company is making use of, that if it continues may force us to close our Hawkesbury plant. Our plant in peak periods last year employed 165 people".
I had my assistant, Francois Giroux, make a phone call just recently to the company in Hawkesbury. We asked how many people were on staff right now. Here is what
McIntyre and Dodd said to my assistant. They have 52 people on staff versus 165 in 1990. All these jobs have been lost in my constituency, 113 jobs lost in that one business alone because this loophole existed. That is why it is so important for us to fix it. We could fix it better if the government would listen to my last minute plea to plug this new loophole it is creating.
I read on from the letter sent to me by McIntyre and Dodd. "The U.S. company in question, Direct Marketing Enterprises out of Westbury, New York, is using Canadian media", I am almost tempted to say the Canadian Post Office, but I will not, "to promote its mail order products with a return address in Windsor, Ontario".
Get a load of this. The orders are dispatched to a fulfilment operation in Detroit where the orders are processed and shipped to the border, ready to be mailed at the closest Canada Post parcel centre.
Here is how it works. The U.S. company places ads in a Canadian magazine, The Canadian Weekender that we get in our newspaper and says: "Do you want to order our such and such widget? Write in giving your Visa or MasterCard number to box so-and-so, Windsor, Ontario". Canadians are first of all misled into believing they are buying this through a Canadian store, outlet or a Canadian mail distribution company in Windsor. It is not true. It is not even in Windsor.
Someone from Detroit crosses the bridge into Windsor, opens a little box, takes the orders out and brings them to the United States, fills them over there and ships them back in the mail. That is the loophole we have created and that we are trying to plug today.
That will still exist for the large mail order houses because we have only partially plugged it. Nevertheless, that is the damage caused by the previous policy, one I raised in this House over two years ago and at that time begged the government to have it corrected because we were losing all these jobs in Canada.
Now, of course, the government is partially addressing the issue in question. I say only partially because of the situation I described only moments ago.
June 11, 1992

The Canadian Direct Marketing Association in its press release -and I want to come back to that for a minute-told us that there were 700 member companies of that organization involved in $7.8 billion worth of Canadian direct marketing. That is the amount of sales we are talking about. This is not small potatoes. This is big business, very big business in Canada. Many people purchase goods by mail.
Some people living in large downtown centres might perhaps be under the mistaken belief the only people who use mail shopping are those wanting to avail themselves of these loopholes and buy something in the United States. It is not so.
I know my colleague from Thunder Bay represents a rural riding as I do. He will know many people order from the Sears catalogue or wherever else within Canada. It is a large business within this country, particularly in rural Canada but also in urban Canada for some people, elderly people or people for whatever reason who do not want to go out, cannot go out, or just enjoy shopping that way because it is less trouble than standing in line before the cash register at one's not so favourite store in the shopping centre. People do a large amount of business that way.
The Canadian direct marketing business is certainly a very legitimate business. There are many jobs there. They provide a very useful service to Canadians.
There is the odd person involved in direct marketing who advertises in a comic book or something and sends a little plastic piece of junk instead of the item we thought we were buying from the photograph. I am sure that is generally not the case. Those are the unfortunate circumstances we are sometimes made familiar with as MPs. We usually complain to the Department of Consumer and Corporate Affairs when we see people using devious methods to sell products. I do not think that is the general case. As a matter of fact I know it is not.
In closing I want to say it is about time we tightened up on that rule. My speech today is not to say that it is about time we charged Canadians more taxes. That is not the point. The point is that no one should be exempted from those taxes because he or she can cross the border to shop by letter or by the mail system.
If all taxes were collected equitably it would mean that each and every one of us paying taxes would have to pay proportionately less. Those who are less fortunate than others and cannot avail themselves of the loopholes are being punished right now because they are paying taxes
Government Orders
that others are not. That is the point in tightening up on loopholes.
The issue is not whether one is in favour of higher taxes. I am certainly not in favour of having more tax increases after this Canadian government across the way has had 34 tax increases since it came to power in 1984. That is not the issue.
The issue, I repeat again in closing, is to ensure there is fairness, to ensure that a person who owns a store in my riding, in Thunder Bay or elsewhere in Canada does not see his or her business undercut by an envelope ordering something across the border and a product being sent back using, of all things, the Canadian postal system as a method to avoid paying Canadian taxes. That is the unfairness right now that many people are living with.

I intend to support this bill, which is badly needed, although unfortunately it still contains a loophole. I predict that the big multinationals and mail order companies will take advantage of the loophole which the government put there, in a piece of legislation that is basically a good bill.
I also think the $5 fee to be charged by the Canada Post Corporation should be $10. Fees should be reciprocal. The American fee is $8.40, which is about $10 in Canadian funds. The government across the way always insists on a level playing field and wants the rules to be more or less the same on both sides of the border. That is not the case here since their fees are twice as high as ours. Fees should be almost identical for the sake of fairness. They should be about $10 and we should eliminate the loophole that allows American companies to register and by-pass the whole fee system.
Finally, I hope Canadians can soon look forward to having fairer laws, especially Canadians who own small businesses in this country and who feel they are not getting fair treatment. They are right. At this very moment Ontario's entrepreneurs are faced with federal legislation that is not to their advantage. At the provincial level, they will soon have to contend with new labour

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
legislation about which they are apprehensive, to say the least. I would say they are more than apprehensive about these new developments. Merchants in the riding of Glengarry-Prescott-Russell, which is a border area, simply want a chance to do business and make an honest living. That is all they ask and I do not think that is unreasonable.
In any case, I am sure that the 113 workers at McIntyre and Dodd in Hawkesbury would rather have jobs than be on unemployment insurance or welfare. They want to be able to earn a living.
I hope the bill will be adopted today and that it will be a step in the right direction towards reducing transborder shopping. In concluding, I would like to repeat my request to the parliamentary secretary.

The parliamentary secretary-and I will predict it now-is making a mistake by going ahead with this clause that will permit large, foreign mail order firms from using what is known as the foreign certification program.
If they want a foreign certification program for administrative simplicity, so be it, but let us not use it as a way for them not to pay the $5 fee at the border. If they want to do it all at once, fine. If they want to send one cheque at the end of the month, fine. I am not going to object to that, but if we say to those companies that they can avoid paying a fee that others are paying then I think it is wrong. That is the problem. I repeat it again for the parliamentary secretary and the government officials who are listening in the lobby.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to participate in third reading debate of Bill C-74.
At the outset let me say that when my children were very young-and I suspect this is the same for pretty well every other parent on this continent-and they came in with a scratch or a scrape that was not bleeding but was sort of roughed up, they demanded a bandage. The parents complied and gave them a little bandage to put over the cut even though the parents knew it was not needed. However, for psychological purposes the child needed to feel secure and needed to feel that there was some kind of treatment happening.
That is what this bill does. It really is a very tiny band-aid to try to give the impression the government is taking some action to stem or stop cross-border shopping. The reality is there is so much else that can be done to reduce people's need or desire to travel across the border to buy consumer goods. They do it personally as people in my community do. They travel to Duluth, Minnesota; Superior, Wisconsin; and Grand Marais, Minnesota. People in other communities also go across the border to get goods at a price less than they can buy them in their home community.
This bill deals with the symptoms, not with the problem. I regret that the government has chosen not to act seriously about the real problem.
Prior to this year's federal budget I wrote to the Minister of Finance and offered some suggestions to him. One of the suggestions was that he conduct a pilot project in northwestern Ontario to take a look at the cost differentials to see what really were the causes of the higher prices in Canada.
I used as an example two-by-fours produced in Thunder Bay from Canadian trees that were available at a price in Duluth, Minnesota, which was much less than the price at Beaver Lumber that was about one-half mile away from the sawmill. I asked the minister to take a look at those input costs to see what the impact of transportation was, to see what kind of mark-up there was, to see what impact hydro costs had in terms of the over-all costs of doing business in northwestern Ontario, and to take a look at all of the inputs to see if there were any areas where we could do better, where we could be more competitive.
I premised my remarks on the basis that I did not believe anyone in the system was ripping people off, that they were all legitimate costs. The minister never replied.
However, another organization did a national study because it too wanted to find out what the causes were. The key element it discovered-and it is one this government should be reacting to and working on-was in terms of the number of times that goods were handled in Canada compared to in the United States.
In the United States there is much more factory to retail outlet direct. In Canada it goes through two or three middle people whether it is domestically produced or whether it is imported. If the government really wanted to get serious about stemming out-shopping, it could work to assist the retail, manufacturing, transpor-
June 11, 1992

tation and handling industries in terms of reducing their cost elements.
When I raise this matter with my constituents they say: "Look, I have no choice. I don't have enough money every month to get by on. If I can save $100 or $200 by buying product x in Duluth and get a short holiday out of it to boot, I am sorry but I am going to do that because I need to it for my survival".
Some people feel very guilty about do that because they know it is their consumer purchases in Thunder Bay that help to pay the taxes for the municipality, to pay the wages for their neighbours and what not. But they feel they have no choice.
This government could act on that. This government could also act on the high cost of the Canadian dollar. There is no question that as long as our dollar is strong as compared to the American dollar imported products are much cheaper. If we allow the dollar to go where the marketplace says it should be, somewhere between 75 cents and 79 cents, then those products from the United States will become less attractive.
There is another thing we need to look at in a serious way. We need to re-examine our taxation policies as they relate to our competitor to the south, not to give corporations a break per se, but to make sure that our products are affordable and to make sure that we are not really tempting people to go south of the border.
Let me specifically deal with gasoline taxes. In the same letter to the Minister of Finance I indicated that perhaps it was time that all of us, whether all of us are the political parties or whether all of us are the federal, provincial and even municipal governments, re-examine how we tax fuel. There is a strong belief that the higher the tax on the fuel, the lower the consumption. From 1981 to 1989 the total cost of automobile gasoline went up by 198 per cent. What happened to consumption? It declined to just around 3.5 per cent.
If we look at that isolated statistic and at the number of people in Fort Francis, Rainy River, Sault Ste. Marie, Windsor and Cornwall who go across the bridge or down the road to cross the border to buy their gasoline because of the big difference in price we must recognize that if
Government Orders
we do not change our gasoline pricing system, including taxation, there will continue to be that kind of draw. While they are down there getting gas they will pick up some milk, hurting our dairy producers, they will pick up some other consumer goods, hurting our retail operations, and on and on and on.
I suggested to the Minister of Finance that he convene an inter-ministerial, inter-governmental team to re-examine gasoline taxation and re-examine how that money is used. Obviously we need tax revenue of some kind or user fees of some kind to maintain, build and rebuild our highway infrastructure. We cannot just say that we would no longer tax it, we must look at it and find a way that treats the north fairly, treats the south fairly, treats the regions fairly and so on. We need to re-examine that because therein lies part of the solution to cross-border shopping.
One of the ironies of this particular bill and the steps the government has chosen to take is that it is actually working against the environment. It is discouraging the use of an integrated postal system that has economies of scale and the ability to take in a diverse range of items into one particular method of transportation and move them short and long distances for redistribution. Compare that to a neighbour of mine driving down to Duluth to buy that same item and only that item and then coming back. Think about the difference in fuel consumption and in emissions. There will be that many more vehicles on the highways, and it goes on and on and on.
Ironically by choosing to target mail order rather than any other method of bringing the goods into Canada the government is saying that it wants us to use the less environmentally friendly way of transport. People will do that. People will drive a hell of a long way to save $5. They do it all the time, even though it may cost them more in the long term. That is how they will approach it.
Let me conclude by saying once again that this is just a band-aid and for that reason we will not support this bill. We will not force a vote on it. We will do it on division. The government needs to know that it must find better ways to deal with a veiy real problem that is costing Canadians thousands of jobs in both the retail sector and the manufacturing sector.

I would like to leave members of this House and the people who are watching with one final comment. Let us all go out and buy something Canadian today.

subtopic: EXCISE TAX ACT AND INCOME TAX ACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to begin debate at third reading of Bill C-75, which has passed committee stage without amendment.
First, I would like to express my gratitude to the members for their co-operation in facilitating the passage of this bill. I am confident that there is general agreement on the nature of the bill, and on the importance of a healthy and vibrant transportation sector in Canada.
This bill amends the Excise Thx Act and Income Thx Act to implement two key measures announced on December 6, 1991 to boost the transportation sector.
The measures included in this bill are a temporary loss offset program with a partial rebate of the federal excise tax on diesel and aviation fuel, and an exemption from
non-resident withholding tax for payments in respect of cross-border aircraft leases. The temporary loss offset program will provide a benefit of $120 million in each of the next two years to transportation firms experiencing temporary cash flow difficulties.
The withholding tax exemption will provide an on-going benefit to Canada's airlines at a cost to the treasury of about $15 million per year.
In December the government also announced changes to the capital cost allowance structure and funding for an institute for research on trucking issues and an owner-operator's trucking co-operative.
These measures, along with the measures included in this bill, respond in a meaningful way to issues raised by the transportation sector. As well, the measures announced in the budget to bolster the economic recovery and build confidence will reinforce the transportation sector as more Canadian goods are shipped to markets at home and abroad.
Response from this sector to these measures has been positive. Of course, this bill does not include everything the sector requested. However, it does provide considerable benefit to transportation in a fiscally responsible way. For example, the temporary loss offset program will yield significant benefits to the transportation sector.
This program provides transportation firms with a 3 cent per litre rebate in exchange for reductions in income tax loss carry forwards. For each dollar rebate received businesses will have to reduce their loss carry forward by $10, reducing future tax deductions.
This 10 to 1 ratio was chosen in order to target the cash flow benefits to those firms that need them most. This targeting will allow the program to deliver significant cash flow benefits while still being fiscally responsible.
I would like to remind the hon. members that maintaining our fiscal strategy is the way to achieve long-term prosperity for the Canadian economy, and therefore for the Canadian transportation sector.
There is an administratively simpler option available for truckers. This option provides a rebate of 1.5 cents per litre of the 4 cent per litre federal excise tax on diesel fuel, up to a maximum of $500 per taxpayer per year. Individual truckers have responded to this program very positively.
June 11, 1992

Although some members of the opposition may differ with the government on certain aspects of these measures it is encouraging that partisan differences have been set aside to ensure the speedy passage of this worth while bill.
It is clear that all parties in this House are in agreement on the importance of transportation to the Canadian economy.
For the information of members, application for the rebate can be made at customs and excise offices across Canada. Application forms will be made available as soon as the bill has received Royal Assent. The sooner this bill is passed the sooner rebates will be received by the transportation sector.
In closing, this bill will provide a timely and substantial boost to the transportation sector while maintaining the government's commitment to sound fiscal management. This is a responsible package of measures that deserves the support of this House.
I urge members to pass this bill without delay.

subtopic: EXCISE TAX ACT AND INCOME TAX ACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am privileged to rise in this House on third reading of Bill C-75, an act to amend the Excise Tax Act and the Income lax Act.
When the bill was tabled in this House back on May 1 it was largely a result of the situation with respect to Canadian truckers and trucking firms. I am sure Canadians can vividly remember the situation involving truckers last summer when major highways and many of our international bridges were blocked by these trucks.
Trucks parked in front of Parliament Hill for a number of days. Truckers and their families were and still are angry and frustrated with this government because of the high cost of doing business as truckers in this country. Their business is becoming increasingly competitive, and compared to their counterparts in the U.S. doing business is much more expensive in Canada.
The protests by the truckers centred on that fact. They were demanding help from the government. This legislation is supposed to respond to those concerns. While it merely attempts to deal with a very real situation affecting Canadian truckers it falls far short of what we
Government Orders
would have liked to have seen in this bill, in other words, practical solutions to a complicated problem.
According to the government the trucking option would be a simpler option for small truckers and independently owned operators. It would consist of a rebate of 1.5 cents per litre of excisable fuel to a maximum of $500 per year. Such a rebate would have no effect on income tax losses according to the government. It would be included in income in the year it was received which is the normal practice. I will have more to say on that aspect in just a moment.
Another failure of the bill is that it does not help those truckers with capital cost struggles at the present time. The proposed capital cost allowance on a trucker's rig will only cover acquisitions made after December 6, 1991. The thousands of trucks parked on highway 401 last summer were purchased before December 1, 1991.
We are not talking about those truckers who may encounter difficulties in the future but those who have difficulties today. Some operators might be able to take advantage of the capital cost allowance in the future. Therefore we agree with the thrust of the bill in that direction. However, we must re-emphasize our concern that the legislation does not affect those purchases made before December 1991.
Another aspect of this legislation is the temporary excise tax transportation rebate, the proposed loss offset program. A general rebate will apply to the purchase of diesel fuel used for the purposes of transportation. The second component of this scheme is the loss offset that would reduce tax loss carry-forwards by $10 per $1 of rebate received.
In plain English it means that while the government is attempting to provide assistance to truckers in the purchase of fuel it is pulling the rug out from underneath truckers on the other side. It is simply robbing Peter to pay Paul. Is that the responsive, responsible way to deal with the situation? While Canadians are plagued with a very high level of taxation, and as businesses fold and our economy continues to struggle, in fact some would say crumble, where is the government? While the cost of doing business is less expensive in the United States, and we know that because many of our businesses and

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
thousands of workers are moving south of the border, the government cannot even offer a helping hand.
The truckers are not looking for a handout they are looking for a helping hand.
As an example of this Peter robs Paul scenario with respect to the diesel fuel rebate, it will be in effect on fuel purchased in 1991 and 1992. The only way it helps small firms and independent truckers is by easing their temporary cash flow problems, which of course is acceptable. However, to cut off the program at the end of the year, if this bill is passed soon, is frankly too little and too late.
In summary, while I welcome the measures contained in this bill I am critical of the extent to which they would assist the trucking industry in regard to the depreciation of highly expensive capital equipment and the amount of tax relief on diesel fuel as it relates to the loss carry-forward provisions.
We support the bill and we will not attempt to delay it. However, the government's response to what is nothing short of a crisis in the trucking industry is veiy disappointing.

subtopic: EXCISE TAX ACT AND INCOME TAX ACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I too wish to make a few comments on Bill C-75. I will not take very long at all.
The need for this bill actually goes back a number of years. It goes back to the white paper Freedom To Move and it goes back to the deregulation of the aviation industry, the rail industry and the trucking industry.
That deregulation of the trucking industry, which was not only passed by this House but also put forward and passed by the then Liberal government of Ontario, led to the situation that we saw outside of this House, in Toronto, in Windsor, and elsewhere in this country. Block after block, if not mile after mile, of rigs stopped at the side of the road, their operators and their owners protesting against the lack of government action.
We ended up with too many trucks chasing too few cargoes. That was something that we predicted.
Under regulation there was a balance. Public necessity and convenience had to be met and people could only get into the business if there was sufficient demand for the service. While the system was not perfect it did ensure that there was some stability. It did not allow
someone with a dream to invest his or her life savings into a rig on the chance that they might make a good buck.
When deregulation came into being we opened the floodgates. A lot of decent men and women decided to get into their own business. They were entrepreneurs, they felt they could do it, and they felt they could out-hussle. However, they did not count on everybody else having the same thought and everybody else convincing the bankers to give them the money and put them in hock for many years to come. They did not count on the competition from United States carriers. They did not count on the kind of consolidation that began to occur, even though there were enough warnings out there about what was going to happen. They did not count on the fact that there would not be enough work to keep them going.
They said: "Help". They demanded action from both the federal and provincial governments to make it possible for them to survive.
What did the federal Government of Canada do? It talked a lot for a long time and it had meetings and consultations. The end result was Bill C-75, a token effort.
In terms of the fuel tax rebate $500 will be a lot for my car but for a transport truck operator it is one, two, three or maybe five tanks full. I am not sure about the capacity and the costs. That is all that means, only to have it pulled back down the road, almost like sleight of hand.
In terms of depreciation, it still does not match then-competitors in the states. In the previous bill I talked about band-aids. This is a band-aid to try to make the truckers feel better, to convince them that the government is really concerned about them and is going to great lengths to do something about them. I would bet that a lot of the truckers will not even agree to dance. They will not participate because it is meaningless.
As my colleague, the member for Hamilton West, pointed out quite rightly it does not do anything for those folks who already have their rigs, their trailers. It is only for new people or new acquisitions. If the existing truckers go out of business there will not be any new acquisitions. They certainly will not be buying a new rig, replacing their trailer.
June 11, 1992

It is a meaningless attempt by the federal government to do something for the truckers. If it was really serious it would re-examine its own philosophy about deregulation. It would allow the Standing Committee on Transport to enter into its own review to find a way to provide stability in the trucking industry, stability that would protect those carriers in the industry today and give them a chance to survive, but also design a system in co-operation with the provinces to make sure the chaos created by this government is never allowed to happen again, whether it is next year, in 10 years or whatever.
I will be supporting the bill because even though it is a minimal bill we must at least get it passed so those who are able can take advantage of it. If we can save one trucker somewhere out there in this country then great, but I sure wish we could have saved a lot more.

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Richardson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Transport):
