speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate you reading the motions just to give the House and those watching an idea of what we are doing here.
I am pleased to rise at report stage of Bill C-45, an act to promote public safety in the transportation of dangerous goods. We expect speedy passage. I think there is

Government Orders
general agreement and I hope we will be able to continue in the fine spirit of co-operation that was exhibited in Legislative Committee E, as we addressed the two further amendments that have been proposed.
To address Motion No. 1, members will know that Bill C-45 is directed not only at preventing accidents but also at ensuring that the industry will respond properly to any accidents that may occur. To ensure rapid response our Canadian industry has established a most comprehensive and highly professional network of response teams from various companies. It is the response team nearest an accident that responds even though it may be another company's product.
In order to promote and support this industry response Bill C-45 provides such teams the measure of liability protection. It was intended in the drafting of the bill that this protection would clearly apply with respect to all the emergency response teams carrying out an emergency response plan approved by the Minister of Transport.
As unfortunately sometimes happens we have had recent advice that paragraph 10(3)(b) covers most but not all such teams as it is presently written. We want to ensure that we absolutely do cover every such response team. That is Motion No. 1.
Motion No. 2 refers to clause 20 of Bill C-45, which contains a reference to clauses 17, 18, and 19. Unfortunately, we have been advised by the drafting experts that while the words used in clause 20 do appropriately reference clauses 17 and 19, the reference does not work for clause 18. Hence, the wording of Motion No. 2.
I hope the House will be disposed to accept these two amendments. I appreciate the co-operation of the opposition parties on this bill.

Mr. Speaker, on behalf of Her Majesty's Official Opposition I do support those motions being put forward by the government.
I would like to rise at this point in debate on this reading of Bill C-45. The entire piece of legislation is welcomed by the Official Opposition. While not as' completely thorough as we would have liked, it nonetheless greatly improves the safe transportation of dangerous and hazardous goods.
The bill provides for a clearer framework for regulating the transportation of dangerous goods and places
additional emphasis on steps that must be taken prior to the transportation of those goods.
In legislation passed back in 1980 a federal-provincial transportation of dangerous goods program was established and adopted by all the provinces and territories as set out by federal regulations. The bill would make it an offence for any person who displayed a safety mark on a vehicle transporting dangerous goods that was misleading in terms of the product being transported. This aspect comes down to an important issue which the Canadian fire-fighters have been seeking within the framework of legislation.
Fire-fighters who are engaged in the containment of goods released as the result of an accident or impending release of goods as a result of an accident are rightly concerned about dangerous and toxic substances. They are, after all, our first line of defence.
They also want to make sure that the product the vehicle or any transportation mode is carrying is the same product that is appearing on the vehicle's manifest. On the outer side of vehicles is a box displaying a card with a number identifying the hazardous product being shipped. This card is supposed to be displayed from the time the vehicle is filled with the substance until the time it is emptied.
Let me give you an example of the type of goods transported and the identification displayed.
Transport Canada provides an important booklet. It is entitled the "Initial Emergency Response Guide". If an accident occurs the identification number on the vehicle is referred to in the booklet and suggested procedures for emergency response crews such as fire-fighters or police or our medical teams are set out.
For instance, identification number UN2806 refers to lithium nitride. The "Initial Emergency Response Guide" procedures say that crews must not use water or foam but should use sand, lime or soda ash to contain that fire.
If the identification label, heaven forbid, were improperly displayed, if the wrong label were placed on the vehicle, or when another product was pumped into the vehicle and the card was not removed, the results would make a very difficult situation, especially in an emergency situation with respect to a fire.
June 11, 1992

Some other products might be contained by water only or foam. Some types of accidents require a local evacuation. We saw evidence of that a few years back in the city of Mississauga in which we had a train derailment and many units of that train had turned over on their sides, some of them spewing their substances. Those substances were highly toxic and when released into the atmosphere could do great damage to the population living nearby and so the order was made to evacuate. As I recall, being a reporter and walking the streets of Mississauga on that very quiet day, the plume of smoke was in the distance and there was no one to be found on the streets and sidewalks of Mississauga.
There are many potential cases where if an accident were to occur, improper containment methods could be used. This is why fire-fighters have been pressing for legislation that would encompass the right to know what is being transported on a vehicle and what the response is.
What this means is that fire-fighters want to enhance the manual system that is now in place in which a card is placed on the outside of the vehicle in that little box and the contents of the vehicle, its manifest, are known through an electronic data base which can be accessed immediately.
Currently in our trains when the locomotive is up front and it carries the manifest of what it is carrying behind the locomotive, oftentimes, and sadly so sometimes, the main locomotive is involved in the collision or the accident that occurs on those tracks and with the damage to the locomotive can come the loss of the manifest and you can understand the concern when we or the firefighters or the police or the medical response teams will not know what is contained within those train units behind the locomotive.
What the fire-fighters have been asking for is this electronic data base and all vehicles transporting dangerous goods would be required to register on a nation-wide data base at the source of transportation and destination. Certainly accessing the most current information this way would be a vast improvement over what we have in place today.
Although the right to know is encompassed in this bill in its language, the bill does not set up such an electronic system of information. That is too bad, for we have the opportunity. Such a system would undoubtedly have be
Government Orders
to arranged with the co-operation of labour and business and government.
We look forward to such a system eventually being put into place.

Mr. Speaker, I have a few brief remarks in support of the latest amendments that the government has proposed to this bill. They are welcome and we do support them.
I will briefly comment on some of the background to the point that we have reached today. I would like to take the opportunity even at this stage to pay some tributes. One may seem self-serving but it is to the transport critic for our own party, the member for Thunder Bay-Atikokan, who has done a great deal of work over a long period of time on this bill and the components that go into it, including extensive public meetings and hearings in his own area and elsewhere with virtually all of the parties that are affected by this legislation in order to ensure that we got it right this time as much as humanly possible.
While there are always deficiencies in any piece of legislation, I think the efforts of all parties, the Official Opposition, ourselves and the government, on this one have been excellent. The co-operation has been excellent. There has been a willingness to horse trade back and forth, to share concepts and ideas.
I would also like to congratulate one of my other colleagues, the member for Mission-Coquitlam, who is not here today. She is out in British Columbia. She presented three private member's bills, one which touched on the same area of the right to know and the computerized tracking system that has been referred to by my colleague from the Official Opposition a few moments ago.
The basic thrust of that private bill and the amendments which the International Association of Fire Fighters has sought in its two legislative lobbies in the last two years are incorporated in this bill. The government accepted and put forward an amendment which we suggested in order to accomplish that. Again, I thank the government for its openness in that regard.
The final tribute I would like to pay at this stage is to the International Association of Fire Fighters. In the eight or nine years that I have been around this place, although it was interrupted on one occasion-time off for good behaviour, as I like to put it-I would like to pay

particular tribute to the International Association of Fire Fighters and in particular to its Canadian Director, Doug Coupar. Of all the various lobbies, especially the labour lobbies that I have seen on the Hill, I have found the association to be the most specific and the most effective of any of the ones that I have ever had the pleasure or sometimes not quite the pleasure of dealing with. It got to the point. It dealt with everybody openly and specifically on issues with which it had immediate concern and experience. It made its points. In large part the points were accepted insofar as it was within the capacity of the legislation before us to deal with those.
I am particular pleased again to have had incorporated into this legislation the wherewithal, the enabling legislation, to allow an electronic computerized tracking system to occur.
This is all I want to say at this point. I will address it perhaps in a little more at length when we get to third reading.
Again, I want to thank all parties and all individual members who have been involved as well as the staff of the Ministry of Transport which was very co-operative in giving its assistance and background knowledge in the furtherance in what I think is essentially a very good bill.

Mr. Speaker, the riding I have the privilege to represent, Thunder Bay-Nipigon, through the Chamber of Commerce and its Citizens Outshopping Committee led by Roy Smyth, have taken the initiative in asking this House to proclaim July 4 "Shop Canada Day".
Shopping outside Canada means billions of dollars are not spent at home, resulting in the loss of many thousands of jobs. What Canada most needs today are jobs and a return to the prosperity we once knew.
By adopting July 4 as Shop Canada Day, we can start to journey back to what we once knew as full employment and prosperity for all Canadians to enjoy.
I compliment the Thunder Bay Chamber of Commerce, the executive director Rebecca Johnson, the president Dick Dolphin and all those involved in taking the initiative of committing July 4 to Shop Canada Day and allowing all of us to buy back into Canada.
June 11, 1992

Mr. Speaker, when is an agreement between two countries not an agreement?
I believe the Canada-Italian Pension Protocol that has been implemented since January 1, 1988 has no legal authority. The protocol states: "This protocol shall enter into force on the date of the exchange of the instruments of ratification and its provision shall have effect on the first day of January, 1988".
This was confirmed by a letter to myself dated November 28, 1990 from the Minister of Finance.
The instruments of ratification have not been exchanged, leaving the agreement in limbo. The agreement allows the Canadian government to tax approximately 60,000 Canadians of Italian descent on $250 million of yearly pension benefits. The agreement is flawed, unjust, unworkable and at this moment, illegal.
On behalf of these 60,000 Canadians my question to the Minister of Finance is, what are the consequences of having collected these taxes on $1 billion of revenue if the agreement is never ratified. Are the cheques in the mail?

Mr. Speaker, young children are the heart of any great nation.
One group that is attempting to provide a better system of protection for our children is CACE, or Citizens Against Child Exploitation. This organization is headed by Mrs. Monica Rainey of Kelowna, B.C.
They have a plan that would go a long way to providing a safe environment for our children at school, at day care and in our neighbourhoods. Much like legislation already in existence in some American states, CACE proposes changes to our system that would:
(1) Establish a central registry for convicted child sex offenders in order to allow schools, day care centres and children's clubs to ensure that our children are not at risk by being placed in classrooms with known child sex offenders.
(2) Pass both provincial and federal legislation prohibiting a sex offender from holding a position of trust or authority with children.
A recent provincial study in B.C. specifies that 82 per cent of all sex offenders outside the home are in professional positions of trust. This is obviously a frightening thought for all Canadian parents. Now is not the time for further study, now is the time for action. The foremost priority of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms is to protect society, and what segment of society is more in need of our protection than our children.

Mr. Speaker, when will Quebecers understand that they are a minority here in Ottawa and that they will get nothing more to help them develop to their full potential?
Let us take a look at what is happening in the constitutional negotiations. Mr. Castonguay himself had to quit because he saw the rug being pulled from under him. The same thing happened to the hon. member for Outremont who was losing his credibility on the Belang-er-Campeau commission. The same thing goes for the hon. member for Jonquiere who realized that his own party did not even respect his proposals on his amendments to the bill on a renewed Canada.
Yesterday the Minister of National Health and Welfare, withdrew after being laughed at for two years although he did not know it, because here in Ottawa he can do nothing to change the Constitution.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have the pleasure to announce in this House that on July 11 my riding will host a conference on young Canadians' commitment and attitude to the future of Canada.
This conference is part of the Forum for Young Canadians project, a joint initiative of the Government of Canada and the private sector. Its purpose is to give young Canadians, age 18 to 25, from 15 ridings in Canada an opportunity to study the economic situation of their riding and of Canada.

Following the regional conference in Quebec City in July two young people from my riding will have a chance to share with young people from the other provinces and write a national report.
These young people are expected to meet with officials from the House of Commons and the government in the fall to present proposed solutions to them.
Finally, these young leaders will appear on a special television program to ask Canadians to work toward building a more prosperous and more economically competitive nation.
I would like to congratulate my colleague, the hon. member for London-Middlesex who initiated the project, and the organizers of this event. I also want to wish all the young participants great success.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, today, June 11, is Miners' Memorial Day in Cape Breton. This day holds a special place in the hearts of Cape Bretoners as it commemorates the work of coal miners.
The life of a coal miner has changed through the years, but danger of working underground continues to be a haunting element of that industry.
Today is a day when we recognize the hard work of our miners and remember those who have sacrificed their lives for that industry. Today is an emotional day for many. In particular one must remember the miners whose lives were lost at the Westray Mine explosion on May 9, 1992.
The coal industry has taken many of our miners. Today we reflect with respect, admiration, and a sense of loss upon those men who have died in our mines.
Today we also remember the families of our coal miners, the mothers, the wives, and the children who waited on the surface only to find their worst fears coming true.
On behalf of my constituents in Cape Breton-East Richmond I salute miners for their contributions, not only to the economy of Nova Scotia, but also to our
culture, our history, and our sense of pride on our great island.

Mr. Speaker, Macedonia has always been an integral part of Hellenic history and Hellenic civilization that dates back almost 3,000 years.
Therefore the usurpation of the name Macedonia which from ancient times has been identified with Greece by a republic whose population is mainly of Slav origin is totally unacceptable and would constitute a destabilizing effect and an ongoing concern in the Balkan region.
On the other hand, a timely settlement of the question of the name of the Republic of Skopje without reference to the Greek historic name Macedonia constitutes a stabilizing factor and paves the way for co-operation and support from Greece for Skopje within a framework of security and stability in the region.
Let us hope that Skopje will follow this course of action which would assure a more peaceful and secure future for the country and its people.

Mr. Speaker, last Saturday at the annual convention of the Federation of Canadian Municipalities the Minister of Transport said that his government would not participate with the municipalities in the $15 billion project to renew urban infrastructure. In addition to the billion dollars which this government took from the municipalities in 1991, the minister had the nerve to suggest to the convention of municipalities that $14 billion should be invested in the Trans-Canada highway system instead of urban infrastructure.
The Liberal Leader at the same municipal convention called for a shared-cost infrastructure program between the three levels of government.
June 11, 1992

This new partnership would stimulate the economy, create 60,000 jobs and address the decaying urban infrastructure problem while decreasing the ever-growing unemployment and welfare payments.

Mr. Speaker, Canadian agriculture suffered a great loss with the untimely death Tuesday of Canadian Wheat Board Commissioner Bill Smith. Mr. Smith died as the result of an accident while on a trade mission in China. He was 55.
Bill Smith was raised on the family farm at Inland, Alberta. After graduating from the Vermilion School of Agriculture, he worked his way up through the Alberta Wheat Pool from elevator agent to manager of grain sales.
Appointed a commissioner of the Canadian Wheat Board in 1983 he was very active in international marketing and developed an expertise in dealing with the Chinese and Russian markets, two of Canada's major customers.
As Wheat Board Minister Mayer said: "Bill will be sadly missed. This marks a great loss for his family, friends, the agriculture industry, and Canada as a whole".
Besides his many friends and colleagues in the grain industry, Bill Smith leaves his wife Kathy and five children.
Mr. Speaker, I am sure all members join in extending condolences to Mrs. Smith and her family.

Mr. Speaker, on June 9 on Poundmaker Reserve in northwestern Saskatchewan about 300 western Canadian judges, lawyers and law enforcement people met as part of a six-day seminar on racial, ethnic and cultural equality.
The seminar, the first of its kind in Canada, included a talking circle that heavily criticized a court system which makes little sense to aboriginal people.
Poundmaker Chief Blaine Favel said that the non-Indian court system seeks to punish offenders while the native model strives to heal and bring the offender back into the community.
I commend the people of Poundmaker Reserve, the seminar organizers and the judges of western Canada who participated in this unique and ground-breaking seminar for their recognition that a new judicial relationship must be created and for their willingness to make the seminar a success.
The work they have undertaken is an important step in opening the lines of communication that must eventually lead to fundamental changes in structures and attitudes and a fair judicial system for aboriginal people.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, yesterday I returned from the Eco Summit in Rio. Thousands of people from some 140 countries have gathered to try and achieve consensus on the future of the globe.
Ninety per cent of these people would give their eye teeth to have a Canadian passport because to the world Canada is the best place on earth.
Meanwhile back in Canada, rather than an Eco Summit, we have the ego summit wherein some provincial politicians have discovered that by being intransigent at the constitutional bargaining table they can become national TV stars. Now constitutional renewal has come down to the issue of Senate reform.
Mr. Speaker, I believe most Canadians would simply like to see the Senate abolished. However, if Senate reform is a priority with western Canadians then let us reform it rather than scrap it.
Reform and renewal mean compromise. Canadians are tired of constitutional bickering. They simply want their country preserved. So do I. Perhaps if our constitution ministers would hold a few sessions in Panama or Sri Lanka they would realize how trivial their pious constitutional principles may really be.
So I say to them all: Quit horsing around with the Senate. Get on with the job. Stop putting the future of the greatest country on earth at risk.

June 11, 1992

Mr. Speaker, this week I received a visit from Ms. Chen Chu, a member of the National Assembly of Taiwan and human rights activist, regarding the wrongful imprisonment of Dr. George Chang, a democratic reformer who was jailed immediately upon his return to Taiwan last December after 30 years of exile.
Dr. Chang, a professor and dean at Cooper Union University in New York, is presently being denied proper medical attention by the Kuomintang government of Taiwan.
As confirmed by Amnesty International, Dr. Chang suffers from acute high blood pressure and a tumour which was recently discovered in his neck.
At the very least Canadians abhor the incarceration of political dissidents but to deny medical attention to prisoners of conscience strikes at the heart of our most cherished and fundamental respect for human rights.
The eyes of the world are watching now. I call on Premier Hau to demonstrate Taiwan's commitment to human rights and free Dr. Chang before it is too late.

Mr. Speaker, this coming weekend, Sunday, June 14 to be exact, marks one of the main events in Canada's 125th birthday celebrations, the National Neighbourhood Party.
In communities large and small across the country picnics and block parties are being organized to bring Canadians closer together in a spirit of pride and goodwill as neighbours and fellow citizens in this great nation.
In my own riding of Fredericton-York-Sunbury, a host of volunteers calling themselves the Fredericton Civil Pride Committee and representing a broad range of organizations and associations will put on a block party to please every age and to make us proud to be Canadians.
I am particularly pleased that we have been able to include my own annual public constituency picnic as an integral part of this 125th anniversary salute to Canada.
These national neighbourhood parties are open to everyone. Just like the future of our country, the potential of coming together in a sense of common Canadian citizenship is limited only by our own imagination.
Let us all join in toasting Canada with conviction and commitment as we celebrate its 125th birthday party this Sunday.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, earlier today this House passed a bill to curb cross-border shopping. At the same time, the left hand of the government across the way, namely Crown-owned Petro-Canada, was busy opening a gas bar in the well-known Canadian city of Plattsburg, New York. There displaying proudly the Maple Leaf of Canada, Petro-Canada advertises cut-rate gas, discount cigarettes and everything else that this great Crown-owned corporation can use to entice Canadians to cross the border and shop in the great U.S.A.
The milk of this U.S. cash cow is so plentiful that Petro-Canada wants to repeat the same exercise in other northern U.S. cities, namely in Vermont and elsewhere. One American is reported to have said to the media: "I can't get over your Canadian government. They tax everything so sky-high you can't pay it and then they go and open a gas bar down here. What are they trying to do?" That is what all of us are asking ourselves as well.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to bring the attention of the House to Grosse ile, an island in the St. Lawrence River just east of Quebec. The island was a clearing house for European immigrants and served as a quarantine station between 1832 and 1860. Over-population and general starvation forced many Irish families to immigrate to Canada on what were later dubbed coffin ships. Disease was rampant because living conditions were poor and in
June 11, 1992

very cramped spaces. Many immigrants were hospitalized on arrival at Grosse tie and thousands eventually died.
Since more than 12,000 Irish immigrants are buried on the island, Irish Canadian communities continue to have a special concern for its future. Parks Canada has proposed the creation of a national park on Grosse lie commemorating and celebrating European migration to Canada. Canadians of Irish descent are requesting that this historic site be attributed to our Irish ancestors.
I hope the parks department can accommodate this request.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Acting Prime Minister.
In light of the information we are now receiving on the constitutional conference and the inability to reach agreement, could the government tell this House what it intends to do in the coming days?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, we are waiting for the report from the Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs. Once it has received this report the government will make a decision on what comes after.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my supplementary is for the Deputy Prime Minister.
Yesterday we saw the minister of health walking out of the conference. As everyone knows, he was named by the Prime Minister to be there to help the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs.
My question to the Deputy Prime Minister is this: Was the departure of the minister of health authorized by the government or was it just another Laurel and Hardy show?
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, as the hon. Leader of the Opposition will know, the Minister of National Health and Welfare has enormous portfolio responsibilities. He has been attending the constitutional meetings as a senior minister from Quebec. He indicated yesterday that he felt that he could contribute no more time to that process since his portfolio responsibilities required his attention. If I can quote him, he said: "I repeat once again, I didn't walk out. I didn't want to protest against anything. I just want that we realize that this step for me is over, that we have to move on to another step". He continues to be very supportive of the government's activities and hopeful, as all of us are, that the process will result in success.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, how can the government believe that the people of Canada will take this government seriously in the matter when two senior cabinet ministers representing Canada at this negotiating table cannot agree? We would like to know from that side of the House what this government intends to do next and give some example to the nation that first the government will have order in its own House before trying to solve the problems of the nation.

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is difficult to say what the government will do next when this step of the process is not completed. We will see what the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs reports.
One thing I can tell the hon. Leader of the Opposition is that this government will do everything possible to ensure that this country remains united.

Mr. Speaker, my question is to the same minister. There has been a lot of agreement on fundamental issues of critical importance to Canadians, for example, the aboriginal question, distinct society, linguistic duality, the social charter.
Will this government now call a First Ministers Conference to try to unravel this constitutional impasse, to solve this constitutional labyrinth?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would simply repeat that we do not yet know what the final results of this

Oral Questions
stage of the process will be. When we do know, we will be in a position to evaluate what is the most appropriate next step.
Once again I underline that we are committed to the preservation of this country and doing whatever it takes to ensure that end.

Mr. Speaker, the Minister of National Health and Welfare talked about a new approach, "a new way", of taking another step, of pursuing a new path when he left the meeting last night.
Can the minister tell us what this new path or further step to be taken is? Can he tell us what Canadians can expect from this government in this constitutional crisis situation?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, as I said, it is impossible to define a new approach until we know what the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs will report to the government and the House.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Deputy Prime Minister.
I want to turn to the proposed purchase of helicopters at a cost of $4.3 billion. The government has defended this purchase by saying that 15 of these 50 new helicopters will be used to replace search and rescue helicopters.
There is no question that it is necessary to upgrade the search and rescue helicopters and the service we have. We know that rather than buying new ones, these helicopters could be upgraded for another 20 years of life for $200 million.
The Deputy Prime Minister often says as Minister of Finance that he has no choices. Here is a choice: $4.3 billion or $200 million. Which is it going to be?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I must advise the hon. member that quite honestly that information is not correct.
To just put this project into context, for some long period we have been looking at a replacement helicopter project, both to replace the existing Sea Kings on the ships and the search and rescue. This has been a longstanding project. It is a project that will take about 13 years to come to completion. The department has been allocating within its budget appropriate funds to provide for this new equipment.
Obviously, no decisions have been made at this point. The minister will be looking at a variety of alternatives. All members would agree that we do need to look at this in terms of what will serve our needs best over the long term, the kind of helicopter that will enable us to provide the capability to do all the different tasks that are required, that will lead us into the 21st century up to the year 2035. Indeed, it may be more appropriate to spend some money now and over the next 13 years to enable us to have that up-to-date modem capability for the long term.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary is for the Deputy Prime Minister. We know that in 20 years technology will change radically.
If we are able to upgrade those helicopters to make sure that we can provide search and rescue efficiently and with safety for those pilots, that is what we should be doing and doing it now.

My supplementary is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister. The other day, the Prime Minister said in the House: We can't spend money we don't have. I assume the Prime Minister can spend the money he does have. I also assume the government now has $4.3 billion to spend. Instead of spending this money on helicopters to defend us against enemies that no longer exist-the Soviets-will the government spend this money on Canada's children who need daycare since that problem does exist?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, again I would ask the hon. member to look at this issue in its proper context.
We have within the Department of National Defence an allocation of funds that is required to enable us to carry out missions that the government and the defence committee agree upon. Within that budget, we try to
June 11, 1992

allocate funds between personnel, infrastructure and capital.
We have over the years, in the 1970s, not spent the amount of money on capital that is required to maintain our capital equipment effectively. We need to change that to provide the equipment that our men and women can utilize to provide the sovereignty patrols, fisheries patrols, drug interdictions, search and rescue and to protect our sovereignty on both our coasts.
If the hon. member looks at that within the context of the over-all defence budget, this indeed is going to be a requirement to replace our existing equipment such as helicopters with new modem equipment that can take us well into the 21st century and assure that we can undertake our responsibilities effectively.

Mr. Speaker, since 1975 there has been a 57 per cent increase in real dollars to defence in this country.
There are many long term investments this country has to make. One of them is in this country's children and in training for this country's citizens. We are busy fighting a country that no longer exists, the U.S.S.R. Maybe it is time to invest in a country that does exist and that is Canada.
I want to say to the minister that for the cost of one-third of one helicopter we could restore the Court Challenges Program for 10 years. We could introduce a decent student employment program for the cost of one helicopter and for the cost of 10 helicopters, we could have a real training program in this country.
Will the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance scrap this $4.3 billion boondoggle and invest the money in Canadians so that we can go into the 21st century with pride and with well-trained citizens?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am afraid that all of the outrage does not really respond to the actual situation. The government responds to all the various needs of its citizens in terms of all of our departmental responsibilities.
Oral Questions
Would my hon. colleague indeed want to scrap the Department of National Defence to make us incapable of providing defence of our sovereignty, so that we are unable to do the kinds of operations on the east coast dealing with fisheries interdictions and unable to work at drug interdiction and search and rescue?
Can the hon. member not understand that we have a long-term planning process within the Department of National Defence. We have been planning for years for replacement equipment, a 13-year program. We will be looking at all of the options and the minister will be bringing forward recommendations to cabinet in due course.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Deputy Prime Minister.
One day before his departure for Rio, the Prime Minister stated in this House that reductions in greenhouse gas emissions are firmly on Canada's agenda at home and at the earth summit.
However that position was contradicted by the official position taken by the Minister of the Environment at the summit when he called not for reduction in greenhouse gas emissions but rather stabilization.
My question to the Deputy Prime Minister is this: Which is the position of the Canadian government, reduction as stated by the Prime Minister or stabilization as stated by the Minister of the Environment?

Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister arrived in Rio de Janeiro today. He was greeted by many good reports. He said that the biodiversity convention was signed this morning. We expect to sign the global warming greenhouse gas convention within the next few days.
But I must mention the number of people who have spoken about what Canada has done at the United Nations. It says: "For years Canada has set the example of the green country that we hope all countries will use as an example". This is the administrator of the United

Oral Questions
Nations Development Program. Eve Savory from CBC says: "Canada's delegation has won the respect of other countries by going out of its way to be helpful".
We are going to be working very closely with other delegations. We will be signing the convention at Rio in the next few days.

Mr. Speaker, it is a good press release, but it doesn't answer the question, which was very specific.
We already know that Australia, New Zealand, Germany, Austria, Italy and Denmark have endorsed a policy for the reduction of greenhouse gases. However, there is a contradiction between the position taken by the Prime Minister on reduction and the Canadian government's official polity which wants to stabilize levels at those existing in 1990.
My question is simple: Which policy does the Canadian government endorse? The policy announced by the Minister of the Environment or the policy announced by the Prime Minister? Mr. Speaker, we can't do both!

Mr. Speaker, we will be signing the global warming convention in the next few days. But I want to say that within the green plan we have the stabilization of the greenhouse gases by the year 2000 at the 1990 level.
But the green plan has gone further than that. We have allotted more than $150 million directed at the uncertainties within the global warming issue in order to reduce those at some point in time.
We are working with the provinces. We have a national action strategy dealing with the provinces as to how we are going to reduce the greenhouse gases. We are on course and we will be signing that convention in Rio de Janiero in the next few days.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of external affairs and in her absence the Deputy Prime Minister.
The justice committee this morning unanimously passed a motion asking the minister of external affairs to request the expulsion of David Spencer and Christine Lamont from Brazil. The committee heard clear evidence of a travesty of justice and discrimination against these two Canadians.
The minister continues to drag her heels. When will the minister make that request?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, in the absence of the Secretary of State for External Affairs, I am prepared to advise the hon. member that I understand the report will be going to her. I believe she will be back next week and I am sure she will take the committee's recommendations under advisement and will be back to the House.

Mr. Speaker, that response is not good enough. The Lamont family and the minister's officials met with the judge who told them that he was under extreme pressure to bring in a clean sweep verdict.
The minister has agreed that 28 years is excessive and the trial was clearly flawed. Canadians and members of all three parties want the minister to act.
Why will the minister not do the right thing and act now?

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I understand that the report of the standing committee was just tabled this morning. I think my hon. colleague must recognize that the minister and officials will obviously want to read that report and to discuss it. Upon her return next week I am sure she will have that opportunity.

Mr. Speaker, my question is to the Minister of Justice.
I want to read a quote from a gun store owner in Los Angeles. He says: "It's scary-they're buying guns; they are going to carry on them-Some of these people have never held a gun or even seen a gun close up". Gun sales in L.A. have gone up from 50 to 500 per cent, depending on the gun store.
June 11, 1992

Is the minister aware that British Columbians are concerned that the dramatic increase in guns being bought south of the border will spill over into British Columbia?
Is the minister aware that this week during the hearings on the draft regulations on gun control, Staff Sergeant Neal Jessop of Windsor, Ontario said that officials at the border are, and I quote: "only scratching the surface of the cross-border gun trade"?
I want to ask the minister: What steps is the government taking to prevent the flow of prohibited and illegal guns into Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in case the hon. member has not noticed, a great deal has been devoted over the last 18 months to strengthening Canada's gun control legislation and bringing forward regulations and an implementation scheme that would in fact give full force to that legislation.
Among the legislative amendments are not simply amendments to the Criminal Code but also amendments to the statutes affecting customs and excise that are important.
Those who are opposed to gun control sometimes point out that no gun control legislation will ever completely succeed in preventing crimes committed with firearms or the smuggling of firearms. However, I believe that what we have done in this House in passing the gun control legislation is to increase the number of tools in the hands of police and customs officers to enable them as much as humanly possible to protect Canadians from the illegal traffic in arms.
I congratulate members of the House for passing that legislation. I thank them for the consideration they have been giving to the regulations. The recommendations of the committee will be taken into account before the final enactment of the regulations. I think we are doing as much as is possible in this House to try to make sure that we do not have the same kind of situation.

Mr. Speaker, as the minister knows, I am not talking about the good work we have all been doing on the gun control
Oral Questions
regulations here. I am talking about the guns flowing across the border.
In front of a committee of the House, here is what a customs officer said: "It is a virtual paradise for anyone who may be inclined at this point to do any smuggling of guns. As I say, you should be alarmed because we are alarmed". The government has been warned. We want a safe, gun-free country in Canada.
Is the minister prepared to toughen up controls at the border? Is she prepared to bring in tough new laws for the criminal misuse of guns and is she prepared to crack down on the illegal violation of the new gun control laws?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in case the hon. member had not noticed, we have brought in tough new sentences for firearms related crimes. We have tried to clamp down legislatively on the criminal use of firearms. Alas, we have no control over the firearms climate in the United States.
It is clear that the majority of people in the United States favour a national gun control scheme. They do not have it there. Perhaps they should consider adopting a parliamentary style of government which would enable the government to reflect the wishes of the majority of Americans, instead of people here looking south to adopt inefficient American institutions of government.
Canada and the United States have the longest undefended border in the world. In many ways that is good; in many ways that is negative. I think many Americans are looking at the kinds of decisions that have been made in this House and the ability of this Parliament to reflect the wishes of Canadians. They are beginning to seriously question the will of their own legislators to translate the concerns that Americans have into effective legislation.
The example we are providing here is perhaps one of the best ways that we can influence in an extraterritorial way the developments south of the border.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Employment and Immigration. He knows that last week a

June 11, 1992
Oral Questions
scientific report was tabled which shows that the northern cod stock is in such poor condition that the fishery may have to be closed.
This has really come as no surprise to the people involved in the fishing industry. What is a surprise and a disappointment to them is that this government refuses to talk about specific plans about compensation.
I ask the minister, as an Atlantic Canadian, will he have compassion and show some leadership and tell us what compensation plan he has in mind with this situation?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I answered that question yesterday and that answer remains valid today.

Mr. Speaker, the minister's answer yesterday was that he could not give me answers to a hypothetical situation and he needed more specifics. If he needs specifics, I will give him specifics.
Specifically, in mid-February a specific plant in Port Union on the Bonavista peninsula closed down and 80 specific families were without compensation because they did not have enough time to qualify for unemployment insurance. Right now, specifically, they have no fish, they have no jobs, they have no compensation and they have no idea how this government is going to look after them.
I will now ask the minister as a supplementary what specific action plan he has for those specific people under this specific situation?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it gives me great pleasure to participate in this debate this afternoon on behalf of the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources on the third reading of Bill C-41, the energy efficiency act.
It is of great interest to watch and see how Bill C-41 moved through the legislative process in this House. You may recall that at second reading the minister suggested that Bill C-41 was a good example of the kind of legislation that could be improved at the legislative committee stage. I am happy to say that he was right. The legislative committee on Bill C-41 has proposed amendments to this bill that will enhance the effectiveness of the legislation.
Several proposed amendments were technical in nature, related to the compliance provisions. However, most of the significant amendments approved by the committee expanded the scope of the legislation to include doors and windows.
The committee members agreed that the scope of the bill should include doors and windows because of their significant role in achieving greater energy efficiency in buildings and their amenability to the regulatory scheme contemplated by the legislation. I am pleased to note that the legislative committee took great care in developing the appropriate wording for this amendment.
The legislative committee also agreed on proposing amendments which would strengthen the compliance system, primarily by allowing inspectors to direct an importer of a non-compliant product to remove it from Canada, and explicitly providing for court orders as alternatives, or in addition to fines as punishment where a person is convicted of an offence under the act.
Bill C-41 has been improved as a result of the legislative committee deliberations and decisions. Useful insights were offered concerning the operation of regulatory programs under authority of this legislation. The committee's hearings confirmed the value and importance of proceeding expeditiously with this legislation. The legislative committee is also to be commended for its pragmatic review of Bill C-41 and for the useful amendments it has brought back to this House. I would
June 11, 1992

like to take this opportunity to thank members of the legislative committee on Bill C-41 for a job well done.
I would like to turn my attention for a few moments to the specifics of Bill C-41, the energy efficiency act, which provides statutory authority for initiatives related to energy labelling, minimum energy efficiency standards and the collection of statistics and information.
With regard to labelling, the bill will facilitate enhancement and expansion of the existing Energuide labelling program which currently applies to refrigerators, ranges, ovens, freezers, dishwashers, clothes washers and dryers. Energuide regulations require that new appliances bear a specified label providing information on a product's use of energy. This is to encourage and assist more energy-efficient purchasing decisions.
Bill C-41 will provide EMR with statutory authority and Energuide regulations which have been the responsibility of Consumer and Corporate Affairs. EMR is redesigning the label to make it easier to read and comprehend. The department is analysing how the program could best be expanded to cover other products.
The bill will permit the government to make regulations requiring that specific products provide at least a minimum level of energy efficiency before they can be marketed in Canada. This meets requests from the provinces, territories and industry that the federal government help establish a consistent national energy efficiency regulatory regime.
I would like to stress that the regulatory actions will only be taken following consultations with affected parties. Regulations will be developed so as to avoid unnecessary costs to manufacturers and to facilitate co-ordination with provincial authorities. They will be developed with due regard for Canada's international trade obligations and the nation's ability to compete.
I feel that it is worth while to note that EMR will seek to ensure that new energy efficiency standards will be consistent with those in force in provincial and American jurisdictions.
Part II of the bill concerns the collection and use of statistics pertaining to efficiency of energy use and the adoption of alternative energy sources.
Government Orders
It is hoped that most of the data and information required by EMR's new efficiency and alternative energy program can be obtained from existing data bases held by Statistics Canada and others, or from voluntary surveys, so that recourse to the energy efficiency act can be avoided.
I would like to stress to this House that this government will ensure that regulation will be used in moderation in co-operation with other authorities and in consultation with those who will be most affected.
This government is confident that the energy efficiency act, along with the efficiency and alternative energy program it supports, constitutes an important and responsible step for Canada to take toward the issue of global warming. The EAE program will have net environmental and economic benefits. The environmental benefits include improvement of air quality, preservation of water and land resources and reduced emissions of greenhouse gases.
Canadian consumers who consider energy efficiency carefully when making their purchasing decisions will be able to reduce their annual energy costs, thereby freeing up some of their income for other uses.
Through investments in energy efficiency and alternative energy sources, Canadian industry can lower its energy costs, raise productivity and improve the ability to compete internationally.
There is a growing international interest in competitive products, technologies and services offering energy efficiency or employing alternative energy sources. Thus, Canadian companies responding to increased domestic demand in these areas gain international opportunities to expand their markets.
In conclusion, I would like to say that Bill C-41, the energy efficiency act, is part of a broader program to help Canadians use energy more wisely.
This government believes that the improvement of energy efficiency is an essential component of any responsible response in the use of global warming.
However, governments alone cannot resolve the issue. Individuals and organizations need to re-examine how these energies are used. This government's new energy efficiency alternatives energy program emphasizes actions that are economic in their own right.

The bill is a step, a very small step, in the right direction but its scope should have been broadened in order to leave the door open for examining energy-efficient trends and other sectors, like commercial and residential lighting, improved voltage regulations, transportation mode shifts, use of waste heat to generate electricity and fuel-switching options. We should take advantage of all feasible options and there are many options available around the world. Many of them were developed in Canada and, if I may say, were cruelly defused by the budget policies of this government since 1984.1 am thinking of wind energy, solar energy, alternative energy, photovoltaics and many, many others.
Government Orders
If we had taken advantage of all the feasible options for saving energy more cheaply than producing it, our need for new production facilities would be reduced.
If a consumer replaces a single 75-watt bulb with an 18 watt compact fluorescent lamp that lasts 10,000 hours, the consumer can save the electricity that a typical Canadian power plant would make from 770 pounds of coal. As a result, about 1,600 pounds of C02 and 18 pounds of sulphur dioxide would not be released into the atmosphere. What is Rio about if not things like that?
In 1990 Ontario Hydro estimated reducing demand in houses heated by electricity could save 1,350 megawatts. Even half of what was saved would defer and perhaps eliminate the need for a large nuclear reactor with all of its risks and hazards in the view of many people living outside of Algoma.
Increasing energy efficiency should become a priority with this government. As I said before, I believe this will be a priority with the Chretien government to be elected as soon as Canadians have a chance to get to the voting booths.
When the U.S. introduced conservation laws which years ago prompted the manufacturing of energy-efficient appliances, our regulatory authorities in Canada did nothing. Now, instead of the threat of confiscation and destruction of private property, the government might better set an example by emphasizing energy efficiency and conservation in its overall operations, particularly in government-funded facilities.
Energy-efficient operations and cost-effective energy retrofits should be increased to demonstrate to our fellow citizens everywhere the many opportunities for improvements. After all, if the government approves of wasting energy, it should not be surprised if other people, citizens, react accordingly.
Energy efficiency could be given increased priority when purchasing new government vehicles and equipment. Madam Speaker, you deserve enormous credit for what the House of Commons is doing to try to promote energy efficiency, a green House of Commons. Perhaps the rug colour here was an early prediction of what you would be doing now in terms of the environment around this budding. Could you please talk to the people in the

Government Orders
Senate and see what they are doing? They should be green as well.
More than 3 million personal computers are in use in our offices and the number is increasing. According to Ontario Hydro as much as 90 per cent of the energy consumed by computers can be saved by introducing more laptop models, inkjet printers, new PowerKey technology, which allows users to control computer times, peripherals, et cetera.
Industries such as appliance manufacturing are global in scope. Products are designed and manufactured to meet the needs of a market which is much broader than our Canadian market. In 1987 the U.S. national appliance energy conservation act established standards for minimum energy efficiency in 13 classes of major household appliances.
I could not agree more and most members on this side would agree as well with the view of the Canadian Manufacturers Association that the standards used in the United States should provide a benchmark so that Canadian companies are not put to a competitive disadvantage by more stringent requirements in the United States than in Canada.
A thorough regulatory analysis of the U.S. standards and provincial standards, both those currently in place and planned in the future, is needed if the bill before us now is to benefit Canadians and our economy significantly-
This issue becomes of utmost importance especially in view of the fact that our industrial infrastructure might not be able to cope with new regulatory initiatives that are too intrusive and out of step with current economic realities.
In its submission to the energy, mines and resources committee, the National Energy Conservation Association stated that:
The industry infrastructure as it now exists in Canada falls
significantly short in its ability to deliver the conservation products
and services demanded by tomorrow's market.
There is unfortunately a lack of skilled trades to implement energy efficiency measures, a lack of access to capital financing for energy efficiency improvements, a lack of provincial incentives for investment in energy efficiency.
There should be some vehicles designed which would assist manufacturers, especially small and medium-sized ones, to change over to the state of the art technologies. Small Canadian producers are particularly vulnerable, as they would have to gear up their operations to deal with new regulatoiy standards and at the same time with a larger marketplace and stronger competition.
The concerns of manufacturers have also been the level of stringency with respect to proposed standards, deadlines they would have to meet, additional costs and so on. Consideration should be given to offering tax credits to manufacturers that exceed existing standards.
In fairness to the bill, regulations would phase out some inefficient equipment from the Canadian market and impose restrictions on imports of electricity guzzling appliances to Canada.
The bill will not prevent our manufacturers, as I understand it, from clearing their inventories by exporting substandard appliances to countries where government efficiency standards are non-existent or less than our own.
The widespread public concern about our natural environment which is at the heart of the debate on energy efficiency and conservation is of global proportions. Exporting inefficient equipment for instance to developing nations would only undermine efforts undertaken by Canadian consumers and manufacturers.
As the Friends of the Earth put it: "We do not want to see a repeat of the tetraethyl lead issue where lead was banned for use in gasoline here but the manufacturer is still allowed to export to developing countries". Is that not exactly the kind of thing that the developing world is objecting to both at Rio and in many other fora?
As reported in the Scientific American, economic projections show that if nothing is done to hasten energy technology development and to introduce existing efficiency technology in developing countries, global climate change and other major environmental problems will escalate beyond unacceptable levels.
Even if our so-called developed countries manage to reduce our LCO2 emissions by 50 per cent, population growth and economic development in the so-called developing countries would most likely increase their

CO2 emissions from 450 to about 900 kilograms per person annually by the year 2030.
World-wide emissions of CO2 will then be two and a half times what they are per year now. In addition, Canada does not have specific policy objectives in its foreign aid and trade policies and programs that encourage and enhance the transfer of environmental technologies, including energy efficiency technologies to developing nations.
This legislation is a small mini-step in a better direction. If properly implemented, it could assist Canada not only in supplying other countries with such technologies but could also provide Canadians with competitive trade opportunities.
In closing-my colleague from Prince Edward Island will be speaking momentarily I believe-we will be supporting this bill but are profoundly regretful that the government did not take a large step in the right direction, rather than what I think can fairly be called a milli-step-"milli" as in millimetre-in the right direction.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased today to rise and speak in favour of this legislation, Bill C-41, which is the government's long overdue energy efficiency legislation.
This bill, among other things, will allow the government to establish minimum energy efficiency standards for energy-using products like stoves, fridges and dishwashers. It also will allow the government to require labelling of energy-using products to say how much energy they use. It will compile statistics and other information on energy use and alternative energy, and promote energy efficiency and alternative energy like solar power, for example.
I want to congratulate my colleague from Edmonton Southeast, who has just spoken, on his very excellent speech on Bill C-41.1 also want to applaud his efforts at prodding the government to promote energy efficiency in this country.
As a former opposition energy critic, I can appreciate the difficulty he had in trying to persuade the government to increase its effort in the energy efficiency area. I tried repeatedly do this when I was the critic, but the government did not seem to get the message that energy efficiency not only helps Canada's environment but it helps the Canadian economy as well.
Government Orders
By using less energy, Canadian industries make their product more cheaply and that makes them more competitive internationally.
It is no wonder that the government did not get the message when you look at the record of what has happened since this government was elected. In 1990, this government allowed Canada to become the first in energy use per capita among industrialized countries. It also allowed this country to become the second in per capita energy carbon dioxide emissions.
We all know that carbon dioxide is the gas that is released when fuels are burned and which is believed to cause global warming.
This is the same government that cut the energy conservation and renewable energy funding from about $500 million in 1984 to roughly $30 million in 1990-91. It cut the funding for research on solar, wind and hydrogen energy to name a few.
This government also closed down energy department offices across this country, offices which provided information and grants for energy conservation and renewable energy projects. I know in my own province of Prince Edward Island we had an office that provided very valuable information to people living not only in my riding but in all of Prince Edward. It provided information on how we could save on energy and it also provided grants.
This government closed those offices and therefore took away the outlet that provided this very valuable information as well as the grants for conservation and renewable energy projects.
The programs to financially help people insulate their homes, to inform people about energy efficiency of home appliances and so on and to advise industry on how to reduce energy consumption were all discarded by this government.
Largely because of this government's abandoning the energy efficiency programs established by the previous Liberal government, we in Canada, as a result, have a more polluted environment and a less competitive economy.
The statistics that I mentioned earlier prove this fact, but I want to mention a few other statistics. In the early 1980s there was a 10 per cent reduction in per capita carbon dioxide emissions in this country. We also know that less carbon dioxide emissions means cleaner air. Yet over the last five years there has not been any reduction in carbon dioxide emissions by the energy industry. In

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
fact there have been increases. Carbon dioxide emissions have been allowed to increase by 8 per cent in the last five years.
Clearly this government has a long way to go to match the record of the previous government on carbon dioxide emissions.
I am pleased that the legislation we have before us today shows that the government has finally answered calls from environmental groups and from this side of the House. Certainly the passage of this energy efficiency legislation is necessary if the government is going to come even close to meeting the target of stabilizing the C02 emissions at the 1990 level. We on this side of the House have been saying this all along. It is what environmental groups have been saying as well. Reducing energy demand is one of the best ways to reduce pollution.
In commenting on the current environmental summit in Rio, one expert said recently: "The ultimate environmental issue is how we use energy, the technology of energy for fueling our cars, heating our homes, producing goods and services".
I am very pleased today to see that the government has finally started to get this message. It has proceeded with Bill C-41, legislation which I said earlier is long overdue.
I want to turn for a moment to my home province of Prince Edward Island and to the progress that has been made there on alternate energy work.
A waste plant at Charlottetown bums the local garbage to provide heat for several nearby buildings including a hospital, a high school, two shopping malls and two colleges. The garbage that would otherwise get landfilled is turned into steam for local use. This plant was given a beautification award not very long ago by the local community. My province is extremely dependent on imported oil for its fuel needs, yet the energy from this waste plant has reduced the amount of oil needed to be imported. At the same time, it has helped to clean up the environment.
I will conclude my remarks by saying I am pleased that this government has finally moved in this direction and has brought in legislation for energy efficiency and diversity in energy. Certainly, it is legislation that is long overdue.

Madam Speaker, I rise to speak on Bill C-41. This bill is certainly a very minor step by the government with regard to energy efficiency and energy efficiency for Canadian industry.
I doubt this bill will actually take us to the situation we were at in 1983 or 1984. The former Liberal government had a very aggressive program for energy conservation and alternate energy use. It was a massive national program to try to take us off oil and fossil fuels.
This legislation sets some standards. It makes provisions for efficiency in appliances and prohibits the use of appliances which are traded or moved across provincial or international borders. It regulates the sale of such equipment which is transported interprovincially. It establishes minimum levels of energy efficiency for household refrigerators, freezers, ranges, ovens, dishwashers, clothes washers and dryers. It tries to do it in parallel with the United States so that whatever is produced in either country would be compatible for trade and useful in that regard.
But if we look back to where we were in 1984 before this government came to power, the Main Estimates will show that with conservation and renewable energy the Government of Canada was spending $575 million then. By 1988-89 the actual expenditures had been reduced to almost nothing. In 1989-90 it was something like $44 million. Since then there has been no commitment for energy conservation and renewable energy.
That is a tragedy. During all those years that the Government of Canada was putting energy conservation and renewable energy mechanisms in place the carbon dioxide level was falling down. Since that time, the carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere have been going up.
This is really one small step back to the future, back to the past. I hope that the government, having made this one small step, will move on to making more steps with regard to energy conservation. That surely is the future.
June 11, 1992

In my constituency in the last couple of years Ontario Hydro has put in place a massive program to reduce energy use in the town of Espanola which has a population of about 6,000.
Ontario Hydro operates on the basis that if one kilowatt of demand can be saved, it is willing to spend up to $3,000 because to provide that in new generating capacity the cost would be even greater. What it has done in the community of Espanola is to provide some $9 million to go through every home that is heated by electricity. A composite program is put in place in which Ontario Hydro pays up to 80 per cent of the cost of reducing the demand. It will spend up to $3,000 to reduce the demand by one kilowatt per year.
That is an excellent thought. I have heard it said that whatever the cost of the Great Whale project is in northern Quebec, if we spent an equivalent amount of money on the island of Montreal we could save the amount of power that is going to be generated by the Great Whale project.
The genius of conservation and saving energy is it is not saved once, it is saved every year. For example, one of the programs the Liberal government had back in the early 1980s provided, I think, $800 to replace an oil-fired furnace with a gas-fired furnace. I took advantage of that, along with everyone else on my street. I spent something like $800, the government provided $800 and I had a new gas furnace in my home. It was a big advantage because the oil-fired furnace was 20 years old and getting worn out in any event.
Now a typical home on that street is heated for about $450 to $500 whereas with oil it was costing at least $1,000 or $1,200 a year. With electricity it was even more.
It is not the initial cost, although that is a stumbling block. But even with the program the former Liberal government had, that cost was reduced. So in that example, at least $500 to $700 is saved each and every year. At the same time, the fuel being used does not contribute nearly as much carbon dioxide to the atmosphere.
I am touching on the program in Espanola because, as far as I know, it is the first community in Canada and perhaps in the world where audits have been conducted
Government Orders
in every electrically heated house to determine the heating and lighting costs.
Replacing light bulbs reduced the demand for electricity by some 70 per cent. Homes were completely reinsulated. Heating costs for hot water were cut by installing new shower heads. Windows and doors were replaced.
In this program being carried out over these past two years by Ontario Hydro the energy demand has been reduced significantly. There is a weakness in the program in that it should have been used for all homes in the community including those not heated by electricity. However, the idea of spending money on energy conservation really is a good one.
Bill C-41 of course does not do anything like that. It simply establishes standards for appliances, equipment and those kinds of things. We are running out of oil in the western sedimentary basin. As a northern nation we should be looking at ways of converting to natural gas and ways of reducing demand for electricity through conservation. To that extent, I support the bill.
In the community of Elliot Lake there are a great many homes which were originally sponsored by Ontario Hydro. Unfortunately, they were built in the early 1980s and were not particularly energy efficient.
One of the diversification projects we have planned for that community is one in co-operation with Ontario Hydro to make it a very energy efficient community. A proposal was presented to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources just this week where we would like to see the federal government establish standards for retrofitting existing homes.
The R-2000 program has been going for many years for new homes and has been very successful. I believe it is being used now in Japan.
The federal government has a responsibility and we are proposing to the minister that we should be developing those standards in Elliot Lake in co-operation with what Ontario Hydro is doing in retrofitting that community. I certainly hope that the government will look at that as an important energy conservation and an alternative energy mechanism for that community.
If Ontario Hydro carries through with what it was talking about which was in terms of $2 billion and $4 billion of energy conservation and retrofitting of homes throughout the province, it seems to me that that would be a major industry. Just as building the Great Whale

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
power project or building new dams, there is no question that in many circumstances we can reduce the demand and provide a lot of employment for people.
There comes a point in a free and democratic society where standards cannot be imposed below a certain level, but clearly with incentives we can reduce the demand for electricity, for our fossil fuels and at the same time help the environment.
This bill is one small step. If the government would maintain the support that was there in the early 1980s, we not only would have much lower levels of carbon dioxide in our atmosphere today, but we would also be a much more efficient energy user. We have one of the highest uses of energy in the world and that certainly is nothing we want to brag about.
What we were able to achieve in the early 1980s shows that if the government has the will and determination to move in that direction we can become a very efficient country. It must be a co-operative operation because it involves the general masses, giant provincial utilities like Ontario Hydro, the entire energy industry, and natural gas pipelines and so on.
I am told that the building of the natural gas pipeline to New York had a powerful impact on the State of New York and New York City deciding to cancel their contract with the Great Whale Project. It meant they had relatively cheap natural gas for energy conversion to electricity and for energy heating purposes in that state and city.
Last year we had an important seminar on the greenhouse effect and the impact of carbon dioxide. It was chaired by the hon. member for Perth-Wellington- Waterloo, who is the chairman of the agriculture committee. Many members of our committee on agriculture took part along with those in transport, environment, and energy.
No one could sit through that seminar and participate in it without believing that the world faces a quantum change in the environment because of the use of fossil fuels. We must use every mechanism whether it is converting to natural gas, which is still a fossil fuel but produces less carbon dioxide, or moving in other directions.
There is a private members' motion next week from the member for Lambton-Middlesex about the use of ethanol. Clearly that will have a powerful impact if we in this country are able to switch to the use of ethanol in our automotive fuels. We will see a dramatic reduction in the amount of carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide produced by the use of ethanol as a blended fuel with gasoline.
There are many things we can do in this country. We simply must put in place the standards, incentives, and the directions we want to go if we want to reach our objective of keeping carbon dioxide levels in the year 2000 at the level they were in 1990.
I am sorry we did not maintain the momentum we had in the early 1980s to switch away from fossil fuels, but that was a decision made by the government of the day in 1984. It is regrettable but at least the introduction of this bill shows that it realized the errors it made. We hope we can get back on track and move toward a society that is less wasteful of our natural resources and more concerned about our environment.
This bill is one small step in that direction and that is why we will be supporting Bill C-41.
