speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Solicitor General of Canada
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to rise today to begin third reading debate of Bill C-71, an Act to amend the Criminal Records Act.
I would like to begin my remarks by stating that I am extremely appreciative of the spirit of co-operation that has brought us to third reading in what may be a record time for legislation of such importance.

These changes directly respond to serious concerns about the pardon granting process that have been raised by members of this House on behalf of constituents and by representatives of the wider criminal justice system.

I believe that the broad support of my colleagues reflects the pressing need for this legislation. Our goal was to find a way to reform the system without disrupting its basic objectives. These include providing fair and timely service to eligible ex-offenders, creating a more efficient records system, and, most important, ensuring public safety.
The government has reviewed various options for reform. We were assisted in our review by some very useful consultations with affected constituencies. These included the police, victims groups, offender-assisting
Government Orders
agencies and provincial government representatives. They all provided excellent advice and suggestions which helped us develop our final proposals.
I would like to thank officials of the Ministry of the Solicitor General for undertaking the very important task of canvassing constituencies with a stake in this legislation. The Department of Justice also deserves a vote of thanks for its assistance and careful drafting of a bill that reflects such a broad range of interests.
I would also like to thank the members and chairman of the Justice and Solicitor General Standing Committee for their timely review and support of this bill. The government was pleased to accept an amendment proposed by the opposition during clause-by-clause review of the bill. The fact that this amendment passed with the unanimous consent of all members of the committee demonstrates once again the positive and co-operative spirit in which this committee works.
This being the government's final opportunity to address the House on this matter, I would like to again praise the work done by the member for Mississauga South who proposed a Private Member's bill which identified and sought to remedy an anomaly in the Criminal Records Act. I commend my hon. friend for the time and effort he put into preparing his Private Member's bill C-238, for our consideration, and for his ongoing interest in this government initiative.
You are already aware of the proposed changes and I do not intend to spend too much time today going over ground we are all familiar with. However, I would like to address some important points.
As parliamentarians, we have all responded to requests from Canadians to help expedite the granting of a pardon.
It is usually for someone who has been living in the community without criminal activity for many years and who needs a pardon for work or for another personal reason.

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
We have all been frustrated that it can take up to a year and a half for the pardon to be granted, even in the most straighforward and deserving of cases.
Why, we ask, does it take as long to investigate and decide on a pardon for a law-abiding citizen with an old record for a minor offence, as it does to investigate and determine if a pardon should be given to a person with a record for serious crimes of violence. This does not make any sense.
We have also been frustrated to learn that a person who has been granted a discharge in court and thereby has not been convicted of an offence must apply for a pardon to have the fact of the discharge removed from his record at a later date.
Why should a person who has never been convicted of an offence be put to the trouble and expense of applying for a pardon if the courts have granted a discharge? This makes no sense, particularly since the pardon has invariably been granted.
I would now like to briefly address concerns about good conduct raised by the hon. member for Brant. The government has considered the cases of those convicted of summary or less serious offences. The current system requires a period of crime-free behaviour in the community before being eligible to apply for a pardon. As well, there is a provision for a community investigation of good conduct.
We have chosen to increase the waiting period to three years from two for summary convictions but to require only that the ex-offender be without conviction during this period to indicate a crime-free lifestyle. There will no longer be the requirement that a decision be based on a judgement of good conduct in addition to the criteria of a conviction-free waiting period.
It should be noted that fewer than 100 pardon applications per year are denied. Of those denied following an investigation of good conduct, most were for people with more serious records for indictable offences. It is these offences on which the government has chosen to concentrate its investigative and decision-making resources.
Madam Speaker, I do not want to take much more of your time. I would like to add that I think the changes which are before us clearly follow a middle ground between various proposals which have been previously discussed. I believe that the changes respond effectively to the various problems in the current system.
All members of Parliament will no doubt find that the proposed changes to the Criminal Records Act are intended to create a more effective pardon system, to improve service to increasing numbers of eligible ex-offenders, to achieve cost savings and reduce delays in the granting of pardons.

The amendments will assist the government to achieve these goals while protecting the integrity of the system and continuing to provide protection for the Canadian public from offenders who have chosen to continue their criminal lifestyle.

That was the goal which the government had in mind as it drafted these changes and I believe that is the goal that we will all achieve when these changes become law.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to rise to debate Bill C-71, which deals with amendments to the Criminal Records Act.
I want to indicate at the outset that the Liberal caucus fully supports all of the amendments. It is not a begrudging "Yeah, we support it but it is sort of a weak bill". The Liberal caucus fully supports the amendments and they have been fully discussed in committee. They have been dealt with quite well by the Standing Committee on Justice and Solicitor General.
I do want to put on the record a number of remarks to clarify some issues for the public, for my constituents and for the record because I believe that this matter will have to be addressed again in the future as the judicial system evolves.
Perhaps most members come into contact with what is known as the Criminal Records Act when constituents have difficulty accessing the pardon mechanism and encounter delays or other administrative obstructions. That is how most MPs come into contact with it, and I have noticed a bit of an increase in the number of complaints by constituents.
June 11, 1992

I suppose it does not speak so well of the past, in that people who have criminal records must come forward and acknowledge the fact that they have these records, but it does augur well for the future in that many more individuals are able to come forward and put an unfortunate part of their past behind them and approach the future fresh with a new start. That augurs well for the individual and for the community.
The changes that have been proposed and are in the process of being adopted here were all needed. There are five key areas of change. The first is a totally new process being adopted within the National Parole Board that will actually grant the pardon instrument.
Previously the pardon instrument was granted by a special committee of the cabinet. Given the great increase in applications over the last few years-this bill has been around since 1970-this has created a bottleneck at the cabinet level because all the National Parole Board did was make recommendations for pardons.
You had the circumstance in which cabinet ministers were simply provided with lots of paper. They probably did not have a chance to look at it in too much detail and they probably accepted in most cases the recommendations of the National Parole Board. It created a bottleneck. That meant that sometimes we were ending up with one and two-year delays and in some cases maybe longer in a decision on whether a pardon should be granted.
That bottle-neck now is removed because those who used to recommend the pardon are now going to be in a position to actually grant it. That is a good thing.
The second item is that the act provides for revocation of pardons where a subsequent offence is committed. This was not as clearly provided for in the existing act and most Canadians would find that very fair and most appropriate when a person is pardoned of an offence and subsequently reoffends. It would not be appropriate for that individual to say, "I have no criminal record because I was pardoned and you must deal with me as a first offender". The act speaks very clearly on that.
Government Orders
The third area is that the waiting period for the non-indictable, less serious offences that were dealt with summarily in the court system, is extended by one year, from two years to three years. That provides a better window for the administrators, the National Parole Board, to review the circumstances and perhaps to be more certain about the appropriateness of the pardon application.
In return for that, the process has been expedited, as we have already mentioned, so that it should not take two years to have the application dealt with.
The fourth item I have always regarded as the area that needed reform first. It was bizarre that this circumstance actually came into existence. In the Criminal Code there is a provision for granting to an offender a discharge for the offence, conditional or absolute.
The code states very clearly that when a discharge is granted, conditional or absolute, the offender is deemed not to have been convicted of the offence. That makes sense to me. In the process that developed into the Criminal Records Act that statute reversed the whole process and stated that even though you were deemed never to have been convicted of an offence, this act deemed you to have been convicted of the offence and so your criminal record was there.
That was bizarre. It meant that all of these people who had committed relatively minor offences, because the court does not give discharges for serious offences, for subsequent offenders and for multiple offenders, had this circumstance in which they were drawn back into the administration. They were brought back in to apply for pardons when the court and the judge had already made a decision that the person should not have a criminal record.
Foolishly in a bizarre twist, that was creating extra work for the National Parole Board and the special committee of cabinet. I do not know how the system evolved. I know that the Criminal Records Act was passed in 1970. At about the same time the provisions for conditional discharges and absolute discharges were passed and implemented. Somewhere in the system the right hand did not know what the left hand was doing. The government of the day let it evolve to the point at which now, some 20 years later, it is undoing that unfortunate administrative overlap.
That is a good thing. We have a conditional or an absolute discharge at the time of conviction within one or three years depending on whether it is an absolute or conditional discharge and automatically the criminal records are removed.

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
I guess I should not call it the criminal record. The act specifically refers to the record of the discharge being removed because, as I will point out later, there are still some problems in the field dealing with the definition of criminal record.
The fifth area is that the act envisages special guidelines now to assist the board and the public in developing criteria in relation to special kinds of offences when maybe we should be looking more closely at the process of pardons. Here we are talking about serious offences of violence and certain types of sexual offences.
It may well be that our society should be looking closely at the whole process by which we pardon individuals who may find themselves locked into patterns of conduct that are unsociable and it may be that we should look at that more closely.
The act envisages that and requires those criteria to be developed.
In the end after those five changes and some more minor changes we have a much more effective administration of the process of applications for pardons. That is better for individuals and for the community.
We also have a more expeditious disposition so that when an individual has reached the point in his or her life that time has passed, whether it be three years, five years, or whatever other period is appropriate, when they feel they are entitled to the "pardon", they can come forward and have it disposed of within a reasonable period of time so that they can get on with the rest of their lives.
If they need a pardon to apply for a job, a certain type of job, a career change, go to school, whatever entitlement or advancement they are looking for, hopefully they will see that the pardon can be there and they can move on and leave the past behind.
For the sake of the record, and not to detract from our indication of support for these amendments, I want to address some areas in the existing act that remain in my view unaddressed. In some way I want to be critical of those who drafted the law some 22 years ago because they made some errors which are visited upon this generation two generations later.
The act is called the Criminal Records Act. In point of fact, this act does not even deal with criminal records. It
does not even try. It does not even use the concept of criminal records. It is an act about pardons. It is a statute that deals with pardons.
I should pause here to say that the act does not even define what a pardon is. That is a problem for the technocrats, the lawyers. I will leave that one.
I want to go back to this criminal record issue. Because the title contains the words criminal record, people tend to think in terms of criminal records, but the act does not tiy to deal with criminal records.
It does not even tiy to deal with the specific item called a record of conviction. That is the document that is created when an individual is convicted of an offence under the Criminal Code. That is called a record of conviction and it is a real piece of paper in a file and copies of it are forwarded to the appropriate filing locations in the country. Ultimately outside the original court files it ends up with the Canadian police information system, which we call CPIC.
It is regrettable that this act which tries to deal with this field of all of the records, the records of conviction, the records of the evidence, the letters going back and forth, the record of decisions by the prosecuting attorney, the submissions by the defence counsel, the records in the press-all of that-does not deal with it. It just leaves it sitting there and that is a bit of a problem which we will ultimately want to address.
Here are some of the reasons. The act does not deal with destruction of the criminal records. The act says you get a pardon. The layman out there and the MP right here do not really understand what that means because the act really is not clear. The act does not define pardon, but it tries to show the effect. It states what the effect of a pardon is without defining what the pardon is. One of those is that "in the case of any pardon the conviction in respect of which the pardon is granted or issued should no longer reflect adversely on the applicant's character". The verb here is should-should no longer reflect.
The individual who applies for a pardon really expects that the conviction will not or may not or cannot-not should not-affect adversely on the applicant's character.
June 11, 1992

That remains unaddressed by this. When the pardon is given you would expect something to happen to all of the records of conviction and criminal records but nothing happens. This bill does not try to do anything and the system does not either. All the records that were in the courthouse, all the records that were with the police, all the records that were in the media and all that were sent out remain exactly where they were. There is no destruction of any of the records. The record of conviction is still out there; it is still in the police files, still in the court files, and it is still with CPIC.
What happens is that the federal government requires that CPIC delete the record of conviction, delete the notation of the criminal conviction from the CPIC record. That is really all that happens. That only happens in this great Canadian computer data base. It does not happen in the province. The province does not change any of its records. Do not forget that the individual was convicted in a provincial court. The province and the court still have all the records and the police still have all their records; no changes in their computer system.
One of the other things that is still unaddressed is that when Canadian authorities convey the record of conviction or a notation of the conviction to American authorities-which they sometimes do to the border patrol, the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service and the FBI-the policing authorities, border services and the customs services exchange this data on their memoranda of understanding which this government enters into. Those notations are given to our American friends and they give us theirs also. There is no mechanism to require the Americans to delete the notations from their records. This bill does not provide for it, there are no regulations to provide for it. That is unfortunate because most Canadians would think that when they get the pardon it is a clean slate. All they get is a deletion of a computer record on CPIC. All those other records I have just mentioned remain there, including the American records.
We are told that the Canadian authorities do not have the ability to force the Americans to delete the record. That is nonsense. We have memoranda of understanding and there is no reason why the memoranda of understanding cannot be amended to require all the parties to
Government Orders
delete the records when the pardon is given under Canadian law.
I want to point out that this act does not affect any of the records of conviction in private hands such as insurance companies, bonding companies. All of that is still out there.
All of this is for another day when we can attempt here in Parliament, and hopefully we can do it as well as we have worked with and expedited this bill, to address in a more comprehensive fashion, with more definition and more certainty, all the areas of these criminal records.

Madam Speaker, I too wish to enter the debate at third reading of Bill C-71, an act to amend the Criminal Records Act and other acts in consequence thereof. As the previous speaker mentioned in considerable detail the act in a way is a misnomer. I am not saying that it misleads but it really is a misnomer.
However, despite its shortcomings my party is pleased to support Bill C-71 because it makes an honest effort at updating an act that goes back to 1970 and at least brings it into the 1990s, perhaps not as a completely as we would have liked but it does improve the present situation with respect to that act.
The government has gone some way in improving the whole pardon system. I appreciate what it has done and I thank the government for that. However, we have some concerns with this bill. The first one is that nowhere in this bill is there a definition of criminal records. We have searched the revised Statutes of Canada and have been told that nowhere is there any definition of "criminal record". Therefore, we are really talking about something that we have not clearly defined and we are amending a process of something we have not defined. We do not know whether we are in fact amending the Criminal Records Act because we do not know what criminal records are.
As the previous speaker pointed out there are records of conviction. However, there are also all kinds of other criminal records relating to a specific crime and the perpetrator of that crime that are held by the police that investigated the crime, by the court that convicted, by the newspapers that covered the trial and by the various libraries that keep those records. Probably carrying this

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
to its extreme, there is the memory of those who were involved in one way or another with that crime.
One could argue that it is virtually impossible to completely expunge the entire record of a criminal act. Perhaps that too is for another day.
I still think that sometime in the near future a government is going to have to come to grips with that anomaly. It is one thing to purge the record of criminal conviction from one computer bank, CPIC that is administered by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. It is another thing to entirely eliminate one's criminal record after a pardon has been granted. Therein lies the anomaly. While the person receives the pardon that person still has a criminal record, even though the record of conviction has been removed from the central data bank at the RCMP headquarters here in Ottawa.
We have other concerns as well. I mentioned the lack of definition of a criminal record. I am also still not satisfied that we know what good conduct is. I know the member has gone a long way in her remarks in defining good conduct by saying that good conduct is an absence of criminality. That is what the officials said at our committee hearings. I am satisfied that is one definition, but I think it is a very limited one.
If the Parole Board restricts its interpretation of good conduct to that narrow interpretation then I am satisfied. If the person who applies for a pardon has not committed another offence, has not been charged and convicted of an offence, then I would say the person should be granted the pardon, all other circumstances being equal.
However, if good conduct has something to do with one's behaviour in society, if it is a community-based assessment, then I am not so certain.
I may have a neighbour who lives beside me who has not committed a criminal offence since the original crime. Perhaps he committed it as a teenager in this hypothetical case. I am asked whether I think my next door neighbour has displayed good conduct. On Sunday morning in the summertime when we want to sit out in our backyard and have a quiet cup of coffee he decides to turn on his radio full blast and play rock music. I would say that is not good conduct. I do not like it and go and tell him to turn it down or turn it off. That might
somehow influence my assessment of that person's conduct.
It could be some narrow religious or moral interpretation of his or her behaviour, about which I should not have any concern because it is none of my business. I might say to somebody investigating that he or she is doing this or doing that and I do not think that is right because it is contrary to the Judaeo-Christian sense of morality. I hope it is not given that broad an interpretation.
If the Parole Board sticks to the one important criterion, an absence of criminal behaviour, then I would say that good conduct is acceptable from our point of view. I hope this will be the restrictive approach that the Parole Board adheres to.
The other point with which I still have some concern, as do some of my constituents-and no doubt I speak for virtually every member in this House-is the situation in which a young lad commits a relatively minor offence in his teens. We will say it is shoplifting. We have all heard the story. It is the same right across the country.
He grows older and he matures. He applies for and gets a job as a truck driver. On his first trip across the border he is stopped. They punch his name into the computer and out comes a criminal record. He is prohibited from crossing the border. He could be going across the border for strictly recreational purposes or for a holiday. He says: "Well, good heavens, I was granted a pardon three years ago for this". However, that does not matter because it is still in the computer.
I will go over in some detail what can still happen, even with this bill that greatly improves the Criminal Records Act. Let us suppose that John Q. Public, a Canadian citizen, gets convicted of a Criminal Code offence on January 1, 1985. I am using this as a hypothetical case. He serves two years in jail with no probation. On January 1, 1987 his sentence officially ends. He must wait five years before applying for a pardon. In June 1989 he wants to go to the United States. At the border his record is called up on the U.S. immigration computer because it is linked to the Canadian information banks because of the reciprocal agreement we have, a memorandum of understanding, with the United States. He is denied entry. This information is now in the computer memory of U.S. immigration, not only his criminal record from Canada but the fact that he
June 11, 1992

was denied access to the United States. That is put in the computer at that time.
On January 1, 1992 he applies for a pardon. Within a few months, and this bill will fortunately hurry it up, he is granted that pardon. In May or June 1992 he tries to go to the U.S. again. They will have no record of his new pardon but will see the record of his 1987 conviction. He is denied entry again. If he has the pardon documents with him it is then up to the U.S. border immigration people or officials to decide. It has been my experience that most of the time they still refuse entry.
The point is that if this person had been granted the pardon and between the time of his conviction and the time that he got the pardon had not tried to enter the United States then the information that would come up on the screen at the U.S. border would include the pardon. The pardon would be there. Then he would probably be allowed in. If he tried to enter the United States after he was convicted and came out of jail and before a pardon was granted and then subsequently tried to enter the United States after a pardon had been granted he would be stopped.
That is the point I am getting at, and it is still a problem. I do not know whether this bill could have dealt with it anyway. I do not think it could have.
I hope that government officials in the Solicitor General's office will meet with their counterparts in the United States to try to get that anomaly worked out. A pardon is a pardon. I do not think a person should be penalized for attempting to enter the United States before his pardon has come through rather than trying to enter the United States after his pardon has come through.
There are two distinctly different records kept in that U.S. computer at the border. That is the point that must be addressed if we are going to be equitable and fair to the people who are granted pardons. I know we cannot force the United States to do anything in this regard. However, I am certain that by getting together a reciprocal agreement can be worked out. After all, this works in our favour too. We do not want their criminal elements coming into Canada and they do not want our criminal elements going to the United States.
Government Orders
When a pardon is granted-and in the overwhelming majority of cases pardons are granted for relatively minor offences, although I think they can be granted for all offences but possibly not capital. I am not sure about first-degree murder or capital offences.
Those are some of my concerns: the definition of criminal records itself, the definition of good conduct, and the problems that Canadian citizens who have been granted a pardon often experience when attempting to enter the United States.
We are supporting this bill. We do appreciate what the government has done. However, the fact still remains that we still have this situation in which a pardon is granted but the criminal record remains. The record of conviction is gone from the RCMP computer but it is in the files of the provincial police forces and municipal police forces, and private agencies such as bonding houses and insurance companies. That record is still there.
This bill is well intentioned in terms of employment, and one of the most common reasons for seeking a pardon is for employment purposes. When this bill goes through the federal government cannot, and I think even at the present time, demand to know whether a person has been pardoned. It can ask whether they have a criminal record and if they have been pardoned they are perfectly within their rights to say, in fact they should: "No, I don't have a criminal record". If they have committed one offence and have been pardoned for it the assumption is that the record is gone. Therefore they can say: "No, I don't have a criminal record".
I am still very concerned about some components of the private sector. A small company may ask: "Have you got a criminal record?" It has checked a bonding company and knows that the person was convicted of shoplifting when they were 17 and pardoned. There is still a record there, and they do not get the job. The company will not say that is the reason they did not get the job but it still works against people.
Unfortunately, that means that a relatively minor crime, and I think shoplifting at the age of 15 or 16 or younger is a petty offence, will dog the person for the rest of his life even with this well-intentioned piece of legislation. I do not know how to deal with it.
June 11, 1992

Government Orders
I think we can legislate and order those other groups and organizations to purge the criminal record, not just the record of conviction but the criminal record itself, from their files so that it cannot be used for any reason. Perhaps I will narrow that down and say that it cannot be used for crossing the border and cannot be used for employment purposes, and there are no doubt several others.
I know that there are times when we will still want a record of that conviction somewhere because that person could be suspected of committing another offence later in life or a few years later.
Obviously the investigative authorities and peace officers would want to have some source to which they could go to verify fingerprints, pictures or behavioural patterns.
Certainly for employment purposes and for travel purposes, I think the entire record should be purged and not just the record of conviction but the criminal file itself.
That is all I wish to say about Bill C-71. We support it, and I presume it will be passed today at third reading and go to the other place.

The House resumed from May 13, 1992, consideration of Bill C-7, an Act respecting the status of the artist and professional relations between artists and producers in Canada, as reported with amendments) by the Standing Committee on Communications and Culture.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: The question is now on Motions Nos. 1 and 2.

Motion No. 1.
That Bill C-7 be amended in Clause 3
(a) by striking out line 16 at page 2 and substituting the following therefor:
"nomic interests of their members;";
(b) by striking out line 20 at page 2 and substituting the following therefor:
"other questions concerning them, and
(d) the right of artists to equity through programming and employment opportunities which serve the needs and interests of Canadian men, women, and children, the linguistic duality and multicultural and multiracial nature of Canadian society and the special place of aboriginal peoples within that society."
Motion No. 2
That Bill C-7 be amended in Clause 3
(a)	by striking out line 16 at page 2 and substituting the following therefor:
"nomic interests of their members;";
(b)	by striking out line 20 and page 2 and substituting the following therefor:
"other questions concerning them; and
(d) the right of artists to the equal protection and equal benefit of the law without discrimination and, in particular, without discrimination based on race, national or ethnic origin, colour, religion, sex, age, sexual orientation or mental or physical disability."
She said: Madam Speaker, first of all may I say it is a pleasure to finally rise to this bill and address the issue of the status of the artist in Canada. It is an issue that we have been trying to address for a long, long time.
The first amendment deals with the non-discrimination clause in the status of artist legislation to be found in the general principles and policy statement section of the bill. The principle behind this amendment is really to bring a sense of clarity and a proclamation of policy and directives that I believe all of us in this country wish to support and see brought into being.
June 11, 1992

In this particular amendment we are talking about the right of the artist to equity through programming and employment opportunities which serve the needs and interests of Canadian people. The first amendment deals, I believe, with the right of artists through programming and employment opportunities which serve the needs and interests of Canadian women and children, the linguistic duality and multicultural and multiracial nature of Canadian society and the special place of aboriginal peoples within that society.
It is really vital that we ensure that Canadians of different cultures are seen as well as employed. The principle that we are placing before this House in this particular amendment is that it is not good enough just to have employment equity as a principle and that we would have people of all races, colours, languages and religions before us. We have to make a concerted effort to ensure that people of colour, people of different ethnic backgrounds are present and can be heard by all people.
It is in seeing the diversity of Canada on the screen, it is in hearing the different voices and the different accents, it is in an appreciation of this incredible diversity that is the reality of the Canadian picture. In fact, it is something that we have been talking about really through this whole constitutional debate, the debate about who we are as a people and what we are as a people. If the what we are as people and who we are as a people is fundamentally the differences that make the greatness of this country then you have to have those people involved, in front of the scene, behind the scene, helping us select the news and in helping us to understand the different messages that are coming because there are cultural differences. It is through these cultural differences and in the eyes and voices of these people that we are able to appreciate and understand not only local, regional, provincial and national news, but also the international milieu.
This amendment is similar to a provision that you can find in the Broadcasting Act. When the Canadian Actors Equity came before the committee they told us that we need to be able to ensure that, as an example, aboriginal cultures are not left to wither away and die not only because it would be tantamount to intellectual genocide for those who spring from those cultures but because those who do not must be able to have a knowledge and an understanding of it.
The more you see people, whether it is our aboriginal people who we are becoming more and more aware of, more and more sensitive to and have a greater and
Government Orders
greater curiosity about their life and and their lifestyle, or it is the newly arrived Canadians be they from South America, Asia, East Timor, the islands in the Caribbean or in the Pacific, all these people come to us with a different approach and a different lifestyle. It is through exposure to these people that we will have a better understanding of our society.
Actors Equity went on to say: "We need to be able to ensure that those who came here as immigrants from different countries have access to Canada's cultural life and the opportunity to participate in it".
A 1989 study for the Department of Communications by Eko's Research found that for affiliated visual and literary artists women on average earned 63 per cent of the artistic income of men and that this is even worse for unaffiliated female visual artists who learn less than half; they earn 46 per cent of the average incomes earned by their male counterparts. Unaffiliated female literary artists earn 57 per cent of the average incomes of their male counterparts.
I would suggest that while I proposed this amendment, there is a strong sense that when you are telling a story, when you are selecting a history, when you are picking the news that should be told, people must be in the news room. They must be there and available to be talked with to enable the information to flow.
The Canadian Conference of the Arts and ACTRA expressed their support for this particular amendment.
We have had an awful lot of discussion around the term "cultural appropriation". If we do not want to be concerned about cultural appropriation I would suggest we need to have the kind of people who will help keep around us this mix that is Canada. People must be around, be near us, in order for us to be able to collaborate.
There is some question as to whether or not this is relevant and necessary given the nature of other legislation we have had in the House. It is my sense we would be moving in the right direction if we would ensure employment equity that would bring us to the point of ensuring artists of these different backgrounds, both men and women, are seen as well as employed was put into place in this particular bill.
As the Speaker, you have seen fit to group two amendments. The first one is on employment equity where I sincerely hope there will be a positive move on the part of the minister to consider this. It does not have a kind of legislative action; it has a hope and direction in that it falls under the policy statement. It does not fall

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
under an action statement. It is part of the general principles and policy statement of the bill.
Similarly the second amendment I was dealing with in clause 3 directs itself to the question of the clause of non-discrimination. It is the clause that, as you probably recognize in section 15 of the Canadian Charter of Rights, ensures legal equality without discrimination.
Some of the characteristics have been regarded traditionally as objectionable grounds of discrimination and they are listed in the clause. We all know them pretty well: race, national and ethnic origin, colour, religion, age, sex, mental or physical disability. This list is by no means exhaustive. One area of serious omission is the protection against discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.
When the Equality for All task force brought forward a recommendation in 1985, it was to the effect that the Canadian Human Rights Act be amended to add sexual orientation as a prohibited grounds of discrimination. I think any piece of legislation, until such time as this government chooses to make the proper amendment to the Canadian Human Rights Act, has to be noted in these provisions where they are of general principle. The general principle and the general policy is well suited to a policy statement that addresses the question of sexual orientation as a prohibited ground of discrimination.
The government responded in 1986 that it would act but it is now six years later. Nothing has happened, and there has been no action.
I believe all members of this House will recall when the Prime Minister of Canada spoke to the issue of sexual discrimination and sexual orientation. He said in regard to the question in the future, which refers to the Human Rights Act, on April 27, 1992, page 9714 that Canadians should be judged on their merit, not on their sexual orientation. He adds:
For my part I believe anything that discriminates against anyone's rights in any way, any discrimination of any kind, is unacceptable in a pluralistic society such as ours.
The Minister of Justice and others are examining these matters very carefully to see what they can do to advance the cause of elimination of discrimination in Canada.
I would ask the minister to give very serious consideration to both these amendments. I would hope he would
find favour with the non-discrimination clause and the equity for artists through employment and programming, both clauses in section 3 of the policy statement of the status of artist legislation.

Madam Speaker, first of all perhaps I could express my thanks to the hon. member for Mount Royal for moving these amendments and giving the House the opportunity to speak to two very important matters.
I would also like to express a word of thanks, which I will repeat a little bit later when we are speaking on third reading, to members on all sides of the House who belonged to the committee for the spirit of collaboration and co-operation that has been shown throughout the consideration of Bill C-7. It has been truly remarkable. It demonstrates that it is possible to build a partnership that stretches between parties and which recognizes the important public interest which is at stake.
The degree of collaboration we have seen today and the amount of co-operation has really been something which has been very encouraging to me.
It is with regret that I have to indicate to the hon. member that the government cannot support the two motions which she proposes today, notwithstanding the fact that the gist of the motions, the substance of them, attempts to move the bill in the direction which we would like to see things going in Canada, all of us, I believe.
All of us are in favour of employment equity. As well all of us are in favour of anything that can strike down discrimination in Canada. Discrimination by its very nature is abhorrent to any of us. In my view the only thing it is acceptable to hate is hatred itself.
The fact that all too many Canadians find themselves discriminated against on the basis of irrelevant criteria is simply unacceptable in 1992. As we look at amendments to human rights legislation we have to do everything we can to ensure that Canadians are judged on their merits and what they can contribute as individuals and not on the basis of irrelevant criteria.
It has to be our goal in Canada's 125th anniversary year to promote a spirit of respect for one another and respect for humanity.
June 11, 1992

I realize that the spirit in which the hon. member poses these amendments is very much consistent with that.
My concerns about the motions are the following. As the hon. member will know Parliament adopted the Employment Equity Act which came into force on August 13,1986 and which covers people employed by an employer that hires 100 or more employees.
Trying to extend federal jurisdiction and private contracts with independent contractors would not be appropriate, nor in some cases would it be legally feasible. One has to remain mindful of our limited jurisdiction in this area.
Further, it is hard to see how the tribunal could force a producer to contract according to equity while selection of artists is usually based upon, for example, a scenario which dictates the type of performer required or musical partition which requires specific talents. It would be very hard to understand how this would work.
As drafted, the amendment deals with employees and would therefore not apply to Part II of the bill. Since Part I is not binding on Her Majesty, it is not clear who this would be aimed at or who it would be binding upon.
Certainly if we want to see amendments made, if we want to see broadening in terms of employment equity, the appropriate place for us to do that would be in amending the Employment Equity Act and it should be in the context of that act that we raise our concerns.
Finally the charter protects to some extent Canadians with respect to their right to work. Recently the Chief Justices of the Supreme Court of Canada stated that the court felt that the charter had been under-utilized with respect to economic rights and one should expect some judicial evolution on that matter in the coming years.
With regard to Motion No. 2, again I repeat and I support enthusiastically the comments that were quoted from the Prime Minister by the hon. member earlier, that discrimination in Canada is simply unacceptable.
The purpose of the proposed amendment is to ensure that artists are not discriminated against on the basis of
Government Orders
race, national or ethnic origin, colour, religion, sex, age, sexual orientation, or mental or physical disability.
For the most part it does not appear that this amendment is necessary because with the exception of discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, all of the criteria enumerated in the motion are covered by the Charter of Rights and Freedoms already which supersedes this legislation.
The bill on the status of the artist is not the appropriate venue to introduce protection against discrimination based on sexual orientation in one area which is not included in this other legislation as it should clearly be done in the larger context such as in human rights legislation.
Let me simply indicate with regard to employment equity that it certainly is the policy of the Government of Canada that it should be our goal to ensure that both in its portrayal of Canada and in terms of employment opportunities which are offered to Canadians the media, including the arts in Canada, should do everything they can to be as representative of the Canadian population as possible.
That is the goal which is shared by members on all sides of this House. It is one which we are all committed to work to try to achieve. It is unfortunate that in this particular case, it would not be appropriate to include these motions in the legislation. We will be forced to vote against them if we come to that point.
But I do want to indicate with great sincerity to my hon. friend from Mount Royal that I understand the direction in which she would like to go. I am certainly supportive of that.

that Bill C-254, an act respecting interprovincial livestock trade, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Natural Resources envelope.
He said: Madam Speaker, this bill was drafted three years ago because of shortfalls in the existing Bankruptcy Act.
It is a coincidence that it has been chosen for debate at the same time as the members of this House have been debating the current Bill C-22 which also attempts to amend the Bankruptcy Act.
If producers do in fact receive protection from "inventory and accounts receivables and cash resulting therefrom" which is one of the amendments that has been proposed for Bill C-22, then there will be no need for the type of trust fund that this private member's bill would create.
Let me give a quick review. This legislation seeks to settle the problem of security for producers who sell livestock outside their own province. Most of the provinces have legislation built into their legal systems which sets up funds to avoid problems for livestock delivered to packing houses within the province. Livestock that is sold across provincial boundaries escapes that legislative coverage because it is federal legislation under the British North America Act. The amendments that we are proposing here today would attempt to provide similar protection to those producers who sell across the provincial border.
The bill attempts to set up a trust fund to which abattoirs and slaughterhouses purchasing livestock and poultry from farmers outside of the province would contribute. In the event of the bankruptcy of those processing firms, the producers would not be left wanting their money.
What prompted this legislation in part, as is often the case, was pressure and lobbying from affected producer groups. Experiences that I recall, growing up in a rural community, also influenced introducing this legislation.
I can recall when I was in my teens, one of my neighbours whose wife was a postmistress at the time decided to dispose of his tiny livestock herd. There were 18 head. They went from Saskatchewan to a plant in Winnipeg. In the process, a cheque was paid when they left the farm. The cheque bounced. The plant that purchased the livestock had declared bankruptcy. It was many months before the farmer received about 10 or 15 cents on the dollar for the disposal of his small herd.
A lot of producers, when they deliver product to the plant, are delivering one year's supply of livestock at that time, depending on the kind of production they are engaged in. Those who produce on their own farm for fattening and finishing often will send the whole year's production to the plant at one time. If that happens to coincide with the time when the plant goes bankrupt, they can be left with the loss of a whole year's work and absolutely no income, even though they still have all the bills to pay.
Ordinary suppliers to plants that might declare bankruptcy are never caught in that kind of situation because their billings take place weekly or monthly and so they do not get caught with a whole year's production on the line.
The model for this legislation is the U.S. Packers and Stockyard Act which is administered by the packers and stockyards administration of the United States Department of Agriculture. The trust fund which was started in 1968 covers all cattle transactions and has been expanded to include poultry and most perishable agricultural produce.
I understand that American legislators are now drafting protection for the dairy sector. In fiscal year 1989 the trust paid out $1.2 million to producers in the U.S. The figures for 1990 and 1991 are $4.7 million and $4.2 million respectively. Therefore, without this kind of fund and protection for producers, individual livestock growers would have been left carrying this bill and it would have effectively forced many of them into receivership or bankruptcy along with the processor to whom they had sold.
Many of the provinces in this country, as I have said, have set up similar types of protection to provide a fund for producer financed insurance to compensate livestock
June 11, 1992

producers against such losses. But these do not apply to livestock that moves across a provincial border because, as we all know, when we put agricultural trade across a provincial border it comes under federal jurisdiction and the responsibility of the federal government. Provincial jurisdiction does not apply. While the provinces have been more aware of this problem over time than the federal government, the provinces have been unable to act fully because of the reality of quite a lot of the trade in livestock going across borders.
In my province of Saskatchewan, for instance, for years and years most of the livestock processing occurred outside the province. That has turned around in the last couple of decades, but there is still a considerable amount of beef and pork that goes outside of the province for slaughter.
The plans that have been in effect in Canada work under different schemes. The Ontario financial protection plan is one that recognizes claims if the sale is deemed to take place in Ontario. It has a couple of wrinkles that provide for licensed dealers outside of the province. When we inquired there was one in Manitoba, one in Saskatchewan and several located in New York and Michigan. Licensed dealers purchasing livestock outside of Ontario for slaughter in Ontario would in those few cases be protected by the Ontario financial protection plan.
This legislation, or if the House and the Senate adopt the amendment to Bill C-22 of which I spoke earlier and which would make this unnecessary, would provide the kind of protection in interprovincial trade to which Canadian producers are entitled. I would urge the House to support the thought behind this legislation. This has not been deemed to be a votable motion.
When we are dealing with Bill C-22 and when the Senate is finished with Bill C-22, I hope the joint concerns of this House will be such that Bill C-22 will contain an adequate amendment to the bankruptcy laws which will protect producers of livestock and other farm products that move across provincial borders for processing so that in the event the processor goes bankrupt those farmers will receive their money.
Private Members' Business

speakeroldname: Mr. Murray Cardiff (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Agriculture):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Agriculture
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak on second reading of Bill C-254.
The issue of suppliers being unpaid after a buyer has failed financially has been a longstanding and very difficult problem not only for livestock producers but for business people throughout Canadian industry as well.
In the agricultural sector various producer organizations have been involved in trying to find solutions to this problem for quite some time. For example, the Canadian Cattlemen's Association has suggested that a program like the United States Packers and Stockyards Act be established.
Under this act meat packers must hold all inventories, accounts receivable and cash in a deemed trust until full payment has been received by any unpaid sellers of livestock. But in Canada such comprehensive legislation would be beyond the constitutional power of the federal government and in any case would address the difficulties of only one sector of the Canadian industry.
Clearly a much broader approach to the problem of unpaid suppliers is needed. For that reason in June 1991 the government introduced Bill C-22, amendments to the Bankruptcy Act.
At present suppliers who are unpaid at the time of a buyer's bankruptcy have the status of ordinary, unsecured creditors. The proposed amendments would add to the act the right of suppliers to repossess goods for which they have not been paid in cases of either bankruptcy or receivership. This right would be subject to the conditions that the goods are both identifiable and in the same state as delivered.
For unpaid farmers and fishermen whose products are often not identifiable after delivery or are quickly reprocessed, these conditions limit the usefulness of the proposed section.
Therefore an additional amendment to the act introduced under Bill C-22 on May 5 of this year would provide special protection for these producers. This amendment provides unpaid farmers or fishermen with a priority claim on the inventory of the purchaser for the full value of the goods they have supplied.

Private Members' Business
Where a farmer or fisherman sells and delivers products within 15 days before the purchaser becomes bankrupt or goes into receivership, the farmer or fisherman has 30 days to file a claim on any unpaid amount. That claim would be secured by a charge on all of the purchaser's inventory and it would rank above all other claims except those of other unpaid suppliers.
Clearly this amendment which was proposed by the hon. Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs in response to a recommendation of the Standing Committee on Consumer and Corporate Affairs would go a long way toward improving protection for fishermen and for all agricultural producers.
On the other hand, Bill C-254 in terms of what we wanted to do is extremely limited in scope and would give enhanced protection to livestock producers only on interprovincial sales and only on sales to corporate slaughterhouses. In such cases the company would be deemed to hold any unpaid portion of the sale price in trust on behalf of the producer.
Bill C-254 does not provide a time period after which the trust lapses. Since unpaid supplier protection would be provided under all circumstances, not just bankruptcy, the bill could conflict with existing provincial unpaid supplier legislation made under property and civil rights authority.
As well, because Bill C-254 does not allow for provincial co-operation and participation, as does the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act for instance, the legislation would be very difficult to implement.
I appreciate the remarks of my hon. colleague and recognize as well that when this bill is finally passed hopefully it will deal with his concerns as well. When he says that this bill has been on the Order Paper for close to three years, that is a long time and a lot of things have changed in that period of time.
The Standing Committee on Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Government Operations completed its clause-by-clause examination of Bill C-22 on May 13, accepting the bill as amended including a special right for farmers and fishermen. When the bill is passed into law it will be closely monitored to determine whether fine-tuning is required in the future. In fact Bill C-22 requires that the amended Bankruptcy Act be reviewed by a parliamentary committee three years after coming into force.
In the interim the amendment to the act to provide unpaid farmers and fishermen with a priority claim on inventory represents a very real gain. At present unpaid farmers are unsecured creditors. With the enactment of Bill C-22 they would be ahead of the secured creditors, which we think would be a great benefit to agricultural producers.

Mr. Speaker, I am glad to have a chance to say a few words about the Bill C-254 of the hon. member for Mackenzie. This bill deals with a problem that many agricultural producers face from time to time when they ship livestock to a packing company, a grower or a buyer outside their own provinces. The individual goes broke. His cheque is no good for the livestock that he has purchased. The farmer is left holding the bag with no benefits.
This bill seeks to deal with the situation where it is a no credit sale. The money would go into a fund which would ensure that the bill was paid. If the livestock or whatever produce was kept, the farmer would be paid.
I was interested in the words of the parliamentary secretary when he talked about Bill C-22. Most agricultural groups were not happy with the amendments made in Bill C-22 respecting bankruptcy legislation which was just passed this week. The parliamentary secretary said that the bill would be closely monitored, that there would be a review after three years and all the rest of it.
There has been an ongoing review for the last three or four months in which practically every farm organization made clear they did not want to wait three years for a review. They did not want to worry about monitoring. They just wanted the bill amended as it should be.
The hon. member for Dartmouth brought forward amendments to the legislation which the government steadfastly refused to accept. The parliamentary secretary glossed over the super priority where a farmer or fisherman sells his produce to a company and the company goes broke. He would have a super priority on inventory, but on accounts receivable or other accounts payable it simply would not apply. If there is inventory in the company at the time it goes into bankruptcy then it works, but if it is a claim against accounts receivable it simply does not work.
June 11, 1992

For instance, James Goodhand of the Ontario Pork Association, Pork Ontario, wrote to members of the agriculture committee. In describing the deficiencies of Bill C-22, he said:
Specifically the proposed changes only allow livestock producers to be repaid from inventory on hand, which is inadequate. As with cattle, hogs are slaughtered and become which will remain in inventory for only a very short time.
If the inventory moves on there is nothing, but if there are accounts receivable for hundreds of thousands of dollars the farmer cannot claim that. The Tories know that, but they have their little deal all cooked up with the big companies. They are looking after them rather than looking after Ontario pork producers, beef producers or whatever other group.
Mr. Goodhand went on to say:
Hence, for this section to provide much needed help to the hog industry, it should be changed to allow claims to be secured by inventory plus accounts receivable and the cash resulting from the livestock originally purchased.
It is most unfortunate that the parliamentary secretary is trying to lead the House to believe that the agricultural industry is satisfied with Bill C-22. The bill of the hon. member for Mackenzie deals with a no cash sale. It would provide the greater protection that is required.
We turn to the Ontario Wheat Producers' Marketing Board and its comments with regard to Bill C-22 which is trying to alleviate some of the same problems outlined in Bill C-254.
In a letter from David Alderman, chairman of the Ontario Wheat Producers' Marketing Board, it is stated:
Section 81(2) of the bill was intended to protect suppliers of agricultural products from dealers who have become bankrupt or forced into receivership. It is the opinion of the Ontario Wheat Producers' Marketing Board that this protection has not been accomplished under the present form of this section.
Our board, in support with other commodity organizations, is proposing the attached appendix, Minor Redraft of Section 81(2), which will help protect producers of agricultural products.
It is the same as the super priority for agricultural producers and fishermen in the bankruptcy legislation. They would be able to make a claim not only against inventory which moves on in the very nature of the production of farm produce but for cash on hand or accounts receivable.
Government Orders
I do not think that the parliamentary secretary was being completely fair and above board with the House by trying to present Bill C-22 as being adequate to cover the problems raised by the hon. member for Mackenzie in his Bill C-254. Clearly none of the mainline agriculture groups are satisfied with the way that Bill C-22 dealt with this problem. Surely it is inadequate and will ultimately have to be changed.

Madam Speaker, I wish to say a few words in support of the amendments introduced by my friend and colleague, the critic from the Liberal Party.
Most of us would agree with the amendments. The first amendment talks about employment equity. As the mover pointed out, it lacks legislative action but it is a policy statement.
Basically it would come at the beginning of Bill C-7, an act respecting the status of artist. It would set forth an ideal with which no one in this House would disagree. The minister, when suggesting why the government would not be able to support the motion, felt that it should be left to other pieces of legislation.
I am certain the minister indicated in his brief remarks that he in no way disagreed with the aims of Motion No. 1 regarding employment equity. It is a policy statement.

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
It is a statement of ideals. It is a statement we all agree with. We will support that amendment.
The second amendment is to a clause on non-discrimination and is, as the minister correctly observed, in every way consistent with the charter of rights except that it does include one other important addition which the mover of the amendment included. That would disallow discrimination based on sexual orientation. Again we can make the argument that the battle really should be done in another way; changes to the Charter of Rights and Freedoms should be introduced and therefore discrimination based on sexual orientation would no longer be tolerated legally by our society, by our country.
One could make that argument, though the fact is that we might not move toward that as quickly as the Prime Minister has done with commitments in the past, the way that I think most members of this House would like to see us move.
Therefore, I support the mover of the amendment in attempting to include it in Bill C-7. In some ways, what better piece of legislation to pioneer this area than in the status of the artist legislation.
Artists in many ways are pioneers. They are at the forefront of social thought as well as artistic thought and cultural thought. To have that section included to ensure that there will not be discrimination based not just on race, religion, creed, et cetera, but also on sexual orientation as a reason not to allow for discrimination is an excellent suggestion.
Again, my party will be supporting that amendment.

Madam Speaker, both of these motions that are before the House seek to give to a committee of Parliament, with the responsibility for supervising this government's actions with regard to culture, the responsibility of reviewing after a period of time how this act functions.
These amendments initially were the initiative of my colleagues on the opposition side and I want to commend them for their initiative. All too infrequently we as members of Parliament put clauses in bills which trigger a review of Parliament's work and all too often what we find is that we pass legislation with the best of intent. It is very clear what each of us would like to see done with the legislation and yet we do not take the trouble years later to review the legislation and determine whether it is serving the purpose for which it was originally intended.
I gave the undertaking to my colleagues, the members of the committee at the time that we were before committee, that I would consult with artist organizations to seek their views as to whether they would agree to a review clause being in the bill. What we found was that this particular structure of allowing the bill to run for some seven years, then having the Minister of Communications prepare a report in conjunction with his colleague, the Minister of Labour, tabling that report in Parliament and sending it to the committees of the House of Commons and Senate charged with the responsibility for cultural affairs was the formulation which they felt would be the most appropriate.
I will not disguise the fact that there was some disquiet within the artistic community as to whether any review of the legislation might mean that hard fought games, which it had won in this legislation, could be lost as a result of review.

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
I can assure the artistic community that in this House, neither on the opposition side nor on the government side, is there any intention or interest in eroding any of the gains that have been won in this bill.
It is just the opposite. We want to ensure in this pioneering piece of legislation in which we have undertaken to make massive reforms to try to recognize the status of Canada's artists that we have done the job right and we have achieved what we were hoping to achieve. If amendments are subsequently needed to the bill at a later date which will ensure we can do the job better, those amendments will be made.
What we have done here is to say we will review Parliament's work, make a public report, give the opportunity for the committees of Parliament, which have the responsibility for reviewing artistic and cultural affairs, to ensure artists' needs are met as effectively as possible.
It is, I believe, a good amendment, one which is very positive. It could enable us to make improvements to the bill some years down the road. It in no way threatens the position or gains that have been won by the cultural communities in Canada. It does mean we as parliamentarians are accepting more fully our responsibility to examine our handiwork years from now to ensure we have done our job properly.
I would ask for support of Motion No. 4 which is moved by the government. I prefer it to Motion No. 5, although I understand the reasons for Motion No. 5 by my colleague for Mount Royal. They are entirely appropriate and consistent with the one proposed by the government.
On the government side we will be supporting Motion No. 4 because it is the one which has secured the support of the artistic and cultural community.

Madam Speaker, through you to the minister, I recognize you have done some consultation with respect to a review procedure and I appreciate that. It was qur feeling in light of the fact this is an entirely new tribunal, a new experience, a new approach for our artists, that this will be successful in terms of the artists' economic and social goals.
It may be your finding that it would be in the best interests of the artists who have some concerns about majorities of the day and perhaps attitudes of majorities
in a parliamentary committee. They seemed to have placed their sense of trust with the minister and the minister's department. That does not prevent the review procedure from proceeding thereafter to the standing committee if the standing committee so desires.
Further to that, the standing committee is really master of its own agenda and it could under its own initiative, not withstanding this particular clause, undertake such a study if it seems inclined to or if so indicated by the arts community.
I therefore feel there is a responsibility on the part of the artistic organizations that will be involved in this new undertaking of the government. They as well as standing committees of the House should be vigilant. They should certainly be prepared to respond to the initiative of the minister at the end of the seven year term and if they do not do so it would be regretfully a lack of responsibility on the part of those organizations as well as perhaps individual parliamentarians or the standing committee.
I am pleased to support the amendment of the minister and I would be pleased to withdraw if I could get unanimous consent of the House.
This has been a very collegial committee and we have worked very hard jointly on this matter. As my colleague from the New Democratic Party has been very much involved in the on-going discussions, I would appreciate it if you would allow him to speak before you withdraw the amendment I proposed.

Madam Speaker, we also, as you rightly pointed out, had submitted an amendment. I believe it was identical to Motion No. 5 as found in our papers. I am also quite happy in accepting the minister's Motion No. 4. I think for all intents and purposes it is almost exactly the same. Motion No. 5 calls for an automatic review within six

months. The minister's motion calls for a review by the parliamentary committee which could occur at any time.
Again there is no difference as the member for Mount Royal pointed out. The committee is in charge of its affairs. Therefore it could deal with the report almost immediately. The minister is specific in that it goes to the committee that deals with cultural matters.

There is not much substantial difference at all in the two motions. To try to debate this would be, I think, splitting hairs and out of tune with how we have operated in this committee which has been very much on the consensus basis.
The general thrust is an excellent one. It is a new piece of legislation. We are pioneering a new area. The federal government is to be congratulated in having finally advanced Bill C-7. We are playing a leadership role in the world. As such it makes some sense that at a period in the future we should stand back and Parliament should stand back and have a look at how the legislation has worked and functioned.
I am sure at that time there will be some areas that will need readjusting, perhaps minor, perhaps major, but on the general basis it is always good when we introduce new legislation, exploring new areas, to build into it sort of an automatic review so that some time in the future Parliament will be forced to look at this again.
