He said: Madam Speaker, this is a very exciting and a very pleasurable day for me, as it is for many of our colleagues in this House.
At the outset, I simply want to acknowledge that I am particularly pleased that as we call third reading of Bill C-7 that you, Madam Speaker, as a distinguished former performing artist yourself, are seated in the chair. You have contributed a great deal to the artistic and cultural life of this country and in many ways nothing could be more appropriate than to have you in the chair at the time we in this Parliament move to recognize the contribution that has been made by artists from one coast to the other.
Hear, hear.

It is too bad we did not have that bill 20 years ago.

June 11, 1992
Government Orders

Theatre director Jonathan Miller once said: "The artistic community is like a great forest which simultaneously alters and depends upon the composition of the air which surrounds it".
Canadians live in a society which is coming to understand that our artistic community influences our sense of identity as much as our sense of identity influences our artists. A symbiotic relationship has developed between the two which makes it impossible to separate one from the other. The artists that we encourage or discourage provide the atmosphere in which we see ourselves, raise our children and speak to the world.

I realized that the status of the artist in Canada was a crucial issue when I was Minister of National Revenue. In fact, I had occasion to work with the leaders of Canada's art community while preparing the government's response to the report of the Sub-Committee on the Taxation of Visual and Performing Artists and Writers.
Today, more than ever before, I am convinced that the contribution of artists to our society goes to the very heart of our identity as individuals and as a country.
Their creations express our deepest convictions and give them a human dimension. They amplify our voices and make them more expressive. They breath life into our culture.

When artists speak, whether on paper, on canvass or in clay, through the movement of their bodies or the flickering light on the cinema screen, they express our deepest thoughts. They see into the hearts of Canadians and they focus bright light on what is real and what is true. They help us to speak to the rest of the world in a voice which is distinctly our own.
While many people would acknowledge the debt that we owe to our artists for contributing to our culture, I am not sure how many people realize how much artists also contribute to our economy.
How many people realize that half a million Canadians earn their livelihood from this sector of the economy? How many Canadians understand that our cultural activities generate a larger percentage of our Gross Domestic Product than the wood and textile industries
combined? How many people are aware that for every $1 of non-profit arts revenue we have the result of a spin-off of another $3 in spending.
It is a vital and thriving contributor to our identity and to our economy and yet artists are among the most poorly rewarded and the least recognized members of our community, a fact made evident in Revenue Canada's recently released income statistics for 1989.
In 1989 the highest paid group in Canada was doctors earning an average of $120,000 per year; dentists came in second with $98,000, lawyers came close behind them in third place. At the very bottom of the heap came pensioners with annual incomes of $15,000. Although this fact is disturbing it is not altogether surprising. What is surprising, however, is that second last came entertainers and artists with an average of $15,877, just $900 away from the lowest income group in Canada.

As a result, our artists have trouble supporting themselves and their families and cannot afford to invest in the future. As educated professionals they deserve to have an income that will enable their children to aspire to excellence. Under the present circumstances that is impossible.
Many artists must look for alternative employment which restricts the amount of time they can spend on perfecting their art. Their lives are a succession of periods of feast or famine.
Because the artist does not fit the norm, qualifying neither as an employer nor as an employee in the course of his career, does not enjoy professional status in Canadian society and has limited access to the social security programs available to the rest of the population.
It is neither desirable nor necessary to tolerate this kind of situation any longer.

Our artists need a framework in law which acknowledges their special and distinctive contributions to our country and which allows them improved access to certain rights and benefits which other Canadians are routinely privileged to enjoy.

This is not a revolutionary idea. We have been discussing it for as long as I have been in politics. The principles that lie behind it were established more than 40 years ago. The Standing Committee on Communications and Culture has examined it thoroughly, devoting more than 50 hours of committee time to this bill. Close to 15 key artists' organizations have appeared before them and many more have made their wishes known to me and to my department.
The time has come for us to take action. Bill C-7 underscores the important contribution made by artists in Canada to the cultural, social, economic and political enrichment of our country. It recognizes the central role played by artists in celebrating the human spirit and in giving expression to the Canadian experience. It acknowledges that artistic creativity is a vital force behind the growth and prosperity of our cultural industries.
Bill C-7 will at last articulate the policy of the Government of Canada on the status of the artist. It will establish the principles which we believe to be essential, including the recognition of the importance to artists that they be compensated for the use of their works. It will create an advisory council whose purpose will be to inform and advise me on all matters of concern to artists in Canada.
By legally acknowledging the specific working conditions of artists and recognizing their right to form associations and negotiate minimum conditions of work, this bill will finally establish a place for artists in our labour relations legislation. It will create a new agency, the Canadian Artists and Producers Professional Relations Tribunal, which will determine sectors within the artistic universe, certify an artists association for each of these sectors, and force any scale agreements into which certified associations and producers enter.
A principal advantage will be that certified artists' and producers' associations will no longer be subject to prosecution under the Competition Act simply for indulging in labour practices commonly accepted as a basic right by the rest of the labour force.
The tribunal will be granted the power to settle cases of unfair practices, ensure duty of fair representation by associations, and remedy infractions. It will allow producers and artists organizations to freely negotiate satisfactory agreements in accordance with existing practices.
Government Orders
Last November when we sent Bill C-7 to the standing committee, I indicated that I would be open to suggestions to improve this bill. A key issue expressed by a number of witnesses concerned the matter of closed shop practices. My officials and I carefully reviewed these concerns and with the full support of the committee we have amended the legislation to allow for a continuation of current artistic professional relations practices where preference for association members are often negotiated as part of collective agreements.
The amendments will also provide important protection through the tribunal to important artists, to individual artists, who might lose the opportunity to work because of unfair treatment by associations. I believe that our amendment strikes the fair balance between the rights of individual artists and associations that a bill always strove to achieve.
Bill C-7 will not solve all of the problems facing Canadian artists today. However, it will be an important step in a complex process designed to improve the environment for artists and the arts in Canada today. It will provide the context, the framework and the impetus for further improvements.
I have heard the criticism that the bill does not answer all of the concerns of all of the interested parties. Indeed, no bill could fully satisfy all of the divergent needs and points of view.
Let me try to put the issue into perspective by using an example from the arts world itself. A work of art is created in stages. The artist must do the planning, preparation, rough draft and revisions before the final work becomes reality. Sometimes in the artist's view, the work is never really finished. By its very nature, the creative process is never finite.
Similarly, this proposed legislation has undergone repeated and careful revisions and reworking in order to reach the final stage. However this process, by nature critical, comprehensive and creative, must be finite or there would be no point to it.

After years of discussion and months of debate, I believe that we have managed to draft a bill that strikes judicious balance between what is desirable and what is possible. I think that this bill will do much for Canadian artists; it assures them that the Parliament of Canada

Government Orders
recognizes their worth and wishes to improve their status.
Along with Quebec's legislation on the status of artists, it will encourage the other provinces to adopt similar legislation at the provincial level. But we do not want to stop there. Bill C-7 must be seen as a part of all the measures intended to improve the lives of artists in Canada. One might even say that it is a most important part, since our strategy must be based on the principle of fairness.
History shows that the value of artists must be recognized in law if they are to be treated fairly. We must make this bill on the status of artists a proper piece of legislation.
Another important part of our strategy is artists' remuneration. We must protect the Canadians who work in the fields of intellectual and artistic creation. Our cultural products are profitable and will continue to be so; we must ensure that their creators benefit from them. That is only fair and economically sensible.
We must revise the Copyright Act, updating it and making it fair by setting clear and effective rules that apply to both the creators and the consumers of cultural products. That will not be easy. There are many interests and many markets. We want a law that benefits everyone, a law that strengthens the rights of some without infringing on those of others. That will take time, but it is worth the effort.

A third element of our strategy will deal with training. Professional development is as important in the arts as in any sector and we must do what we can to improve accessibility and availability.
A fourth element will focus on marketing, giving artists the information which they need to identify those Canadians who wish to purchase cultural products.
The Department of Communications, together with all 10 provinces and with the municipalities of Vancouver, Montreal and Toronto, has just released the first panCanadian survey of current and potential customers of the performing and visual arts in Canada.
I am confident that this 600-page report will provide an extremely useful marketing tool, one which is sorely needed by the cultural community in these tough times.
A final focus of our strategy must be to critically examine the structure of our cultural industries, ensuring that they are forward looking and flexible, capable of competing with the best that the world has to offer.
This means continuing to move ahead with the next phase of the broadcasting summit, consolidating what we have accomplished to date. This means encouraging our radio action plan consultative committee to look for creative solutions to ensure the future of Canadian radio. This means consolidating the progress that we have made in the field of publishing by getting changes to the Copyright Act and the Investment Canada Act passed by the House.
It does not mean selling off Canadian culture to the highest bidder. Canadians have much more to offer the world when they speak with a voice which is truly their own. The Prime Minister believes it. The Minister for International Trade believes it and so does everyone else who understands that Canadian culture is something which is both valuable and unique. It is the reason why we did not include culture in the Canada-U.S. Trade Agreement and it is the reason why we will not include culture in any North American free trade agreement.
When you view the components of our strategy to improve the lives of Canadian artists, equal treatment, economic reward, training, marketing and structural change, you will see how a wide variety of initiatives are meant to complement each other.
The result must be an environment which encourages the arts and does not discourage them. It must be an environment which values diversity, honours creativity and fosters growth. It must be an environment which stimulates a strong Canadian voice, different from that of our neighbours to the south and secure in its own identity. Bill C-7 can only help to foster that environment.
When Bill C-7 was proposed last spring, the headline in The Globe and Mail read: "Proposed bill on artists' status called a cause to celebrate". And so it is, Madam Speaker.
June 11, 1992

This bill is so elementary, so straightforward, so absolutely necessary that we should not hesitate to enact it. It will, after 40 years of discussion and debate, give us the foundation from which we can move forward on a whole range of policies.
The standing committee did an outstanding job of considering this bill, Madam Speaker. All of your colleagues in the House of Commons who were on the committee from all three parties deserve credit for their thoughtful consideration of the bill and for the amendments which they made to it. They demonstrated that it is possible for people of different political parties to work well together in the public interest.
Let me simply elaborate on that by saying that for me it was a tremendous pleasure to be able to work with my colleagues, to see the commitment which they demonstrated on a day-to-day basis to the status of the arts in Canada, to see the flexibility and the genuine generosity of spirit which was exhibited on both sides of the committee and to be able to report, as I have done, to members of the artistic and cultural community across Canada that there is a commitment that transcends partisanship in this House of Commons to do what any of us can do to strengthen the arts in Canada and to give long overdue recognition to Canadian artists for what they have contributed to our society. That bipartisan support, coming from all sides of the House, is something that speaks loudly and clearly as Canadians celebrate their 125th anniversary.
As we look to our future, we will need our artists to help us to continue to define who we are as a people. But our artists also need us. They need our support here in Parliament and they need the support of Canadians from one coast to another. This bill is in one small way an attempt by members of Parliament on all sides of the House to lend them that support.
All parties represented on the standing committee have urged the government to act on the status of the artists. The arts constituency is urging the government to act on this bill and the public at large is supportive. Our homework has been done. Thoughtful discussion and consideration have been given. The time for action has come. Bill C-7 is our opportunity to paint a new and a brighter picture for Canadian artists. Let us seize that opportunity.
Government Orders

Madam Speaker, I wish to express to the minister our appreciation for his having brought this bill to light finally and to suggest to him that although the cup is only half full, I sincerely hope he is going to put every effort into completing the picture so that truly we can celebrate with full glasses of champagne, which I am sure the minister might want to indulge in tonight if he sees this bill finally going through.

It is with pleasure and some emotion that I participate today in this debate on Bill C-7 concerning the status of the artist and governing the professional relations between artists and producers in Canada.
I say with emotion because our creative artists who inspire us and reflect our collective soul are also, we must admit, the most poorly paid and often among the least fortunate in our society.

I think I can truly say that all members of our committee view this legislation as a first step in responding to the many serious needs of our arts community who are not just nation builders or educators but are custodians of the values other civilizations struggle to preserve.
To paraphrase Maria Tippett in her 1990 University of Toronto book which I have just enunciated, she expressed that very clearly. As Greg Graham said so well, even in a bill on the status of the artists, artists are marginal. This is not a bill for artists. It is a bill for arts' organizations and institutions.
That may well be, but the artist will also benefit in some measure from this bill, not to the extent that we would have appreciated, however. This bill is another step in public policy that attempts to secure the economic and social rights of the artists who are defined as you follow the peregrinations of this bill in a very circuitous route throughout the course of the beginning of the particular bill in question.
It is such a complicated route, I was going to outline it for everybody but I decided it would be far too lengthy and too complex, so I will just let it pass and let members read it for themselves and try to figure out how they are going to define themselves as an artist.

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
Culture is the sum of a country's shared perceptions, beliefs, conventions and values. It is what makes a country different from others. It is what indicates their uniqueness on the world stage.
In the 1979 task force on Canadian unity Coming to Terms, it was stated that:
Culture draws individuals together, supports thought, judgment and action, gives a community its character and personality, differentiates it from other communities and encourages its members to seek common objectives.
A year ago, the Belanger-Campeau commission report-I see some of its members in this House-went even further in the definition of an artist and included artists in the following way. They said:
Culture is the sum of the works which the artists of an entire people had gleaned from the collective imagination as well as from the habits, words, songs, and accents that represent the everyday expression of that people. It is its culture, nurtured and supported by creative artists and researchers, nurtured by artists, experienced by every element that breathes life into identity.
Clearly the arts help us to better understand ourselves, who we are, where we come from. Through the personal expression and performance of individual artists, we develop a better sense of our personal and collective identities. Canada's creators express the great diversity of this nation's people, and it is our strength.
A country's artists are key to its identity. They are a country's ID card and our artists are our seers. It is through our creators that society better understands itself.
As we travel the world or the world comes to our shores, it is our cultural identity that distinguishes us from other nations. They say we are a peaceful people. I hope we keep it that way, that we believe in fairness and equity. I hope we keep it that way, but that is what distinguishes us in the world of nations.
It is difficult for a lot of us if you think about it. How do you associate countries? You associate Russia and Tolstoy, n 'est pas"? I wish I could have said that in Russian, but I cannot. How do you dissociate France from Hugo, Ireland from Joyce, England from Dickens or Shakespeare and from a musical perspective we just had the world of Beethoven and his homeland rings clear as a bell in his musical cutouts.
I could go on and name many of the musical artists around the world, and you could almost immediately identify them with the country of origin. It is so easy, Rodgers and Hammerstein and American jazz. You think American jazz, do you not, when you think of the United States?
We have the same kind of ability right here. We are growing very quickly and we have some wonderful artists who are easily now identified as Canadians on the international arena.
Dr. Jean-Pierre Wallot of the National Archives during our committee hearings and in particular on The Ties That Bind, when we were looking at the Canadian Constitution and cultures' place within the Confederation said:
The United States and France have a strong national identity. This national identity is constantly being nurtured. Through the erection of monuments, the collecting of archives, and through teaching in schools et cetera, a highly developed sense of patriotism and attachment to the nation is developed in these countries, even when deep splits exist.
During their lifetimes artists have challenged their countrymen and often were anything but celebrated in their own homelands. They were broke and they were exiled, yet they revolutionized their country's identities. Today it is our singers, performers, film makers, visual artists, broadcasters, writers, and dancers who bring culture to life. We have many successes and many stars in every field.
Unfortunately, far too often they are overlooked until they get an international reputation. They have not been seen very often as central to the formulation of cultural policies here in this country.
Paul Siren, who has been a proponent of the status of artist legislation for 20 years, is a stalwart in the field of the arts and a person upon whom we can count for wise counsel. In appearing before the committee he hit this point so eloquently. He said:
We need to recognize the artist as a human being rather than simply as an appendage to some property rights, whether they're copyrights or the national conventions governing the insurance for the transportation of works of art, or other legislation that deals with a specific property. We want to be able to recognize the human spirit and the human contribution as an artist in the legislative sense.
June 11, 1992

That is what Bill C-7 attempts to do. However, it barely brings artists to the starting line and it only goes a small part of the way.

The former Minister of Communications described to the Standing Committee on Communications and Culture the plan of action which we must pursue. He explained that the absolutely unique working conditions of artists remain an obstacle which prevents them from having access to our social benefits. Their income is small and seasonal and often artists are not eligible for unemployment insurance because they are self-employed. The same restrictions apply to the workers' compensation program and the Canada Pension Plan.

It has been said that the greatest subsidizers of the arts are the artists themselves. Unfortunately the numbers prove that. According to Revenue Canada professional artists are the lowest paid group of workers.
In 1988 self-employed artists received an average income of $15,877, barely $1,300 a month. Higher on the list is the $18,298 received by farmers and $22,515 received by fishermen. The only group lower on the list is pensioners.
There is little understanding that artists' careers are not comparable to others.
It is interesting to note the portrait of the artist because it identifies the uniqueness of the skills and talents and the maturity that one very often sees in the artists. They are about 44 years old and self-employed. In most cases they have acquired 17 years of experience in their artistic field. They devote 35 to 45 hours a week to their art, and merely to subsist they spend another 10 to 15 hours a week on a job not directly related to art.
The net annual income derived from their art is $13,000 for dancers, $11,079 for authors, $11,444 for visual artists, $15,210 for actors, and $18,248 for musicians. There is also little understanding that culture is also a business, and it is both information rich and labour intensive. The arts industry employs 400,000 people. It is a big business. It generates about $14 billion in economic activity in culture and broadcasting. I believe the minister gave us a figure on the fall-out, I do not remember it but it was a very significant amount.
Government Orders
These figures demonstrate that cultural investments has direct economic benefits too. We often forget that. It is vital to our society. It makes the wheel roll.
I see another past chairman. This place is filled with past chairmen of the standing committee: the members for Edmonton Southwest and Portage-Interlake. That is very nice. Welcome.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext: Thank you.

When the chairman of the Canada Council, Mr. Allan Gotlieb, appeared before the standing committee he described how perilous the situation has become for the arts community in this country. I am quite sure he has spoken into the minister's ear in a very diligent manner and tried to convince the minister to go and get some dollars from Treasury Board and that tight-fisted Minister of Finance, but to no avail. If they only realized the economic fallout they can derive from a small investment. I think they could receive about 11 per cent return, if not more, on their investment. What could be better than that?
I would suggest that we go back and speak to the powers that be to see whether we can remedy some of the crisis in the Canada Council.
This bill is about artists, and therefore I think it is important for the government to note that its cutting of the financial support is a serious threat to these very artists that it says it is trying to assist in this bill. There are some contradictory messages being sent. On the one hand we support artists and on the other hand we are sort of starving them a little bit, through a lack of financing that would be very helpful for their promotion and to their welfare.
Mr. Gotlieb said that the Canada Council, whose main client is Canadian artists, is financially going backwards. Its parliamentary appropriation for ongoing grants and services has been virtually frozen since 1986-87. The council appropriation has been declining in real terms since the mid-1980s. I am aware of the fact that our side is also guilty of some cuts that were unnecessary, in my view.
However, I would suggest that we can make it up. That would be very helpful to artists because since 1987 funding has increased by a mere 2.6 per cent while inflation has stood at 21 per cent over the same period.

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
We have had death by decrement and that is the result, according to Mr. Gotlieb.
However, the situation is quite different internationally. It is good to put things into perspective. Some of these countries that have a long history and have made their mark in the world over time have seen how important it is to invest in the cultural life of their country from all kinds of points of view.
A study conducted by the international cultural policy group of the Department of Communications pointed out that in the late 1980s levels of art support in Canada are below that of many countries. Canada Council per capita funding in the 1980s was below that of the arts council of Great Britain and about equal to that of the Australian council. However, both of these arts agencies have received substantial increases to their appropriation since then making them better positioned to address the financial difficulties facing the arts community in the 1990s. The Canada Council has not been so favoured.
It would appear that the government had the facts and understood the problems because this bill has had a very long history in the making. There has been an extensive process for which Parliament, all sides of this House, should be quite proud.
Bill C-7 had its genesis in 1980 with Canada's signature of the UNESCO recommendations in which signatory states agreed to consider the implementation of a broad range of policies to recognize and encourage the development of the role of the professional artist within society, including funding, training, professional status for artists and access to social programs such as health care, pensions and unemployment insurance.
In 1986 a task force headed by Gratien Gelinas and Paul Siren, after extensive consultations within the artistic community, presented 41 recommendations to the government on how to implement the spirit of the UNESCO declaration.
After that the Standing Committee on Communications and Culture issued two reports on taxation and the arts. In 1989 the standing committee studied and issued another report calling for the status of the artist legislation. I believe it is as a result of some of these pressures that this bill was finally drafted and introduced.
This is an act respecting the status of the artist and professional relations between artists and producers in Canada. That title would lead one to believe that this piece of legislation deals with many artists' issues, but beyond the title and the introductory part that deals with a set of principles and policy directions there is very little.
It brings artists to the starting gate. There is much more that needs to be done. Pages 3 to 36 address labour relations, remaining silent on issues concerning social benefits, bankruptcy protection, income averaging, et cetera.
This bill is largely a labour relations bill and as such does not address the concerns of independent writers and visual artists who are not engaged in this field.
It provides self-employed artists the right to collectively bargain through organizations such as ACTRA, Union des Artistes, and the American Federation of Musicians.
In order to receive recognition for the purpose of collective bargaining, organizations will seek certification from an independent commission known as the Canadian artists and producers professional relations tribunal. The efficacy of this independent body for the management of collective bargaining will largely depend on the quality and experience of the appointments made to it by the Minister of Labour, after consultation with the Minister of Communications. We made it quite clear we would have preferred that the Minister of Communications should be charged with making the nominations.
There are serious concerns being expressed about certain aspects of this nomination procedure because the minister involved is very closely related to and involved with decisions of the Canada Labour Relations Tribunal, and that is making widgets.
Madam Speaker, as an artist you know that the manufacturing trade and assembly plants are not exactly the milieu in which you work. Your conditions of work and the product you produce is not a widget. It is not a manufactured good. It comes from the heart, the soul, and the creative energy of people involved in this very particular field. It requires a very particular skill to be

able to determine the right kind of answers in situations in which there are disputes that need to be settled.
The Canadian Conference of the Arts has pointed out that the experience of Quebec artists with the introduction of their tribunal was almost one of chaos because appointees did not have a background in the cultural fields.
During clause-by-clause I moved an amendment that would have had the Canadian advisory council on the status of the artist develop a list of appointees from which the Minister of Labour would be invited to make appointments.
This approach has a precedent in the Public Service Staff Relations Board and this amendment had the support of the artistic community that appeared before the committee. Unfortunately the government refused.
This bill also creates a permanent Canadian council on the status of the artist. This body's predecessor, the Canadian Advisory Committee on the Status of the Artist, was responsible for providing the impetus to progress on this issue.
As well, this advisory council created the Canadian artists' code, which has served as a benchmark for the development of policy and legislation.
The details regarding staffing and administration of the council are not part of this bill. There have been calls for the council to be "managed at arm's length" from the Department of Communications and other government departments or agencies for it to be able to reach the highest possible level of effectiveness. Here again we attempted to provide more openness.
This bill requires the council to make a report annually to the Minister of Communications but does not require the report to be made available to the arts community or the public at large. The whole point of making a report is so that the constituents and the constituency should be advised of what is going on.
Once again this amendment was rejected even though it had the support of the artistic community. The answer was that some things might be contained within this report that we do not not want the public to know about. That is a very poor excuse for not having an open process
Government Orders
so that artists and our creators can air their views in the public arena.
Although I support this bill in principle and certainly will pass it with pleasure, as a first step, I have argued and will continue to argue that this bill is only half-full because there is so much left to be done from a socio-economic perspective for our Canadian artists.
Simultaneously the government did do some things that were worth while. With the tabling of this bill in the House the finance minister announced tax measures that will benefit artists. These were passed by the House in December 1991. The first concerned the income tax treatment of donations made by artists of culturally significant works of their creation and of expenses incurred by employed artists in connection with their artistic employment.
The second allowed employed artists to claim a deduction in respect of actual expenses incurred in the exercise of their artistic employment of up to the lesser of $1,000 or 20 per cent of their income from artistic employment. It is not exactly going to allow them much latitude.
However, even with those two measures the artists are still waiting for this government to take action on what is called income averaging provisions. All of us know that artists have rich times and poor times. If you are in any of the creative arts fields you have a period of employment and then all of a sudden there is a period of famine. You make sales of your creative works and all of a sudden sales dry up or you have to stop selling in order to create new product.
The standing committee unanimously recommended that artists be given the right to stabilize their income by setting aside a part of their artistic income in what was called an artist's account on which tax liability would be deferred and that the Income Tkx Act be amended accordingly. The government in its response to that recommendation promised in 1990 only to examine income averaging provisions. It would seem to be the government's point of view that such allowances already exist through the liberalized RRSP rules.
The arts associations' view of the RRSP solution is one that is seriously flawed according to them. They argue that RRSPs were created to provide pension income not to serve as an income averaging device.

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
Bill C-7 does not address the government's commitment to protect artists' royalties from the bankruptcy of producers. In its response to the standing committee the government said it was prepared to protect royalties flowing from the copyright of self-employed artists against bankruptcies of cultural industries with which they contract and to propose the best measures to reach this objective.
Since the government's response it has introduced bankruptcy legislation. That was Bill C-22 which has just gone through this House. It does not have one single word or any protection for the artist in this life even though those promises were made.
The bill remains silent on the right of compensation by the government for the public use of works of art. While clause 2(e) was amended in committee to recognize the importance to artists that they be compensated for the use of their works including the public lending of them, it does not provide any formal recognition or mechanism of that right for compensation for public use.
In 1986 a public lending rights program providing compensation to Canadian authors for their works in public libraries was introduced. However, it has no statutory basis, which is what the standing committee has recommended. This position was reiterated to Parliament by the Writers' Union, the Canadian Conference on the Arts, CARFAC, SARDEC, the Public Lending Rights Commission itself and the Minister of Communication's own Advisory Council on the Status of the Artist.
We have argued on this side for the inclusion of statutory recognition, even suggesting that if it is not done in this legislation, hopefully it will be included in the new Canada Council legislation which will soon see the formal merging of the council and the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council. Let us hope the minister will hear that plea and include it at that stage when it comes before this House.

As you know, Madam Speaker, the unique working conditions of the artists put a major obstacle in the way of them gaining access to several benefits most Canadians routinely enjoy.
The fact that artists are often self-employed also denies them access to several programs such as wage loss insurance and extended health coverage or unemployment insurance which all employees get through their employers.
That is why the Standing Committee unanimously recommended right off that this bill on the status of the artist allow those who are members of certified associations to become "employees" for the purpose of the regulation on the insurable portion of a wage-earning job and that the Unemployment Insurance Act be amended in consequence thereof. That makes a lot of sense, does it not?
Second, the standing committee recommended that the Minister of Communications look into the need to establish private group benefit plans for creative artists as well as the viability of such plans.
In the government's response to this first recommendation a commitment was made only to continue to examine the eligibility criteria of the unemployment insurance program with a view to expanding coverage to artists within the framework of the Unemployment Insurance Act.
In response to the second recommendation the government passed off the issue to the Canadian Advisory Council on the Status of the Artist to propose options to solve this problem.
The former Minister of Communications suggested the following possible solutions to make such benefits more accessible to artists: For example, could not the Canada Pension Plan contributions be determined according to gross revenue rather than taxable income? Could we not recognize for performing artists their status as employees under the Unemployment Insurance Act without impinging on their status as entrepreneurs under the Income Ihx Act?
Has the current Minister of Communications investigated those options of his predecessor? Could he tell us what the conclusions are? What are the results of the government's promise to continue to examine the eligibility criteria of the unemployment insurance program? These matters remain unresolved. They are critical to the financial well-being of this sector of our important cultural enterprises.
Bill C-7 only applies to the National Film Board, the National Arts Centre, the CBC and federally regulated broadcasters. It does not apply to companies that receive
June 11, 1992

money from Telefilm Canada for the making of films. It is really quite a restricted number of clients within the framework of this legislation.
When the minister was asked why he did not at least include Telefilm Canada the reason given was that the operation of companies falls under provincial jurisdiction. That may well be the case. Yet Telefilm requires certain Canadian content criteria when it gives money. Therefore, why could the federal government not provide within the context of this bill that when Telefilm money is involved in a film project, the status of the artist legislation would apply? I do not have the answer to that. It would be interesting to know some day if we could do that.
In conclusion, I would like to say that this has been a very interesting exercise. It has highlighted all the areas that need to receive some attention. I know Rome was not built in a day and so the status and the health of our artists is certainly not one I can anticipate, particularly at this time and unfortunately with this government. I would like to add that working together in the best interests of the arts and the artists in a collegial and non-partisan way and if we could continue in this mode of operation and if it could be extended to other committees, I do believe the well-being of Canada could be assured. We could see through these expressions the sense of hope and the sense of future that we can look forward to in this wonderful land in which we are privileged to live.
I would like to reflect at this point on the words of a cultural nationalist for whom I have a great deal of respect, Mr. Bernard Ostry. In a recent speech at Carleton University he said:
Only developing the mind and imagination of Canadians can we survive with influence over our life and our community. Only by that influence can we come together, even if only in the old way we know so well, the way of agreeing to differ, of live and let live.
He went on to say: "One thing remains. We have to act". I might add it is my hope that the work for the Canadian artists has only just begun and we will work and act so that it may continue and flourish and grow.

Madam Speaker, it gives me much pleasure to have the privilege of being able to add a few words on this historic occasion on behalf of my colleagues in the New Democratic Party.
First of all, I also mention as the member for the Liberal Party and the minister did, how well we worked
Government Orders
on the committee. We worked as a team. We were not in there trying to score political points. We were trying to advance the cause and the interests of the artists and we were doing this together.
Working on the committee shows the best of Parliament, the best of our democratic traditions and of this institution. I join both with the minister and the critic from the Liberal Party in expressing our wish that if more institutions of Parliament could operate the way our committee has operated, certainly this institution would be held in much higher esteem by Canadians. I would suggest as well we would be much more effective. Part of the problem with our committee is that you sort of go bump into the bureaucracy. In some ways it would seem to me that government members, including the minister, are caught in the hands of the bureaucracy.
I suspect, although the minister has never formally indicated this to us in committee or privately, many of the things we were suggesting the minister was in agreement with, but that also his hands are tied as were the hands of the governments members on our committee who very often and very openly expressed agreement with the things we are all proposing, amendments that were being introduced, suggestions that were being made. Their hands were tied. Perhaps some day we will have a committee system in which the politicians are the representatives of the people and will again become masters of this House and its committees.
Having said that, I commend all members on the committee. I commend the minister for the work that has been done that leads to this moment and it is an historic moment. I have heard both the minister and the critic from the Liberal Party mention that it has been some 40 years in discussion and debate. Sometimes progress is slow-40 years. Let us then also celebrate. Let us also celebrate, and I will mention this later in my remarks, some of the things that still need to be done. The fact is the glass is not half empty but half full. Therefore, my anticipation is that the movement is toward filling it and not emptying it.
In Canada, more than in many other countries, we should recognize the importance of culture. Art is like a mirror. It reflects who we are and through seeing who we are we become ourselves. We become more. We begin to gain our sense of identify, a sense of ourselves as people. Nationalism and patriotism could not have existed without the arts, without paintings, without song, without sculpture and without drama. A nation could not exist.

Government Orders
Its identity could not exist without the artistic reflections of that nation. It is essential.
This young country is struggling in an attempt to maintain itself and its identity, culture and the arts are vital to the survival of Canada as a nation. It is not easy. The job has never been easy for Canadians stretched across this huge geographic land mass from ocean to ocean to ocean, a society with many different peoples from many races and different parts of the earth who have come and lived here and with the different geographic districts and regions.
To begin to try and bring this together into a sense of oneness is not an easy job. It is not something that the state or some bureaucratic planners could bring about. It is only through giving its people the ability of expressing themselves and other peoples and other regions and districts being able to view and experience that expression that we can finally begin to bring together this nebulous notion of Canadian identity. I think we have been successful.
You cannot quite define it, you cannot exactly put words to it or measure it or weigh it, but we as Canadians know we are Canadians. We know we are different. We know we share some values that are different from the values of many of our ancestors in Europe or our friends and neighbours to the south or other locations on this globe. We know we are different because we have been able to see the reflections of other Canadians in the mirror through culture and through artistic expression.
Culture and the arts are more than just creating patriotism and nationalism. They help to bring forth our individual self-consciousness. Why do artists participate in this activity? It is certainly not a money-maker in terms of economic activity. Many of them will tell you that it is the challenge and the pleasure of exploring one's own self, one's own consciousness and expanding that and moving on to newer and higher levels.
As individual artists engage in that exercise, we as a collective all benefit from that. Not only do we as Canadians benefit from the artistic productions of Canadian artists, but in this day and age of globalization, through giving artists new tools for expression, new
audiences which are global, a new form of consciousness also begins to arise and is allowed to arise. It is more of the global consciousness. It is a consciousness that begins to recognize the humanity of all. The universality of the human experience is now beginning to be appreciated as it has never been appreciated before in the history of the human race.
When the Beatles, for example, in the early 1960s started to use the sitar and the harpsichord, instruments from different cultures and different time periods, bringing them together into the here and now, we began to recognize that human awareness now spreads not only over all different cultures of this globe but also back in time, in historic time.
Through these artistic expressions a new global consciousness is arising. It is exciting and new. It points to a new human relations between peoples. It destroys the mystique of different cultures in the sense that those different cultures are now understood better and appreciated better through the understanding of the universality of the human spirit.
I appeal to my fellow artists in Quebec who are so concerned, and rightly so, with the national spirit of the collective consciousness of the Quebecois, of the French experience on North America, not to isolate yourselves, caught in 19th century nationalism, and escape the marvellous experience and opportunities of a global consciousness and a global awareness in which the experience, as expressed through its culture and the arts of the francophones, can be presented on the global stage and participate with the global human family.
I make that appeal because while I understand the origin and the importance and the drama and the poetiy of nationalism, we are surely also living in this tremendous opportunity of living in a post-nationalist period. Surely the artists in Quebec would do themselves a disservice and the people and audiences in Quebec a disservice if they cut themselves off from that rich possibility of a more global and a more universal form of art.
While we celebrate the passage of this legislation, and I expect I will be the last speaker and that this House will unanimously give approval to Bill C-7, things must be
June 11, 1992

said to indicate that this cup is only half full. More needs to be added.
The minister strongly indicated, and certainly the official spokesperson for the Liberals has eloquently laid before the House, the economic hardships that many artists face. While they have this important task of giving identity to themselves, they are hardly recognized in an economic sense. Next to the pensioners they are the lowest and the poorest as an occupational group in this country.
There are many things to be added. I was not entirely happy with Bill C-7. There were many shortcomings in the bill. Again, going back to how our committee worked, all members of our committee, whether they were government or opposition, recognized the shortcomings of the bill. Rather than trying to score political points and sitting here moving amendment after amendment, trying to hold up the bill and voting against it and doing all these things that opposition parties are supposed to do, we decided not to do that. We recognized there were more miles to travel.
Let us take what we have now. Let us try to approve as much as we can, given the possibilities and the state of awareness, not by the minister and the government members in this case, but by the bureaucrats. Let us go with that.
There was one very important amendment. I could not have voted for this bill and I could not have advised my colleagues to support this bill had the minister and the department not agreed to change that one section to allow for a closed shop.
The original bill was a step backward. Where a victory had been achieved, especially by the musicians to allow them to negotiate in a united way, the original bill would have forced them backwards. That would not have been acceptable to us in this party.
I am happy that the minister and the committee unanimously supported the minister and the government's amendments to the bill.
There are other problems. The definition of the minister is the Minister of Labour. Here we have the Minister of Communications introducing the bill. The bill came to the communications committee, not to the labour committee. It is the labour minister who in the
Government Orders
end is referred to as the minister who sets up the tribunal and who is, for all intents and purposes, in charge of this legislation. This is obviously something that needs to be corrected.
We are concerned and we have expressed this. We suggested amendments. The tribunal should consist of people who should be nominated by the Minister of Communications or at least who have some input from the cultural organizations.
I am glad to see that the Minister of Communications will advise the Minister of Labour but the Minister of Labour need not heed that advice. We wish the legislation had been different and the Minister of Labour would have had to heed the advice of the Minister of Communications.
We are concerned that the Department of Labour, which is experienced and knowledgeable about industrial disputes, will look at the cultural sector in that same light. Culture does not produce widgets. The human relationship and the human dynamics are different. It is not on the industrial union model side. It is not on the industrial labour relations side. It is different. There are different practices and understandings that have been created in this field. We hope that this tribunal will understand that and will consist of men and women who fully and totally understand that and will be able to deal with potential labour disputes in this sector in a knowledgeable way and in a way that is sympathetic.
We hope that the rules, regulations and practices of the labour department will not be imposed on the cultural sector.
There are certainly indications around that different departments do not share the sensitivity and understanding of the arts and the cultural sector.
The other day I asked the Minister of Employment and Immigration about the job training program, professional job training, an essential element for artists and the training of professional artists in this country.
There was an important task force that brought down its report on December 1,1991. The Minister of Employment and Immigration has not even responded to that. His department is the most important department when it comes to professional training. All sorts of important

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
cultural institutions are dependent upon those training dollars-not a word from the department.
What I am hearing from within the department is that the people in the employment sector of that department who have experience and dealt with the arts community and the cultural community are not having their contracts renewed. The department is losing its ability, its expertise, in the cultural sector.
I am hearing from within the department that this minister is not interested in culture and the arts, that the job of the department is not to open the doors to the cultural community but rather to close them.
The arts community and the leadership in the arts organizations have not been able to meet with the minister. They have not even been able to meet with the deputy minister.
This is outrageous and I am afraid if the Department of Labour deals with the arts community the same way the Department of Employment and Immigration is dealing with the arts community, Bill C-7 might not produce the things we are all hoping it would produce today.
There is a lot more work to do and a lot to add to the glass to enable us to have a full glass of champagne to celebrate. Certainly we need more changes in the Income Tax Act to make it appropriate to the artists.
We are concerned as well, and the committee reported this in its report, about some of the constitutional changes. Are some of the politicians, provincial and federal, willing to shuttle the arts off to the side? I hope not. There is that concern.
We have concerns about the funding of artistic organizations and the artists themselves. There is concern about book publishing and the authors, trying to make certain there remains an industry in this country.
We are concerned about broadcasting and films, that Canadians are able to see their own films, their own cultural products. I go back to what I said before. A nation gets and develops its identity when it is able to see itself in the mirror and the artists create the mirror.
If Canadians cannot see each other through television and film, by reading books and magazines, if these are
not available, if we all get sucked into that mass culture from south of the border and we lose our identity, as a country we have lost our soul and we have lost our reason for being. Then we begin to feel as Canadians that we are no different from other people south of the border. We really begin to lose our will of remaining as a separate nation, a separate people and a separate identity-
That would be so sad.
I believe, and I speak here as an immigrant, that what Canadians have achieved is something unique in the pages of human history. We have developed a society that has values and sensitivities and that is really the most civilized in the world.
The Prime Minister quoted that the United Nations, through some measurement, has considered Canada to be the number one place. I agree in this one instance with our Prime Minister and certainly with the United Nations. In many ways Canada is number one. We have and share values that in the evolution of our humanity are unique. It is at a high pinnacle. It is worth not just preserving but broadcasting to the world. It is a beacon of hope. The arts and the artists are the means of communicating that. These people help create and engender that.
Bill C-7 goes some way in helping them. I am certain all of us in the House will continue in our own way to make certain we begin to fill that cup so that it is not half empty but will become fuller and fuller and fuller.

speechtext: The House proceeded to the consideration of Bill C-58, An Act to amend the Oil and Gas Production and Conservation Act and other Acts in consequence thereof, as reported (without amendment) from a legislative committee.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
There are nine amending motions on the Notice Paper concerning the report stage of Bill C-58, An Act to amend the Oil and Gas Production and Conservation Act and other Acts in consequence thereof.

Motions Nos. 1, 2, 6, 7, 8 and 9 will be grouped for debate. A vote on Motion No. 1 will apply to Motions Nos. 2, 6, 7, 8 and 9.

Motions Nos. 3 and 4 will be grouped for debate and the vote on Motion No. 3 will apply to Motion No. 4.

Motion No. 5 will be debated and voted on separately.

Motion No. 1
That Bill C-58 be amended in clause 8 by striking out line 24 at page 4 and substituting the following therefor:
"environmental programs or studies or studies on evacuation systems; and"
Motion No. 2
That Bill C-58 be amended in clause 8 by striking out line 22 at page 5 and substituting the following therefor:
"ing procedures, evacuation systems and personnel".
Motion No. 6
That Bill C-58 be amended in clause 58 by striking out line 34 at page 30 and substituting the following therefor
"environmental programs or studies or studies on evacuation systems; and"
Motion No. 7
That Bill C-58 be amended in clause 58 by striking out line 34 at page 31 and substituting the following therefor:
"operating procedures, evacuation systems and personnel". Motion No. 8
That Bill C-58 be amended in clause 96 by adding immediately after line 25 at page 51 the following:
"environmental programs or studies or studies on evacuation systems; and"
Motion No. 9
That Bill C-58 be amended in clause 96 by adding immediately after line 22 at page 52 the following:
"operating procedures, evacuation systems and personnel".
He said: Madam Speaker, I will speak very briefly to this group of amendments to Bill C-58, the Oil and Gas Production and Conservation Act. The purpose of all these amendments is to insert specifically reference to studies and implementation and inspections of evacuation systems.
During both committee hearings and in other discussions outside committee there was a great deal of information relayed to many of us who had become involved in working on this legislation.
One of the areas in which significant progress had not yet really been made was coming up with safe evacuation systems that could be relied on in stormy sea situations such as those which gave rise to the disaster commonly known as the Ocean Ranger that cost some 84 lives just a little over 10 years ago.
For this reason and considering, if we go back to second reading debate, some of the concerns expressed at that time about the importance of effective and efficient evacuation systems for offshore oil rigs in emergency situations, we felt a greater degree of specificity ought to be accorded to the whole matter of evacuation systems in mentioning it concretely within the legislation.

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
One example I will quote as far as Motion No. 2 is concerned, for instance, in paragraph 5.02 found on page 5 of the bill under Safety of Works and Activities. The amendment would cause it to read:
The minister shall, before issuing an authorization for a work or activity referred to in paragraph 5(l)(b), consider the safety of the work or activity by reviewing, in consultation with the Chief Safety Officer, the system as a whole and its components, including its installations, equipment, operating procedures, evacuation systems and personnel.
The effect of all the other amendments is simply to bring the other provisions of the bill before us into line with that change. That fairly clearly spells out the intent. It might be argued that evacuation systems are covered by the more general wording. However, concern was expressed by many to me and to a number of my New Democratic colleagues, particularly those who attended the committee from the province of Newfoundland where this tragedy was most closely felt. They believed it was important in order for greater onus to be placed on the need to develop, test and implement safe evacuation procedures that we have specific mention of that particular problem within the legislation itself.

Mr. Speaker, I want to congratulate all my colleagues on the work that took place in the legislative committee. There is no doubt that during the hearings we heard representation from many witnesses.

On Motion No. 5, this ties down too strictly into one department. There is a combination of all departments that are involved in this legislation. Rather than zeroing in on one department, we believe that it is better that it is the entire operation of all departments involved in this. Again, we would be rejecting the motion.

Mr. Speaker, I have had a very close look at the amendments and discussed them with my colleagues. I think I see the intent of some of the reasoning. I did not sit on the committee, but I reviewed the four committee reports. I have been in contact with three members and I see another one waving across the floor.
Essentially I do not believe that the intent of the bill will be changed significantly by these amendments. Without grouping them separately, I do not believe there is a necessity for the amendments. While I do have some reservations about the bill which I will express in third reading, I am quite happy with it the way it is with respect to these amendments.

Mr. Speaker, very briefly I want to intervene on these amendments put forward by my colleague. I sat on the committee for one of the sessions. I have had an ongoing interest in the legislation in the safety of workers at sea, whether they be on stable platforms or on vessels. I am flabbergasted that both the government and the Official Opposition do not want to include in the bill a reference that eventually will lead us to some form of safe egress from the platforms.
All the amendment called for is adding the words "or studies on evacuation systems" which would force the government, would mandate the government, to do some work on that. It has been 10 years. The Government of Canada has done diddly as I understand it to ensure that the research is done to find a way to take the workers off a platform in the event that one of the legs buckles or the seas become so strong that the whole structure is in danger. We know that you cannot get a helicopter over in that kind of weather. We know that you cannot get a ship close enough. There needs to be a way that those workers can get off that platform, which is high above the sea, safely into the water and withstand the kind of swells that will occur. I am flabbergasted that both parties have rejected that particular amendment.
The other one in terms of the comments from the representative of the government talking about the amendments that focus things on the ministry of labour, it is my understanding that the bill gives paramountcy to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources. In the event there is an emergency, it is up to the minister responsible for raising oil and therefore raising revenue
June 11, 1992

who will make the decision on safety of this particular rig or this particular platform.
I argued in committee and I argued in the briefings that the parliamentaiy secretary gave to me that either the Minister of Labour or the Minister of Transport should be the one who is paramount. In consultations with my colleague who moved the motion, we decided that the best approach was for the Minister of Labour who has the ultimate responsibility for the health and safety of the workers. We do not feel the minister who is responsible for revenues, as it relates to energy of the economic development, should be the one who has that power.
Let us put a neutral person from the cabinet, from the government, in that position so that the workers will be the bottom line, not the expendable line.

Mr. Speaker, I have had an interest in the particular subject from some long time ago when we dealt in this House with the tragedy of the Ocean Ranger and the difficulties surrounding the safety issues. I would like to support and concur with what my colleague said, that it is an absolute conflict of interest for the minister of energy to be responsible for the safety of the individual on the rig when it comes to pumping oil and raising revenue versus protecting human life.
They dealt with the ocean danger before and after the tragic event and tried to deal with an American company, Odeco, benefits for the families that went through tragedy and suffering. It was just a catastrophe.
I want to add a little bit more. My colleague mentioned the dilemma of extracting people, getting them out of the operation in very dangerous circumstances. I recall the morning after the Ocean Ranger disappeared. The Armed Forces were out in very dangerous seas. Maybe some of my colleagues in the House will recall the event on the front page of The Globe and Mail when there was a Labrador helicopter with rescue specialists hanging into the water searching for survivors after that event.
I can remember at the time the pilot of that particular aircraft, Mike Clark, in the opinion of many people here
Government Orders
deserved a medal for the kind of activity that went on in that very dangerous situation.
The current purchase by the Government of Canada of $5 billion worth of military helicopters impinges on this. If we were taking that kind of money and spending it to ensure that these kinds of recommendations were put in place, we would be far better off protecting the lives and safety of Canadian workers.
We have seen a terrible tragedy in the coal mines in Nova Scotia. We have seen marine problems, but in terms of this helicopter purchase at $5 billion, it is an absolute obscenity. I suspect that right now, today, we could probably buy the Soviet nuclear fleet and turn it into junk for less than $5 billion.
I wonder exactly why we are making this purchase when we could be putting the money to work in terms of safety for workers involved in just the kind of proposals that my colleagues have put forward.
The present Armed Forces equipment with Labradors and Chinook helicopters is absolutely adequate. They need to be refitted with engines and then they can provide the kind of safety in equipment that both the member for Kootenay and the member for Thunder Bay-Atikokan have been talking about here today, and the proposers of this amendment.
The Labrador helicopters on the coast of British Columbia with the twin rotors are ideal equipment in mountain valleys where you need stability while you are trying to work in very careful environments. You need decent engines in those aircraft and those twin rotors give far more stability than the Prime Minister was trying to talk us into yesterday with a single rotor piece of equipment. They absolutely lack the stability.
At almost $5 billion, and we have seen over-run after over-run come into this, this is a disgusting proposal. I say we ought to be sending the Prime Minister to what is left of the Soviet Union to attempt to purchase the Soviet fleet. They would give it to us for less than $5 billion. We could scrap it safely. This purchase is absolutely insane.
We should be spending that money making the kind of safety improvements that we are dealing with. We do not need this purchase. I see the Minister of State for Defence here today. I would love to see her stand up in the House and justify this thing.

I must admit that one of the reasons for doing so has to do with perception. In addressing that I would like to read a letter I received in early April from the Seafarers' International Union.
June 11, 1992

It seemed almost beyond belief to me that after 10 years' investigation of this disaster in 1982 that we could have been constructing a bill dealing largely with the safety aspects arising from the Ocean Ranger disaster without close consultation among the government, the ministries involved, and those segments of organized labour most closely associated both with the industry and with the specific disaster which gave rise to this legislation, especially in an area such as safety which in every jurisdiction in Canada is recognized as being an area in which industry, labour and government must be closely involved, particularly in the development of the legislative and regulatory regime.
The letter I want to refer to, and it is in perhaps stronger language than I would normally use, is from the president of the Seafarers' International Union of Canada and is dated April 2.
He says:
Let me firstly thank you for bringing Bill C-58 and its contents to our attention. The scoundrely attempt by the Department of Energy, Mines and Resources to go through a legislative back door with safety legislation without the input of labour, regardless of its content, shows the blatant disregard this government and the oil industry truly have with respect to fair representation of the industry work force.
This designed attempt by EMR to usurp the mandate of Labour Canada, a federal department which does utilize the consultative process with its clientele and is responsible for occupational safety and health warrants investigation. Why were labour representatives not invited to participate? What are the government and the oil industry hiding? As employee safety is an issue, is EMR the right department to responsibly handle it?
This bill should be referred to a committee consisting of labour, management and government representatives for review.
Thanking you in advance for your assistance in helping to achieve this goal in getting answers to the above questions.
Yours fraternally,
Roman Gralewicz,
President Seafarers International Union of Canada.
As I said earlier in my remarks, I find it unfathomable in this day and age that the government would proceed with safety-related legislation and not have the closest consultation with all of the parties that are involved and all of the parties that are at risk.
Government Orders
More than capital is at risk in the oil and gas industry, as countless families, especially in Newfoundland and other Atlantic provinces have found out to their great sorrow. Surely it is time to learn.
The administration of the Offshore Oil and Gas Training Standards Advisory Board seemed the appropriate agency to myself and my New Democratic colleagues. We also felt, not only on this board but other advisory boards, that representation should be accorded to those employees who work in the industry.
It is not only the lack of consultation in this bill but the attitude of the oil and gas industry regarding organized worker representation across Canada which has not been an enlightened one. They are very resistant to having any employee organization, whether onshore or offshore. They have failed, as in a recent industrial accident, to have the appropriate kind of tripartite consultation taking place.
One of the results of that is that we have these disasters and we do not seem to learn from them. On the day-to-day administration of safety it is vital. In the development of the procedures and the technology and in matters of the appropriate training for the personnel on offshore rigs, there should be representation from those organizations and from those employees who are putting their lives at risk every day.
That is the purpose of these particular amendments and I would hope they would receive some favourable consideration.

Mr. Speaker, in advance of my remarks I would ask for a little time to develop the context into which these remarks fit. I notice the Minister of State for Transport laughing over there, but in this matter I really support what she has done. I would like to lay out for her a very serious case about safety in the transportation field. The Ocean Ranger has been quoted here often, but if you go to the coast of British Columbia, extricating an individual from a marine platform is often a very difficult thing.
