speechtext:
Thank you, Mr. Speaker, and thank you to my friend opposite.
I am going to be very brief. This is a very important piece of legislation. Tragically, it has been 10 years in the making since the February 1982 disaster which affected so many people in Newfoundland and Labrador and across Canada.
This piece of legislation has been developed with the input of a tremendous number of people, certainly officials from a number of federal departments who have carried out extensive consultations themselves. The Department of Energy, Mines and Resources, the Department of Labour, the Department of Industry, Science and Technology and certainly the Department of Transport consulted client groups and interested parties throughout the discussions.
Discussions have been held with a number of provincial governments that have been directly involved, not only in their ongoing responsibility for resource development, but also their responsibilities particularly in the areas of worker safety and health and safety regulations.
The industry, the workers in the industry and those who over a period of years have developed either in this country or particularly in the North Sea a capacity to understand the real risks that are involved in this business were also consulted.
There have been a number of discussions about amendments. Having participated in all of the hearings in the legislative committee, we had some very interesting testimony and some very good witnesses with whom we had the opportunity to discuss a number of important things.
Two of the important things that have come up in this House and in committee are our ability to to continue to develop the newest systems for evacuation and our ability to know that we have the best equipment and the best technology available to protect the offshore workers in this very dangerous business. That technology continues. That technology is supported by the federal government. It is supported by provincial governments. It is supported by the industry and it is certainly being supported and enhanced by labour groups in an ongoing way.
I recently met with the oilfield workers in Newfoundland. Some of the things they are doing are very much on
the leading edge. This legislation not only allows for that but also encourages it. It makes it absolutely mandatory that everybody understands the regulations and everybody understands the systems that are in place and that they are approved before projects can proceed.
When the bill was first introduced in the House the question of the ultimate responsibility of the minister was debated. I think all members of the House will remember that the Hickman royal commission on the Ocean Ranger disaster recommended that one minister be responsible.
The task force which reported in 1985 or 1986 brought together many people who looked at the expertise here in Canada, looked at comparable regimes, particularly in the United Kingdom and Norway, and recommended that it be the minister of energy who played that role.
It is a role that ensures when this process of regulation, this process of ensuring maximum safety, of ensuring the best and the most advanced systems of evacuation and protection are put in place, ultimately one minister is responsible. I asked a number of people why it would be the minister of energy. The reason is that ultimately, this is an industrial project.
There is a substantial labour component and real responsibility not only for the federal Minister of Labour but also in some situations depending on the jurisdiction, the provincial Minister of Labour.
We are dealing with a ship and all the regulations that exist to govern ships and shipping in this country prevail today in this legislation. The Minister of Transport and his or her officials continue to play a very substantial role not only in the responsibility under all the shipping acts, the Canada Shipping Act and others, but also in the role that the Minister of Transport and the officials must play in the development of regulations that govern the offshore.
Ultimately, a minister has to be responsible. Ultimately, it must be remembered that this is an industrial project.
Ultimately it must be remembered that the first responsibility of these regulations is the health and safety of workers aboard rigs, the protection of those who depend on the seas for their living-such as mariners, people who depend on the fisheiy, those who must know that not only are the seaways safe but the ocean is
June 11, 1992

clean and protected from pollution-from the tragedies that come from accidents.
All the responsibilities of the other departments come into play but when action is needed there must be one minister.
There is one other component that I would briefly like to touch on that is as important as any. All the regulations we have in place, all the systems we may put in place are of no value unless our people are properly trained in the use of those systems and fully understand their responsibilities as individuals, their responsibilities as part of a production or exploration team and their responsibilities to each other, not only for the preservation of the environment and their own lives but for the preservation of the lives of those people around them.
It is that training we must focus on. It is that training that we have done a lot of in the past. However, it is that training that needs to continue to be developed. We need to know that when those people are trained they are fresh, they are trained under the right conditions and they are trained to do the things that matter, not only in a crunch situation, when they are faced with a serious situation because of weather or mechanical problems, but day to day, hour by hour so that the workers know their responsibilities and can protect themselves and avoid the creation of accidents. It is a responsibility, in the situation I am most familiar with in Newfoundland and Labrador, that the Government of Newfoundland and Labrador has undertaken very seriously.
It is a situation that the Newfoundland and Labrador Oil Workers Society has looked at intensively. It has worked very hard to develop not only proper sources of training and proper courses but to ensure that their workers are as trained and as skilled and as capable as possible so they can contribute to the job they are doing that they are very proud of. Many Newfoundlanders and Labradorians have been working offshore and around the world for well over 20 years, and some for longer.
We have a capacity in Newfoundland and Labrador today because we have undertaken a number of technological advances and innovations and because we have worked so hard on training. We have the potential to export that skill and export skilled workers and give them
Government Orders
the opportunity to work around the world when the opportunity is not available at home. That is something we do not like. We do not like to have to go overseas but we recognize that it is something that is important.
This legislation will ensure that as we develop the offshore-be it off Newfoundland and Labrador, be it in the Arctic or off the coast of British Columbia-those who are actually doing the work on the site can do their job knowing that they and those around them will be safe. It will ensure that they know that the environment, which is so fragile and with which they have a balanced relationship, will be protected and that if there is an emergency they can respond in a way that is responsible and positive and that contributes to a solution to the problem not to the problem itself.
In February 1982 this tragedy brought a lot of sadness to a lot of individuals, families and communities, and to our whole province and, I would suggest, to our country. In many ways the passing of this legislation signifies the passing of a time. The hurt and the loss will never be erased or eradicated. The hurt and the loss will never be compensated. It never can be. However there should be some satisfaction that we now have in place a mechanism that will ensure the top level of safety.
We can never guarantee there will never be another accident. Anybody who suggests that we can is misleading themselves and anybody else who listens. However, we can guarantee that we have the best tools and the best skills available.
This legislation ensures that, and assures it to the people directly affected and indirectly affected, those who depend on our oceans and our frontiers.
I commend the House for the work that has been done by all parties in first and second reading and particularly commend the work of the legislative committee and the work done this afternoon. I commend this legislation to the House for its consideration.

Madam Speaker, I want to congratulate my hon. colleague from St. John's East for his presentation on this bill which is very important to him, to me and I am sure to all Canadians, in particular those of us who live in the

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
areas where offshore oil rigs have been the order of the day in the recent past.
I would perhaps like to take more time than I would normally because this is the first time I have spoken on this bill. It is important to give the perspective under which the the bill developed, how it came about and why it is addressing what it is addressing.
Between 1970 and 1990, I do not have the figures between 1990 and 1992, 123 oil rigs were destroyed and over 1,300 lives were lost. The one that we are all concerned with mostly today is the Ocean Ranger tragedy. I will speak about that later because the Ocean Ranger tragedy is related directly to the recommendations of the report and the bill itself.
Just imagine this. In the North Sea on July 6, 1988 an oil rig called the Piper Alpha had an explosion that ripped through its steel superstructure. After a series of explosions and fires the rig was destroyed. One hundred and sixty-seven lives were lost but 61 people miraculously escaped by jumping 175 feet into the water and by sliding down the hoses, sometimes accidentally and sometimes on purpose, in a raging storm in the North Sea.
With that background we can understand the necessity and the concern of all members who have spoken on this bill at first reading, second reading, report stage and now. It does concern safety. It concerns life. It concerns the very reason we are here, to protect life and to make it better.
I now want to address the Ocean Ranger. I do not want to go into all the details of the tragedy, but on February 15, 1982 during a severe Atlantic storm a semi-submersible drilling unit, the Ocean Ranger which was the largest of its kind in the world at the time, capsized and sank 166 nautical miles east of St. John's, Newfoundland. All 84 men on board perished.
In response to the tragedy the Governments of Canada and of Newfoundland and Labrador appointed the joint Royal commission on the Ocean Ranger marine disaster. It was called the Hickman commission and was chaired by the Hon. T. Alexander Hickman, who is now the Chief Justice of Newfoundland.
In August 1984 the commission submitted its initial report that dealt solely with the facts and events pertaining to the ocean disaster. In 1985 the commission submitted its final report that dealt with the broader issues of petroleum operational safety off the Canadian east coast.
It was a comprehensive report. They were comprehensive hearings. The report contained 136 recommendations. On April 14, 1986 the Government of Canada released a status report of the initiatives it had taken in response to the Hickman commission's recommendations. This report indicated that 85 per cent of the commission's recommendations had been implemented in whole or in part.
The commission recommendations that had not been addressed included those dealing with the consistency of regulations of offshore operations and those recommending maintaining the approach of having a single agency exercise regulatory control over mobile operation drilling units.
At the time of the status report's release it was also announced by the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources that he had been given a mandate by cabinet to develop legislative and administrative procedures to address the royal commission's remaining recommendations. To assist the minister in this regard, a private sector task force on Ocean Ranger regulatory recommendations was appointed. The minister requested that the task force prepare proposals, not only for mobile drilling units, but for all types of equipment used in frontier land petroleum activities.
This task force to which I am referring was chaired by Mr. Roland J. Harrison and was known as the Harrison task report and was made up of three specialists: Mr. Harrison, with expertise in oil and gas law, Vice-Admiral Dan Minguay, who had recently retired as the vice-chief of the defence staff, an expert in marine operations, and Dr. Pallister, a Calgary oil and gas industry consultant and who had previously been the vice-chairman of the Science Council of Canada-all expert advice.
They consulted extensively with provincial and industry experts and they examined the regulatory regimes for offshore petroleum operations in the United Kingdom, Norway and the United States. The task force submitted its report, The Promotion and Enhancement of Safety in Oil
June 11, 1992

and Gas Operations on Canadian Frontier Lands, on July 31, 1986.
As a result of this report and that of the Hickman commission, the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources developed the Oil and Gas Production and Conservation Act, a proposal for amending the legislation governing petroleum operations on frontier lands.
The effort of which I have just spoken culminated in this bill, C-58, an act to amend the Oil and Gas Production and Conservation Act and other acts in consequence thereof.
This bill received first reading in the House of Commons on February 20 of this year second reading on April 9th of this year four committee reports, and now we are here for the third and final reading.
There is a lot in the bill and I do not want to repeat a lot of the excellent material that my hon. colleague from St. John's East presented. I know that he sat on the committee and although I did not sit on the committee I have reviewed the testimony of the committees. Certainly there were a number of things that would impress one, having read these committee reports. I want to bring to the attention of the House the two principles of safety that were brought out by Mr. Harrison in his report.
It is very important when you are looking at this legislation to understand these principles. The first one is regarding safety. It reflects the fact that responsibility for the safety of oil and gas operations must rest squarely on the shoulders of those engaged in the operations and of the suppliers of equipment used in the operations.
I am going to use the words of the task force report: "It is fundamentally the responsibility of industry to undertake its activities in a safe manner".
The second principle is that the proposed regime reflect the fact that safety ultimately results not from mere compliance with regulatory requirements as we have here today, nor necessarily from using the best available equipment, but rather from the proper integration of equipment, procedures and personnel. It is an integrated thing.
Government Orders
Those principles have to be borne in mind when you look at the bill and it was for that reason I had some difficulty with some of the amendments.
The purpose of the bill is very simple. It is designed to deal with the technical aspects of regulation of oil and gas and the safety of the installations involved.
I want to get to the main points of the bill. I want to make a personal comment and then I want to state a reservation I have but it will not prevent me or my party from agreeing with the bill. Nevertheless, it is a reservation that I would like to state.
There are essentially nine issues in my mind that this bill addresses. I will go through them as briefly as I can.
The first and probably the paramount one is related to the fact that over and above marine activity, because it happens on the seas, you have another activity, an industrial activity. Both these activities are very hazardous. Sometimes marine activity is more hazardous than industrial activity and vice versa. It is because of this that we have the difficulty of who is the responsible person. Quite frankly, the bill addressed it veiy nicely.
The bill essentially says that in an emergency situation in which the safety of personnel or operations is in jeopardy, the federal energy minister will override all other federal legislations in accordance and in response to the emergency. This override position will ensure that emergencies are immediately responded to in an efficient, co-ordinated manner.
I would have to add at this juncture that I will be looking forward to the regulations that will follow from the legislation once and if it is passed.
The second point is that on every petroleum facility operating on frontier lands, an installation manager who has to be expert in both marine and industrial petroleum operations will be in charge at all times. The qualifications of this manager will be prescribed in regulations and his responsibility will include the safety of all personnel as well as the safety of the facility itself.
The third point is that operators will have to obtain a certificate of fitness issued by an approved independent body in order to obtain the authorization required to conduct petroleum activities. I am not going to go back to any of the disasters. It is not my job here or that of

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
anybody else to go back and look at the causes of accidents. That is encompassed in the bill.
It is significant that a certificate will be required for any facility, installation or equipment defined in regulations and will verify that it is fit and complies with all appropriate regulations and requirements. The certificate will further verify that the facility, installation or equipment can be operated safely for the intended purpose without threat to the environment.
The fourth point is that operators of equipment or facilities used in petroleum operations will have to issue safety declarations to the regulator in order to obtain authorization. These declarations will verify the appropriateness of the operating procedures as well as demonstrating that personnel are qualified, competent and have received appropriate training.
The next point is that a chief safety officer and safety officers will be appointed as statutory officers responsible for independently monitoring safety standards. In other words, this is not self-monitoring. A safety officer will be appointed. There will be somebody overseeing this. I believe that is very important.
The minister must consult with this chief safety officer before issuing any work authorization through his officials. The officer will be responsible for reviewing the system as a whole as well as its components, including all the installations, individually and collectively, the operating procedures and the personnel.
The next and probably one of the more important aspects of this is that an offshore oil and gas training standards advisory board will be created to encourage the development of new training standards, qualifications, accreditation standards and course assessments for positions on offshore facilities. The appointments to this board will be made by the federal energy minister in consultation with the Newfoundland and Nova Scotia energy ministers.
Training with regard to the things that are hazardous is probably, after the regulations, the legislation and the administration are set up, the most dynamic part of this whole business. You can have it all but without the training it is no good. I have taken a personal interest in these events for reasons that my hon. colleague from St.
John's East has mentioned. We have made it our business, irrespective of our parliamentary responsibilities. I have learned and I am pleased to learn that in terms of training and training standards work has been going on for the last six or seven years in developing qualification requirements for individuals working offshore.
Shortly after the Ocean Ranger disaster anyone working offshore had to have rather extensive survival training. I use that in a qualitative sense. Experts could argue with the degree. The important thing is that the training was intensive. Also it is important for people who work offshore that it is not treated as an onshore facility without proper training in things that are marine.
In addition to the other points I mentioned, an oil and gas administration advisory council will be established as a forum for inter-agency promotion of consistency and improvements in the administration of the regulatory regime across frontier lands. In particular, the council will seek to avoid any inconsistent or duplicative requirements which could jeopardize the safety of frontier petroleum activities.
Of the two final points the penultimate one is that the member of the council will be the chairman of the two petroleum boards. A representative will be designated by the federal minister and a representative will be designated by each of the Newfoundland and Nova Scotia energy ministers.
Finally, when a serious spill, accident or incident occurs as defined in these regulations, the minister must order that an independent inquiry will be held to investigate its cause. I do not think it was really that necessary to have it there, but it is always nice to dot the is and cross the is.
It is important to me that the province of Newfoundland in my case, and the province of Nova Scotia in the case of others here tonight, have signed the frontier development accords with the Government of Canada. The two territorial governments, the Newfoundland and Nova Scotia petroleum boards and the industry itself have indicated their support for the amendments that have culminated in this bill.
June 11, 1992

I have a reservation and it is one that I think should go on the record, but I add that I do not think it should hold the bill up. The Hickman commission emphasized the need to impose a graduated scheme of penalties for failure to comply with the regulatory requirements and to ensure the severity of penalties reflecting the significance of non-compliance.
That was not really addressed specifically in the bill. I would not say it was totally disregarded, but specifically as a series of graduated penalties it was not there. I am hoping that perhaps this could be picked up in the regulations as we develop further from the backbone of this particular legislation.
By way of conclusion and if I could be permitted a personal note, I do not mind saying that I have been involved with this bill from the night of the Ocean Ranger tragedy. I happened to be in New York at the time. It was a very bad February night in New York, the middle of February. I remember watching the television. When I heard what I heard I could not believe it. I said: "It is a nightmare".
In the aftermath of the disaster Chief Justice Alex Hickman was appointed as the chairman of the investigative committee. He came and sat in my office in another role I had at the time. We discussed at the very beginning of his investigations some of the aspects of the tragedy and where it may end in the sense of regulations and what recommendations would be taken. Little did I know I would be standing here tonight as the spokesman and associate energy critic for the Liberal Party making comment on it.
I then attended many of the hearings of the Ocean Ranger inquiry itself, read the reports, and I supposed followed the progress of this activity as it progressed.
There is criticism that it has taken 10 years. I am not going to engage in that criticism tonight. There is not a lot we can do about it. The fact that the bill is here tonight, I am thankful for and grateful for. I know it does take a lot of work and a lot of time. If it is any solace, if it is any consolation, perhaps the bill is more complete and more thorough because of the thoroughness of the Hickman report and the Harrison report themselves.
I suppose my final comment on this bill would be that on February 15 this year I attended the memorial service for those men who were lost in the Ocean Ranger tragedy. I had an opportunity to speak with a few of their
Government Orders
survivors. It was a very solemn moment, but I got a message from them and from others who knew them.
They do not want to prolong the agony. It is something they want to have over. They have put their lives in order. It has left a scar on their lives forevermore, but there were two things they wanted to know. They wanted to know when something was going to be put in law. The second thing they wanted to know is when it is put in law, when the legislation does come forward, will it prevent another disaster like the Ocean Ranger?
I am pleased to say that the legislation is here. In my opinion, in the opinion of my party and I think in the opinion of the House, it will prevent another tragedy such as the Ocean Ranger.
We are supportive of this bill and I personally am privileged and honoured to have the opportunity to speak on it this evening.

Madam Speaker, I listened with care to the remarks of my colleague. I understand and appreciate that he, especially as a representative of the province which was most heavily victimized by this particular tragedy, has both personally and in his role as a public representative very strong feelings and concerns about the subject at hand.
I face a problem with this legislation. Generally we are supportive of it. We had some amendments that we utilized as a means of expressing some concerns. We do feel this is a legitimate and longstanding expression of concern by many people in government, both elected and within the bureaucracy and the staffing of the various departments involved. It was a major piece of work to achieve what we all hoped would be the goal of a safe and efficient work place in the offshore.
While my own background is in health and safety and mostly in the lumber industry, I still hold a seaman's card and worked on the ships off the west coast for a number of years. My father was a seaman for some 45 years but involved in a lot of life-boat drills. My dad was almost killed in one when a 500-pound tackle almost crushed his skull at one point.
Even though we go through all those drills in that industry, and especially when there are passengers at stake, we ever have enough familiarity with what is likely to happen in a disaster when it happens, especially a disaster such as the one that happened in the heavy seas

June 11, 1992
Government Orders
off the coast of Newfoundland on that tragic day a little Second, is the committee satisfied that we have all learned from Over 10 years ago.	'he Ocean Ranger incident to prevent such a tragedy from ever
happening again?
We cannot predict the sea. The only thing we can predict is that it will be unpredictable at times. She is a hard master or mistress, I guess as the case is, and can be veiy unforgiving. I would like to read into the record the remarks from one witness before the committee, Miss Cynthia Parsons, the former chair of trustees of the Ocean Ranger Families Foundation. The foundation was funded by government and private donations and was served by a board of directors drawn largely from the community and the families. The government fund ceased in December 1986. The foundation has closed its offices and has not been active since 1986.
Miss Parsons accompanied Mr. Clay Newhook to the committee and gave short testimony. I think it is important to put the whole disastrous matter into perspective. I will read into the record her few words. Miss Parsons said:
In the early morning of February 15, 1982, the drilling rig Ocean Ranger sank in a violent winter storm off the Grand Banks, killing everybody on board. Nobody in the industry, in government, in the community, in the families were prepared in any way for the disaster. My husband Clyde died that morning, leaving me with two small children.
At present, ten and a half years later, most families have put their lives back together. However, all of us carry scars from this tragedy and will never forget the experience.
We found no comfort in the findings of the Hickman commission. When all of the evidence had been sifted, it was clear that with proper training and appropriate safely precautions the rig need not have sunk. Indeed, it was also clear that every corrective action taken after the first major incident only added to the certainty of the disaster.
It further appears that if the rig had been shut down completely after the panel and the ballast control room flooded, the Ocean Ranger and its victims would have survived.
It is not necessary for our purposes today to take you through the history of the Ocean Ranger story. However, two questions need to be asked, which is mainly why I am here this morning.
First, while we are pleased to see that many of the recommendations of the Hickman commission are being reflected in federal and provincial legislation, I have to ask why this has taken so long.
The Ocean Ranger Families Foundation closed its offices in December 1986. There has been no independent agency to watch over this industry and the regulating agencies, nor has there been much offshore activity off the coast of our province. However, we are poised for renewed activity both in drilling and production. We, the public, must now look to our governments and the oil and gas operators to safeguard the public interest in the hostile environment. Failure to do so would mean not only more loss of life but also that my husband would have died in vain.
The major comment I want to make is that when I first came to this place, one of my concerns was that politics was often too full of people who were still idealists and especially idealists about the workplace. While I know that the input of many public servants and politicians to this legislation has the best intent in the world, I also know and many of my colleagues know that as people who have worked in industry we recognize that the best laws and regulations, unless they have ongoing inspection and ongoing enforcement, are not going to accomplish the goals we set out.
That is one of the reasons we have continuously hounded-I think that may be the appropriate word- this government on this bill and on other bills having to do with health and safety.
There is the importance of establishing tripartite representation on a continuing basis at every level through all of the responsible agencies to ensure that the goals and objectives of our laws and regulations are lived up to on the job. For those of us who have worked for years on the job, we know that safety is never in practice the prime consideration.
Anyone who expects safety to be the prime consideration on the job quite frankly is a damn fool. The world does not work that way. It never has, and it never will, even on the part of some employees in industry who get familiar and say: "I have been doing this for years. My family has been doing this for years. We can handle this". It is the risks that go with it that tend to some time, to their own peril, adopt attitudes, and some time ignore and take short cuts that lead to these kinds of tragedies.
Our purpose in law and our purpose in setting up regulatory mechanisms is to minimize the chances of

that pattern of behaviour happening whether in employees, among management, in middle management or in government regulators.
We recently had another industrial disaster at the Westray mine in Nova Scotia. I hope that it will not take 10 years to learn and implement the lessons that we learned from that disaster. I read through the background notes on the legislation now before us, especially when it came to the description of the duties and the responsibilities of the chief safety officer, the chief conservation officer or installation manager.
My colleague from the Official Opposition a few moments ago gave quite good praise I think to the delineation of responsibilities which is fairly clearly set out in the legislation. That is set out. In every act and set of regulations there is a provision for exemptions.
One of those same kinds of exemptions I suspect will be found to have caused the most recent major industrial disaster in this country. While the laws and regulations in the province of Nova Scotia set out that there must be coal mining inspectors, the minister waived that and instead had hard rock mining inspectors investigating in that coal mine.
There is not an insistence on a day-to-day basis by representatives of both management and employees and government that keep a continuing watch on the application of the laws and the regulations that we construct.
With all the best intent in the world, and I am sure all of us here have that, we are living in a dream world to think that management, government inspectors and employees will do what is necessary to create safe work places, especially in these most hazardous potential conditions, unless there is an ongoing process where they keep tabs on each other, on their purposes and on their practices on a day-by-day and sometimes minute-by-minute basis.
We tried through a number of our amendments- again, some of them were simply there in large part to make a point-to attempt to stress the importance of developing evacuation systems. I know a lot of work has been done. We are aware of that, but we still have not developed, according to everything we heard, a system that will work.
Government Orders
If we want to put some priorities on human life and on human life in the work place, especially when there are large numbers of lives at risk, surely we as a society ought to get some of our financial priorities right.
If we can put men and women in the most hostile of environments, in outer space, and have them floating around and bringing vehicles together and pulling them apart surely it is not too much to expect that we could keep people alive in the water, evacuate them with some security and safety and get them into vessels to keep them alive for reasonable periods until we can bring them back to shore. If the will is there and if we are willing to place a high value on human life, as we do on many other objectives in this society and in other developed societies, we can accomplish that.
However, unless we set ourselves some specific targets and say that efficient, effective evacuation systems are a must then that is going to get by-passed, particularly when the overriding responsibility is with the ministry. For all the excellent people involved in it the ministry's prime objective is the production of our energy resources and the maximizing of both private and governmental revenue from those resources rather than the safety and security of people who work in hazardous industries.
In conclusion, if we want a regime that protects people's lives it must be a regime that sets up on an ongoing basis, not just sketched out in regulations or in law but in living, breathing people who we pay to be involved at the bottom level, as well as the medium and upper levels, to insist that all maximum measures are taken to comply with both the letter and the spirit of that law and of those regulations. Otherwise, we are just a bunch of flaming idealists and nothing will happen to make the oceans or the rigs any more secure for the people who work on them or for the communities they come from.

Madam Speaker, I rise with respect to a question that I posed to the Deputy Prime Minister and that was responded to by the Minister of Justice as recorded in the House of Commons Debates of May 4.
My question concerned the rejection, until that point, by the government and the Official Opposition of a proposed amendment to the Charter of Rights and Freedoms that would have provided for a commitment on the part of governments to preserve and promote racial and ethnic equality.
I take this opportunity to point out that under present circumstances equality and non-discrimination rights are provided for in section 15(1) of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
That provision is subject to section 33 of the charter which is the notwithstanding clause. That clause provides of course for legislatures, including the Parliament of Canada, to override the rights which are set out in section 15(1).
The essential effect of those two sections in the Charter of Rights and Freedoms is to provide an explicit declaration of the inequality of the groups listed in section 15(1).
My specific reference in the question was to ethnic and racial minorities because the proposition was advanced that would amend section 27, which presently provides for the preservation and enhancement of the multicultural heritage of Canadians, such that it would provide
for a commitment by those governments to preserve and promote racial and ethnic equality.
Since that question was posed to the minister, the province of Ontario has advanced propositions for the inclusion of the recognition of racial and ethnic equality in the Canada clause and in fact proposed the amendment to section 27 that I just set out.
I understand as well that the government in the negotiations which took place last week expressed some support for some form of expression of that principle of a non-contingent recognition of racial and ethnic equality in the revised Constitution which we hope will result from the present constitutional negotiations.
In my question, I identified the refusal of the Leader of the Official Opposition to support this proposition, a position that the Leader of the Official Opposition still maintains.
In fact, in recent correspondence the Leader of the Official Opposition launched upon a defence of the notwithstanding clause which did not address the issue yet to this day whether the Liberal Party is able and willing to recognize the principle about which I asked the Minister of Justice.
Therefore my intervention here takes the form of inquiring what is the present status of that proposed amendment? What is the position of the government with respect to it?
I want to make reference as well to the latter part of the minister's answer. She seemed to exhibit some misapprehension of my understanding of the role of the charter and attempted to therefore explain the implications of what I said which I fully understood in the first place and that is what I said required amendment.
The minister had an interesting final or penultimate sentence in her response. She said: "I do think that we have within the hands of responsible authorities at all three levels of government in this country enough legal devices to do the job". Now we must construe that what she was talking about was the enforcement of the principle of equality through actions of government and in legislation.
Madam Speaker, I would only say this in closing since I see that you are demanding I do so. There is much outside of that context that needs to be done but the establishment of a principle in the Constitution that all Canadians are equal is of fundamental importance. It is an issue I hope this government and the Leader of the

speakeroldname: Mr. John A. MacDougall (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources):

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have quite detailed information from the Justice Department and I am hoping that if I am not able to read all of it into the record that the balance will be placed on the record.
The multicultural and multiracial character of Canada was officially recognized by the federal government when the federal multiculturalism policy was introduced in 1971.
Since then equality rights and multiculturalism have been entrenched in sections 15 and 27 of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The Canadian Multiculturalism Act was passed in 1988. As well federal, provincial, and territorial human rights laws prohibit discrimination on the basis of race and colour.
In view of Canada's increasing ethnic diversity the Department of Justice is taking steps to consider the multicultural nature of Canada's society in the development of policy and discharge of responsibilities.
The principles of a fair and equitable justice system are basic to the goals of the Department of Justice and apply no less to our approach to multiculturalism.
All Canadians should enjoy uninhibited access to the system including legal assistance, victim/witness services, recourse to the courts, and other legal mechanisms for redress and resolution of disputes.
The Department of Justice is committed to promoting a harmonious multicultural society.
Madam Speaker, I would like to table the balance of my response.

Immigrant populations need to learn as quickly as possible about the laws regulating important aspects of
Adjournment Debate
daily life and ways to get information about the legal system.
They also need to use and to feel comfortable using the Canadian justice system. In addition to its cost-shared access to justice programs, such as public legal education and legal aid, the department conducts research and supports pilot projects in order to assist service delivery agencies to improve the delivery of justice services to members of multicultural groups.
Lawyers and judges and, indeed all justice system professionals, must be sensitized to the various ethnocultural clientele they will encounter, and the laws and legal process must be clear to all Canadians, regardless of their first language. The department is supporting the Canadian Judicial Centre and the Western Judicial Education Centre in their efforts to provide judges with training to sensitize them to cultural differences of minority groups.
Further, the department is committed to hiring practices which will increase the representation of visible minority personnel to better reflect their representation in the population. Awareness training concerning multiculturalism is being provided to managers in order to enhance the notion of "inclusive justice" which means making the justice system more accountable, more responsive, and more reflective of the interests and value of all Canadians.
I should add that the compounded inequities encountered by minority women will be considered in all research by the Department of Justice. One of the most powerful messages delivered at the National Symposium on Women, Law and the Administration of Justice hosted by the Minister of Justice in June 1991, was that visible minority women face multiple disadvantages resulting from gender bias and racism.
The Department of Justice is committed to work with the provinces and concerned groups to ensure fair treatment of all people who become involved in the system and to eliminate barriers affecting visible minorities.

Madam Speaker, I rise on the question that I asked the Minister of Employment and Immigration, a question relating to an event in my riding that goes back to February 21 of this year.

June 11, 1992
Adjournment Debate
I think the fish processing plant in Port Union is going to become a very well-known plant because this is about the fifteenth time that I have been up to speak on this subject. I will be up 15 more times, until I get some kind of an answer or some kind of redress to the question that I have been asking.
It is a very simple question. On February 21 this plant, on the tip of the Bonavista peninsula in the town of Port Union, closed. It employs 1,200 people and at the time all those working were laid off. The crux of the question was that are 80 families, less than that at the time because of other events that have occurred, that were not covered by unemployment insurance. Some of them had two weeks, three weeks, or four weeks.
My basic point has been that since the government is responsible for managing the fishery, it has been responsible for eight years, and since the fishery has failed dismally then it is my belief, and it is shared by others, that the government has some responsibility to those people who through no fault of their own are without work, without fish, without income, and now they are almost without food.
I am not known in this House for dramatizing, exaggerating or over-emphasizing. However, I cannot emphasize with more vigour, enthusiasm and feeling the need of those people who have no source of income.
Imagine the frustration. By the time I asked the minister this question it was question number 7 or number 8 in two months, and that is not unreasonable. I asked the minister about the families and wondered when could I expect some form of compensation. In the response this Minister of State for Employment and Immigration said that: "We could look for a way out in conjunction with the private sector".
I had to inform the House and the parliamentary secretary that there are no other jobs, there is no other industry, there is nothing. We can train people for as long as we are alive, but train them for what. They cannot even go to Toronto or Montreal because the unemployment is so bad there that people are leaving there and going somewhere else.
However, the minister did give hope and she went on to say in response to my supplementary: "For the time
being we are trying to do what we can and to focus on the training and adjustment of the workers".
Only yesterday, on the same subject, the minister responded and said with respect to contingency funding that when the need arises the government will come forward with a response.
Today I was very specific. He was talking about hypothetical questions. He asked: "How can I give you an answer to a hypothetical question?"
I was very specific today, which relates to the question that I asked May 8. The specific thing was that 80 families had no work, no compensation and no idea as to what sort of compensation, support or care they are going to get from the government.
It is a very desolate situation when you wake up in the morning and have no job, no money and no place to go except to hope that somebody is going to come to your rescue.
I do not like pleading but I am pleading to the government with all the emotion that I can muster without getting loud and without becoming obstreperous.
Please come to the rescue of these people who badly need it. They are in hardship. They are in dire need and they are crying out to me for the government's help and I am crying out to the government.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on behalf of the Minister of Employment and Immigration, I would like to respond to the hon. member's question tonight.
The situation in the Atlantic fishery has been and continues to be of major concern to the government. In this regard, a number of programs and services have been put in place to deal with the problems in the fishing industry.
I would like to mention to the House that since 1984, the federal government has directed almost $1.4 billion in unemployment insurance and training benefits to individuals in the fishing industry.
The five-year, $584 million Atlantic Fisheries Adjustment Program was announced in May 1990 and includes measures to rebuild fish stocks and to help those who wish to leave the industry adjust.
June 11, 1992

There have also been short-term emergency response programs such as last year's $130 million relief program to help plant workers and fishermen adjust. Another $22 million has been distributed to assist Newfoundland fishermen affected by ice conditions.
As we speak, a task force on incomes and adjustments is advising the government on issues such as the continued supply of the resource, the future stability and profitability of the industry and the achievement of stable and adequate incomes for those who make a living in the fishing industry.
The recent decision by the World Court on St. Pierre and Miquelon, the fishery treaty signed at the earth summit in Rio de Janeiro and the continued pressure on countries that overfish along the Grand Banks, all of these demonstrate that this government is doing its utmost to put the needs of the fishing industry at the forefront of its national and international agenda.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have another opportunity to pursue a question which I raised in this House concerning the move by cable companies to remove Canadian broadcasting services like MuchMusic or TSN from Canadian consumers television sets unless they decide to take on more American stations or more American services at an additional price.
I find this a rather curious way to promote Canadian programming for all of us here in Canada. To deliver this choice, the procedure is for the cable companies advise their consumers that the onus of responsibility is on them to call the cable company if they do not wish to have and do not wish to pay for the new service. Otherwise it becomes an automatic "I accepted".
In other words if you want the service you do nothing but if you do not want it you must call. It is a very strange way to do business. Ottawa has been the latest area to take this approach and the response has been very interesting.
I would just like to quote from one area resident who wrote: "I find somewhat disconcerting that MacLean Hunter Cable Television can send out under the guise of an exciting new concept a brochure to an unsuspecting subscriber and this in my opinion, amounts to an unsolic-
Adjoumment Debate
ited increase in the monthly cable charges. Particularly disquieting is that MacLean Hunter places the onus on the consumer to reply". He went on to say that he felt that the CRTC should shield consumers from such practices. He felt the CRTC has a responsibility to the Canadian populace to protect it from such practices.
This marketing technique is known as the negative option. I find it very objectionable. In fact, in the province of Quebec, the technique is against the law in the selling of products while its use with services is currently under debate.
Canadian broadcasters are concerned about the potential impact. They see this as a potential loss of income from advertising and decline in audience ratings. That is the last thing we need here in Canada as we are trying to build up our television broadcasting situation.
The president of the CBC, Mr. Veilleux in his speech to The Financial Post conference on April 8, 1992, said the following:
To be blunt, we-none of us-can afford to have our audience bled from above by satellite and bled from below by cable systems who are prepared to create even greater American competition for Canadian program services.
I have in mind, of course, the negative option marketing approach now being used by the cable industry-an approach in which subscribers are given the choice of dropping two or three Canadian services and saving a bit of money-or adding four or five American channels and paying more. Canadian programming-and jobs - become hostage to U.S. broadcasters. What a prospect!
This effectively means "basic" cable for at least 90 per cent of subscribers, will expand by that many new U.S. services, and the further fragmentation will cost Canadian channels both viewers and commercial revenues.
Canadians have access to a broad array of television services. Choice is one of the cornerstones of government's policy on the Canadian broadcasting system. At present some 50 per cent of Canada's cable subscribers have access to what is called an extended basic tier, which is sort of a package of TV services that includes Canadian specialty services and TV services linked with U.S. specialty services.
The negative option marketing practice used by the cable industry to ensure higher penetration of this tier is the mechanism. However, I do believe this is not based on the principle of consumer choice or fairness. Rather I

June 11, 1992
Adjournment Debate
believe it is based on silent acquiescence of the Canadian cable subscriber.
In conclusion, I call upon the Minister of Communications to ask the CRTC to investigate the financial, cultural and consumer impact of the introduction of more American channels on the Canadian broadcasting system through the use of negative option marketing strategies.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, what a pleasure it is to be re-engaged in debate on these matters with my hon. friend. We had discussions for over seven years on these matters. I am pleased to deal with this issue which results from the practice of cable operators making available to their subscribers an extended basic tier.
An extended basic tier involves providing a new service or a group of services to all subscribers on a free trial basis for a period of time, then inviting those customers who do not wish to subscribe to the tier to advise their cable company.
I wish to point out this practice is not new and has been used by cable operators, many of them in western Canada but not confined to western Canada, for some time.
The benefit of the approach to subscribers is that they are given more flexibility to choose to receive specialty services of particular interest to them at a very low cost. The Canadian specialty service available on the extended basic tier include Much Music, the Sports Network, and TV5.
Some American specialty or narrow cast services such as the Nashville Network, Cable News Network, and the Arts and Entertainment Network are authorized by the CRTC for this tier as packaging partners with the Canadian services.
The CRTC has permitted the offering of the U.S. specialty services to enhance the attractiveness of the tier in order to maximize the penetration of the Canadian specialty services. TV5 is an example of a Canadian service "that is now much more widely available than previously because of this practice".
Recently the CRTC announced that it will be holding hearings to look into the whole issue of specialty services tiering. As many members may be aware-and I am sure my hon. friend for Mount Royal is aware of it-discussions are now taking place between representatives of the Canadian broadcasting industry and the Department of Communications toward developing a long-term industrial strategy in the context of the second phase of the Canadian television summit.
The impact on the Canadian broadcasting industry of an increased number of American television services being offered in Canada is currently being studied as part of the second phase of that summit. The industry has been asked to submit a report to the Minister of Communications, and that report is expected in the very near future.

Madam Speaker, I would like to thank the Minister of State for Transport for her attitude in responding to my question of June 3 regarding the obsolete Soviet flag being displayed at the Calgary airport during the North Atlantic Assembly meeting that was held in Banff from May 14 to May 18.
I found it very strange that months after the Soviet Union had disappeared and months after Canada had recognized the nations of the former Soviet Union participating in the North Atlantic Assembly, for instance Russia, Ukraine, Byelorussia and the Baltic states, and months after Canada had established diplomatic relations with those nations, this obsolete symbol would still be displayed at the Calgary International Airport.
It indicates to me a lack of communication between the government and the bureaucrats at the lower level. It is not because we do not have enough bureaucrats or infrastructure that would respond to such an action.
Therefore we can ask ourselves: Was it because there was lack of communication, intelligence or simply negligence? I am sure all three elements played a role. It is not the minister's responsibility if a faux pas has been committed by one of the department's bureaucrats. This incident proves that the minister cannot be responsible for all the actions taken on his or her behalf.
This puts in question the tradition of ministerial responsibility. Those responsible should be taken to task. In this particular instance it is those at the Calgary airport. They should not hide behind the minister of state's skirt. Bureaucrats should be responsible for their actions, but if those higher up want to protect them, they should be taken to task as well. As long as this type of system exists, you will not have efficiency or good government in Canada. We will be unable to address the problems of expensive and inefficient government. This is why we have a problem with debt and debt deduction and the huge deficit of $420 billion.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have this
June 11, 1992

opportunity to respond to the question by the hon. member for Calgary Northeast about the flag display at Calgary International Airport. I had the same questions when I saw those flags flying and have discovered, as the minister has reported, that the many international flags that hung until recently in that air terminal building were intended as a visual tribute to the nations which sent teams of athletes or officials to the 1988 Winter Olympics.
Although Calgary International Airport management was fully aware that the geopolitical state of the world could change over time, it was decided to maintain the original flag display to remind the many visitors to that airport of the countries which were represented in the 1988 games. In other words, it is kind of a snapshot display of the international scheme which emphasized the significance of the 15th Winter Olympics and remembered the nations which had participated in those games. It was neither intended to reflect ongoing inter-
Adjoumment Debate
national geopolitical changes nor to symbolize the nations which attended the North Atlantic Assembly Conference recently held in Calgary and Banff.
I understand that the airport has recently substituted the display's Olympic motif with flags from Canada's provinces and territories which is a fitting salute to Canada's 125 anniversary. The flag of the former Soviet Union has been removed and flags from nations that provide the largest number of tourists to Calgary have now been given prominence.
